nLab
geometry of physics -- categories and toposes

Skip the Navigation Links | Home Page | All Pages | Latest Revisions | Discuss this page | Feeds |

This page is going to be one chapter in geometry of physics.

next chapter: smooth sets

under construction

\,

\,

Category theory and topos theory concern the general abstract structure underlying algebra, geometry and logic. They are ubiquituous in and indispensible for organizing concpetual mathematical frameworks.

We give here an introduction to the basic concepts and results, aimed at providing background for the synthetic higher supergeometry of relevance in formulations of fundamental physics, such as used in the chapters on perturbative quantum field theory and on fundamental super p-branes.

This makes use of the following curious dictionary between category theory/topos theory and the geometry of generalized spaces, which we will explain in detail (following Grothendieck 65, Lawvere 86, p. 17, Lawvere 91):

A\phantom{A}category theoryRmk. 2A\phantom{A}geometry of generalized spaces
A\phantom{A}presheafExpl. 14A\phantom{A}generalized space
A\phantom{A}representable presheafA\phantom{A}Expl. 15A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A}model space
A\phantom{A}regarded as generalized space
A\phantom{A}Yoneda lemmaProp. 1A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A}sets of probes of generalized spaces
A\phantom{A}are indeed
A\phantom{A}sets of maps from model spaces A\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A}Yoneda embedding A\phantom{A}Prop. 2A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A}nature of model spaces is preserved when
A\phantom{A}regarding them as generalized spaces A\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A}topos theoryRmk. 9A\phantom{A}local-global principle for generalized spacesA\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A}coverageDefn. 34A\phantom{A}notion of locality
A\phantom{A}sheaf conditionDefn. 36A\phantom{A}
Prop. 31		A\phantom{A}plots of generalized spaces
A\phantom{A}satisfy local-to-global principle A\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A}comparison lemmaProp. 28A\phantom{A}notion of generalized spaces
A\phantom{A}independent under change of model space
A\phantom{A}gros topos theoryRmk. 14A\phantom{A}generalized spaces at the foundations
A\phantom{A}cohesionDefn. 41A\phantom{A}generalized spaces obey
A\phantom{A}principles of differential topology
A\phantom{A}differential cohesionDefn. 44A\phantom{A}generalized spaces obey
A\phantom{A}principles of differential geometry
A\phantom{A}super cohesionA\phantom{A}A\phantom{A}generalized spaces obey
A\phantom{A}principles of supergeometry

This is the perspective of functorial geometry (Grothendieck 65). (For more exposition of this point see also at motivation for sheaves, cohomology and higher stacks.)

Hence one motivation for category theory and topos theory is a posteriori: As a matter of experience, there is just no other toolbox that allows one to really understand and handle the higher supergeometry of relevance in physics. Similar comments apply to a wealth of other topics of mathematics.

We offer also an a priori motivation: Category theory is the theory of duality.

Duality is of course an ancient notion in philosophy. At least as a term, it makes a curious re-appearance in the conjectural theory of fundamental physics formerly known as string theory. In both cases, the literature left some room in delineating what precisely is meant. But the philosophically inclined mathematician could notice (see Lambek 82) that an excellent candidate to make precise the idea of duality is the mathematical concept of adjunction, from category theory.

Historically, category theory was introduced in order to make precise the concept of natural transformation: The concept of functors was introduced just so as to support that of natural transformations, and the concept of categories only served that of functors (see e.g. Freyd 65, Part II). But natural transformations are what allows us to define, in turn, the concept of adjoint functors, also called adjunctions between categories. All the deep concepts of category theory (such as representable functors, Yoneda embedding, Kan extensions, hence limits and colimits, to be introduced below) are special cases of adjoint functor constructions â€“ hence of dualities, if we follow Lambek 82. Therefore it makes sense to regard category theory, to a large extent, as the theory of adjunctions, hence the theory of duality:

A\phantom{A} hierarchy of concepts A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} category theory A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} enriched category theory A\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A} adjoint equivalence / A\phantom{A}
AA\phantom{AA} dual equivalence AA\phantom{AA}		A\phantom{A} Def. 13 A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} Def. 30 A\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A} adjunction / duality A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} Def. 10 A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} Def. 29 A\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A} natural transformation A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} Def. 9 A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} Def. 27 A\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A} functor A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} Def. 6 A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} Def. 26 A\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A} category A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} Def. 1 A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} Def. 24 A\phantom{A}

The pivotal role of adjunctions in category theory (Lawvere 08) and in the foundations of mathematics (Lawvere 69, Lawvere 94 ) was particularly amplified by F. W. Lawvere1. Moreover, Lawvere saw the future of category theory (Lawvere 91) as concerned with adjunctions expressing systems of archetypical dualities that reveal foundations for geometry (Lawvere 07) and physics (Lawvere 97). He suggested (Lawvere 94) this as a precise formulation of core aspects of the theory of everything of early 19th century philosophy: Hegelâ€™s Science of Logic.

These days, of course, theories of everything, such as string theory, are understood less ambitiously than Hegelâ€™s ontological process, as mathematical formulations of fundamental theories of physics, that could conceptually unify the hodge-podge of currently available â€œstandard modelsâ€ of particle physics and of cosmology to a more coherent whole.

The idea of duality in string theory refers to different perspectives on physics that appear dual to each other while being equivalent. But one of the basic results of category theory (Prop. 9, below) is that equivalence is indeed a special case of adjunction. This allows to explore the possibility that there is more than a coincidence of terms.

Of course the usage of the term duality in string theory is too loose for one to expect to be able to refine each occurrence of the term in the literature to a mathematical adjunction. However, we will see mathematical formalizations of core aspects of key string-theoretic dualities, such as topological T-duality and the duality between M-theory and type IIA string theory, in terms of adjunctions. Indeed, at the heart of these dualities in string theory is the phenomenon of double dimensional reduction, which turns out to be formalized by one of the most fundamental adjunctions in (higher category theory (base change along the point inclusion into a classifying space). All this is discussed in the chapter on fundamental super p-branes.

This suggests that there may be a deeper relation here between the superficially alien uses of the word â€œdualityâ€, that is worth exploring.

In this respect it is worth noticing that core structure of string/M-theory arises via universal constructions from the superpoint (as explained in the chapter on fundamental super p-branes), while the superpoint itself arises, in a sense made precise by category theory, â€œfrom nothingâ€, by a system of twelve adjunctions (explained in the chapter on supergeometry).

\,

Here we introduce the requisites for understanding these statements.

\,

Contents

  • Basic notions of Category theory
    • Categories and Functors
    • Natural transformations and presheaves
    • Adjunctions
    • Equivalences
    • Modalities
  • Basic notions of Categorical algebra
    • Monoidal categories
    • Enriched categories
  • Universal constructions
    • Limits and colimits
    • Ends and coends
    • Kan extensions
    • Further properties
  • Basic notions of Topos theory
    • Descent
    • Codescent
  • Cohesive toposes

Basic notions of Category theory

We introduce here the basic notions of category theory, along with examples and motivation from geometry:

  1. Categories and functors

  2. Natural transformations and presheaves

  3. Adjunctions

  4. Equivalences

  5. Modalities

This constitutes what is sometimes called the language of categories. While we state and prove some basic facts here, notably the notorious Yoneda lemma (Prop. 1 below), what makes category theory be a mathematical theory in the sense of a coherent collection of non-trivial theorems is all concerned with the topic of universal constructions, which may be formulated (only) in this language. This we turn to further below.

\,

Categories and Functors

The notion of a category (Def. 1 below) embodies the idea of structuralism applied to concepts in mathematics: it collects, on top of the set (or generally: class) of mathematical objects that belong to it, also all the structure-preserving maps between them, hence the homomorphisms in the case of Bourbaki-style mathematical structures.

The first achievement of the notion of a category is to abstract away from such manifestly concrete categories (Examples 2, 10 below) to more indirectly defined mathematical objects whose â€œstructureâ€ is only defined, after the fact, by which maps, now just called morphisms, there are between them.

This structuralism-principle bootstraps itself to life by considering morphisms between categories themselves to be those â€œmapsâ€ that respect their structuralism, namely the connectivity and composition of the morphisms between their objects: These are the functors (Def. 6 below).

For the purpose of geometry, a key class of examples of functors are the assignments of algebras of functions to spaces, this is Example 11 below.

\,

Definition

(category)

A category ð’ž\mathcal{C} is

  1. a class Obj ð’žObj_{\mathcal{C}}, called the class of objects;

  2. for each pair X,YâˆˆObj ð’žX,Y \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}} of objects, a set Hom ð’ž(X,Y)Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y), called the set of morphisms from XX to YY, of the hom-set, for short.

    We denote the elements of this set by arrows like this:

    XâŸ¶fYâˆˆHom ð’ž(X,Y). X \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} Y \;\;\in Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y) \,.

  3. for each object XâˆˆObj ð’žX \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}} a morphism

    Xâ†’id XXâˆˆHom ð’ž(X,X) X \overset{id_X}{\to} X \;\; \in Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,X)

    called the identity morphism on XX;

  4. for each triple X 1,X 2,X 3âˆˆObjX_1, X_2, X_3 \in Obj of objects, a function

    Hom ð’ž(X 1,X 2) Ã— Hom ð’ž(X 2,X 3) âŸ¶âˆ˜ X 1,X 2,X 3 Hom ð’ž(X 1,X 3) X 1â†’fX 2 , X 2â†’fX 3 â†¦ X 1âŸ¶gâˆ˜fX 3 \array{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X_1, X_2) &\times& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X_2, X_3) &\overset{\circ_{X_1,X_2,X_3}}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X_1, X_3) \\ X_1 \overset{f}{\to} X_2 &,& X_2 \overset{f}{\to} X_3 &\mapsto& X_1 \overset{ g \circ f }{\longrightarrow} X_3 }

    called composition;

such that:

  1. for all pairs of objects X,YâˆˆObj ð’žX,Y \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}} unitality holds: given

    Xâ†’fYâˆˆHom ð’ž(X,Y) X \overset{f}{\to} Y \;\;\in Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y)

    then

    XâŸ¶id Yâˆ˜fY=XâŸ¶fY=XâŸ¶fâˆ˜id XY; X \overset{id_Y \circ f}{\longrightarrow} Y \;=\; X \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} Y \;=\; X \overset{f \circ id_X }{\longrightarrow} Y \,;

  2. for all quadruples of objects X 1,X 2,X 3,X 4âˆˆObj ð’žX_1, X_2, X_3, X_4 \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}} composition satifies associativity: given

    X 1â†’f 12X 2â†’f 23X 3â†’f 34X 4 X_1 \overset{f_{12}}{\to} X_2 \overset{f_{23}}{\to} X_3 \overset{f_{34}}{\to} X_4

    then

    X 1âŸ¶f 34âˆ˜(f 23âˆ˜f 12)X 4=X 1âŸ¶(f 34âˆ˜f 23)âˆ˜f 12X 4. X_1 \overset{f_{34} \circ (f_{23} \circ f_{12})}{\longrightarrow} X_4 \;\;=\;\; X_1 \overset{(f_{34} \circ f_{23}) \circ f_{12}}{\longrightarrow} X_4 \,.

The archetypical example of a category is the category of sets:

Example

(category of all sets)

The class of all sets with functions between them is a category (Def. 1), to be denoted Set:

  • Obj Set=class of all setsObj_{Set} = \text{class of all sets};

  • Hom Set(X,Y)=set of functions from set X to set YHom_{Set}(X,Y) = \text{set of functions from set X to set Y};

  • id XâˆˆHom Set(X,X)=id_X \in Hom_{Set}(X,X) = identity function on set XX;

  • âˆ˜ X 1,X 2,X 3=ordinary composition of functions\circ_{X_1,X_2,X_3} = \text{ordinary composition of functions}.

More generally all kind of sets with structure, in the sense going back to Bourbaki, form categories, where the morphisms are the homomorphisms (whence the name â€œmorphismâ€!). These are called concrete categories (we characterize them precisely in Example 10, further below):

Example

(basic examples of concrete categories)

For ð’®\mathcal{S} a kind of mathematical structure, there is the category (Def. 1) ð’®Set\mathcal{S}Set whose objects are the corresponding structured sets, and whose morphisms are the corresponding structure homomorphisms, hence the functions of underlying sets which respect the given structure.

Basic examples of concrete categories include the following:

A\phantom{A}concrete categoryA\phantom{A}A\phantom{A}objectsA\phantom{A}A\phantom{A}morphismsA\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A}SetA\phantom{A}setsA\phantom{A}functions
A\phantom{A}TopA\phantom{A}topological spacesA\phantom{A}A\phantom{A}continuous functionsA\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A}Mfd k{}_{k}A\phantom{A}differentiable manifoldsA\phantom{A}A\phantom{A}differentiable functionsA\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A}VectA\phantom{A}vector spacesA\phantom{A}A\phantom{A}linear functionsA\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A}GrpA\phantom{A}groupsA\phantom{A}A\phantom{A}group homomorphismsA\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A}AlgA\phantom{A}algebrasA\phantom{A}A\phantom{A}algebra homomorphismA\phantom{A}

This is the motivation for the terminology â€œcategoriesâ€, as the examples in Example 2 are literally categories of mathematical structures. But not all categories are â€œconcreteâ€ in this way.

Some terminology:

Definition

(commuting diagram)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a category (Def. 1), then a directed graph with edges labeled by morphisms of the category is called a commuting diagram if for any two vertices any two ways of passing along edges from one to the other yields the same composition of the corresponding morphisms.

For example, a commuting triangle is

f=hâˆ˜gAAAAAA X gâ†™ â†˜ f Y âŸ¶AhA Z f = h \circ g \phantom{AAAAAA} \array{ && X \\ & {}^{\mathllap{ g }}\swarrow && \searrow^{ \mathrlap{ f } } \\ Y && \underset{\phantom{A}h\phantom{A}}{\longrightarrow} && Z }

while a commuting square is

g 1âˆ˜f 1=g 2âˆ˜f 2AAAAAAX âŸ¶Af 1A Y 1 f 2â†“ â†“ g 1 Y 2 âŸ¶Ag 2A Z g_1 \circ f_1 \;=\; g_2 \circ f_2 \phantom{AAAAAA} \array{ X &\overset{\phantom{A}f_1\phantom{A}}{\longrightarrow}& Y_1 \\ {}^{ \mathllap{f_2} }\big\downarrow && \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{ g_1 }} \\ Y_2 &\underset{\phantom{A}g_2\phantom{A}}{\longrightarrow}& Z }
Definition

(small category)

If a category ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Def. 1) happens to have as class Obj ð’žObj_{\mathcal{C}} of objects an actual set (i.e. a small set instead of a proper class), then ð’ž\mathcal{C} is called a small category.

As usual, there are some trivial examples, that are however useful to make explicit for the development of the theory:

Example

(initial category and terminal category)

  1. The terminal category *\ast is the category (Def. 1) whose class of objects is the singleton set, and which has a single morphism on this object, necessarily the identity morphism.

  2. The initial category or empty category âˆ…\emptyset is the category (Def. 1) whose class of objects is the empty set, and which, hence, has no morphism whatsoever.

Clearly, these are small categories (Def. 3).

Definition

(isomorphism)

For ð’ž\mathcal{C} a category (Def. 1), a morphism

Xâ†’fYâˆˆHom ð’ž(X,Y) X \overset{f}{\to} Y \;\;\in Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y)

is called an isomorphism if there exists an inverse morphism

YâŸ¶f âˆ’1YâˆˆHom ð’ž(Y,X) Y \overset{f^{-1}}{\longrightarrow} Y \;\; \in Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Y,X)

namely a morphism such that the compositions with ff are equal to the identity morphisms on XX and YY, respectively

f âˆ’1âˆ˜f=id XAAAfâˆ˜f âˆ’1=id Y f^{-1} \circ f \;=\; id_X \phantom{AAA} f \circ f^{-1} \;=\; id_Y
Definition

(groupoid)

If ð’ž\mathcal{C} is a category in which every morphism is an isomorphism (Def. 4), then ð’ž\mathcal{C} is called a groupoid.

Example

(delooping groupoid)

For GG a group, there is a groupoid (Def. 5) BG\mathbf{B}G with a single object, whose single hom-set is GG, with identity morphism the neutral element and composition the group operation in GG:

  • Obj BG=*Obj_{\mathbf{B}G} = \ast

  • Hom ð’ž(*,*)=GHom_{\mathcal{C}}(\ast,\ast) \;=\; G

In fact every groupoid with precisely one object is of the form.

Remark

(groupoids and homotopy theory)

Even though groupoids (Def. 5) are special cases of categories (Def. 1), the theory of groupoids in itself has a rather different flavour than that of category theory: Part of the homotopy hypothesis-theorem is that the theory of groupoids is really homotopy theory for the special case of homotopy 1-types.

(In applications in homotopy theory, groupoids are considered mostly in the case that the class Obj ð’žObj_{\mathcal{C}} of objects is in fact a set: small groupoids, Def. 3).

For this reason we will not have more to say about groupoids here, and instead relegate their discussion to the chapter on homotopy theory.

There is a range of constructions that provide new categories from given ones:

Example

(opposite category)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a category. Then its opposite category ð’ž op\mathcal{C}^{op} has the same objects as ð’ž\mathcal{C}, but the direction of the morphisms is reversed. Accordingly, composition in the opposite category ð’ž op\mathcal{C}^{op} is that in ð’ž\mathcal{C}, but with the order of the arguments reversed:

  • Obj ð’ž opâ‰”Obj ð’žObj_{\mathcal{C}^{op}} \;\coloneqq\; Obj_{\mathcal{C}};

  • Hom ð’ž op(X,Y)â‰”Hom ð’ž(Y,X)Hom_{\mathcal{C}^{op}}(X,Y) \;\coloneqq\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Y,X).

Example

(product category)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} and ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be two categories (Def. 1). Then their product category ð’žÃ—ð’Ÿ\mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{D} has as objects pairs (c,d)(c,d) with câˆˆObj ð’žc \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}} and dâˆˆObj ð’Ÿd \in Obj_{\mathcal{D}}, and as morphisms pairs (c 1â†’fc 2)âˆˆHom ð’ž(c 1,c 2) (c_1 \overset{f}{\to} c_2) \in Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c_1,c_2), (d 1â†’gd 2)âˆˆHom ð’Ÿ(d 1,d 2) (d_1 \overset{g}{\to} d_2) \in Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(d_1,d_2), and composition is defined by composition in each entry:

  • Obj ð’žÃ—ð’Ÿâ‰”Obj ð’žÃ—Obj ð’ŸObj_{\mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{D}} \coloneqq Obj_{\mathcal{C}} \times Obj_{\mathcal{D}};

  • Hom ð’žÃ—ð’Ÿ((c 1,d 1),(c 2,d 2))â‰”Hom ð’ž(c 1,c 2)Ã—Hom ð’Ÿ(d 1,d 2)Hom_{\mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{D}}( (c_1,d_1), (c_2,d_2) ) \coloneqq Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c_1,c_2) \times Hom_{\mathcal{D}}( d_1, d_2 )

  • (f 2,g 2)âˆ˜(f 1,g 1)â‰”(f 2âˆ˜f 1,g 2âˆ˜g 1)(f_2, g_2) \circ (f_1, g_1) \;\coloneqq\; ( f_2 \circ f_1, g_2 \circ g_1 )

Definition

(functor)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} and ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be two categories (Def. 1). A functor from ð’ž\mathcal{C} to ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D}, to be denoted

ð’žâŸ¶Fð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \overset{F}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{D}

is

  1. a function between the classes of objects:

    F Obj:Obj ð’žâŸ¶Obj ð’Ÿ F_{Obj} \;\colon\; Obj_{\mathcal{C}} \longrightarrow Obj_{\mathcal{D}}

  2. for each pair X,YâˆˆObj ð’žX,Y \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}} of objects a function

    F X,Y:Hom ð’ž(X,Y)âŸ¶Hom ð’Ÿ(F Obj(X),F Obj(Y)) F_{X,Y} \;\colon\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y) \longrightarrow Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(F_{Obj}(X), F_{Obj}(Y))

such that

  1. For each object XâˆˆObj ð’žX \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}} the identity morphism is respected:

    F X,X(id X)=id F Obj(X); F_{X,X}(id_X) \;=\; id_{F_{Obj}(X)} \,;

  2. for each triple X 1,X 2,X 3âˆˆObj ð’žX_1, X_2, X_3 \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}} of objects, composition is respected: given

    X 1âŸ¶fX 2âŸ¶gX 3 X_1 \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} X_2 \overset{g}{\longrightarrow} X_3

    then

    F X 1,X 3(gâˆ˜f)=F X 2,X 3(g)âˆ˜F X 1,X 2(f). F_{X_1, X_3}(g \circ f ) \;=\; F_{X_2, X_3}(g) \circ F_{X_1,X_2}(f) \,.
Example

(categories of small categories and of small groupoids)

It is clear that functors (Def. 6) have a composition operation given componentwise by the composition of their component functions. Accordingly, this composition is unital and associative. This means that there is

  1. the category (Def. 1) Cat whose objects are small categories (Def. 3) and whose morphisms are functors (Def. 6) between these

  2. the category (Def. 1) Grpd whose objects are small groupoids (Def. 5) and whose morphisms are functors (Def. 6) between these.

Example

(hom-functor)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a category (Def. 1). Then its hom-functor

Hom ð’ž:ð’ž opÃ—ð’žâŸ¶Set Hom_{\mathcal{C}} \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow Set

is the functor (Def. 6) out of the product category (Def. 6) of ð’ž\mathcal{C} with its opposite category to the category of sets, which sends a pair X,Yâˆˆð’žX,Y \in \mathcal{C} of objects to the hom-set Hom ð’ž(X,Y)Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y) between them, and which sends a pair of morphisms, with one of them into XX and the outher out of YY, to the operation of composition with these morphisms:

Hom ð’ž:X 1 Y 1 gâ†‘ â†“ h X 2 Y 2â†¦Hom ð’ž(X 1,Y 1) â†“ fâ†¦hâˆ˜fâˆ˜g Hom ð’ž(X 2,Y 2) Hom_{\mathcal{C}} \;\;\colon\;\;\; \array{ X_1 & Y_1 \\ {}^{\mathllap{g}}\big\uparrow & \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{h}} \\ X_2 & Y_2 } \;\;\mapsto\;\; \array{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X_1, Y_1) \\ \big\downarrow^{ \mathrlap{ f \mapsto h \circ f \circ g } } \\ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X_2, Y_2) }
Definition

(monomorphism and epimorphism)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a category (Def. 1). Then a morphism Xâ†’fYX \overset{f}{\to } Y in ð’ž\mathcal{C} is called

  • a monomorphism if for every object Zâˆˆð’žZ \in \mathcal{C} the hom-functor (Example 8) out of ZZ takes ff to an injective function of hom-sets:

    Hom ð’ž(Z,f):Hom ð’ž(Z,X)â†ªAAAHom ð’ž(Z,Y); Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Z,f) \;\colon\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Z,X) \overset{\phantom{AAA}}{\hookrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Z,Y) \,;

  • an epimorphism if for every object Zâˆˆð’µZ \in \mathcal{Z} the hom-functor (Example 8) into ZZ takes ff to an injective function:

    Hom ð’ž(f,Z):Hom ð’ž(Y,Z)â†ªAAAHom ð’ž(X,Z). Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( f,Z ) \;\colon\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Y, Z) \overset{\phantom{AAA}}{\hookrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X, Z) \,.
Definition

(full, faithful and fully faithful functors)

A functor F:ð’žâ†’ð’ŸF \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{D} (Def. 6) is called

  • a full functor if all its hom-functions are surjective functions

    Hom ð’ž(X,Y)âŸ¶surjF X,YHom ð’Ÿ(F(X),F(Y)) Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y) \underoverset{surj}{F_{X,Y}}{\longrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(F(X), F(Y))

  • a faithful functor if all its hom-functions are injective functions

    Hom ð’ž(X,Y)âŸ¶injF X,YHom ð’Ÿ(F(X),F(Y)) Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y) \underoverset{inj}{F_{X,Y}}{\longrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(F(X), F(Y))

  • a fully faithful functor if all its hom-functions are bijective functions

    Hom ð’ž(X,Y)âŸ¶bijF X,YHom ð’Ÿ(F(X),F(Y)) Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,Y) \underoverset{bij}{F_{X,Y}}{\longrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(F(X), F(Y))

A fully faithful functor is also called a full subcategory-inclusion. We will denote this situation by

ð’žâ†ªAFAð’Ÿ. \mathcal{C} \overset{\phantom{A}F\phantom{A}}{\hookrightarrow} \mathcal{D} \,.
Example

(full subcategory on a sub-class of objects)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a category (Def. 1) and let SâŠ‚Obj ð’žS \subset Obj_{\mathcal{C}} be a sub-class of its class of objects. The there is a category ð’ž S\mathcal{C}_S whose class of objects is SS, and whose morphisms are precisely the morphisms of ð’ž\mathcal{C}, between these given objects:

Hom ð’ž(s 1,s 2)â‰”Hom ð’ž(s 1,s 2) Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(s_1, s_2) \;\coloneqq\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(s_1, s_2)

with identity morphisms and composition defined as in ð’ž\mathcal{C}. Then there is a fully faithful functor (Def. 8)

ð’ž S â†ªAAAA ð’ž \array{ \mathcal{C}_S &\overset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\hookrightarrow}& \mathcal{C} }

which is the evident inclsuion on objects, and the identity function on all hom-sets.

This is called the full subcategory of ð’ž\mathcal{C} on the objects in SS.

Beware that not every fully faithful functor is, in components, exactly of this form, but, assuming the axiom of choice, every fully faithful functor is so up to equivalence of categories (Def. 14).

The concept of faithful functor from Def. 8 allows to make precise the idea of concrete category from Example 2:

Example

(structured sets and faithful functors)

Let ð’®\mathcal{S} be a kind of mathematical structure and let ð’®Set\mathcal{S} Set be the category of ð’®\mathcal{S}-structured sets. Then there is the forgetful functor

ð’®SetâŸ¶Set \mathcal{S}Set \longrightarrow Set

which sends each structured set to the underlying set (â€œforgettingâ€ the structure that it carries), and which sends functions of sets to themselves. That a homomorphism of structured sets is a function between the underlying sets satisfying a special condition implies that this is a faithful functor (Def. 8).

Conversely, it makes sense to define structured sets in general to be the objects of a category ð’ž\mathcal{C} which is equipped with a faithful functor ð’žâŸ¶faithfulSet\mathcal{C} \overset{faithful}{\longrightarrow} Set to the category of sets. See at structure for more on this.

Example

(spaces seen via their algebras of functions)

In any given context of geometry, there is typically a functor which sends any space of the given kind to its algebra of functions, and which sends an map (i.e. homomorphism) between the given spaces to the algebra homomorphism given by precomposition with that map. Schematically:

{geometric spaces} âŸ¶algebra of functions {algebras} op X 1 â†¦ FunctionsOn(X 1) fâ†“ â†‘ Ï•â†¦Ï•âˆ˜f X 2 â†¦ FunctionsOn(X 2) \array{ \left\{ \text{geometric spaces} \right\} & \overset{ \text{algebra of functions} }{ \longrightarrow } & \left\{ \text{algebras} \right\}^{op} \\ \\ X_1 &\mapsto& FunctionsOn(X_1) \\ {}^{\mathllap{f}}\big\downarrow && \big\uparrow^{ \phi \mapsto \phi \circ f } \\ X_2 &\mapsto& FunctionsOn(X_2) }

Since the precomposition operation reverses the direction of morphisms, as shown, these are functors from the given category of spaces to the opposite (Example 5) of the relevant category of algebras.

In broad generality, there is a duality (â€œIsbell dualityâ€) between geometry/spaces and algebra/algebras of functions) (â€œspace and quantityâ€, Lawvere 86).

We now mention some concrete examples of this general pattern:

\,

topological spaces and C*-algebras

Consider

  1. the category Top cpt{}_{cpt} of compact topological Hausdorff spaces with continuous functions between them;

  2. the category C*Alg of unital C*-algebras over the complex numbers

from Example 2.

Then there is a functor (Def. 6)

C(âˆ’):Top cptâŸ¶C *Alg op C(-) \;\colon\; Top_{cpt} \longrightarrow C^\ast Alg^{op}

from the former to the opposite category of the latter (Example 5) which sends any compact topological space XX to its C*-algebra C(X)C(X) of continuous functions Xâ†’Ï•â„‚X \overset{\phi}{\to} \mathbb{C} with values in the complex numbers, and which sends every continuous function between compact spaces to the C*-algebra-homomorphism that is given by precomposition:

C(âˆ’):X â†¦ C(X) fâ†“ â†‘ f *:Ï•â†¦Ï•âˆ˜f Y â†¦ C(Y) C(-) \;\;\;\colon\;\;\; \array{ X &\mapsto & C(X) \\ {}^{\mathllap{ f }}\big\downarrow && \big\uparrow^{\mathrlap{ f^\ast : \phi \mapsto \phi \circ f }} \\ Y &\mapsto& C(Y) }

Part of the statement of Gelfand duality is that this is a fully faithful functor, hence exhibiting a full subcategory-inclusion (Def. 8):

Top cptâ†ªAAAC *Alg op. Top_{cpt} \overset{\phantom{AAA}}{\hookrightarrow} C^\ast Alg^{op} \,.

\,

smooth manifolds and real associative algebras

Consider

  1. the category SmthMfd of smooth manifolds with smooth functions between them;

  2. the category Alg â„{}_{\mathbb{R}} of associative algebras over the real numbers

from Example 2.

Then there is a functor (Def. 6)

C âˆž(âˆ’):SmthMfd opâŸ¶Alg â„ op C^\infty(-) \;\colon\; SmthMfd^{op} \longrightarrow Alg_{\mathbb{R}}^{op}

from the former to the opposite category of the latter (Def. 5), which sends any smooth manifold XX to its associative algebra C inft(X)C^\inft(X) of continuous functions Xâ†’Ï•â„X \overset{\phi}{\to} \mathbb{R} to the real numbers, and which sends every smooth function between smooth manifolds to the algebra homomorphism that is given by precomposition:

C âˆž(âˆ’):X â†¦ C âˆž(X) fâ†“ â†‘ f *:Ï•â†¦Ï•âˆ˜f Y â†¦ C âˆž(Y) C^\infty(-) \;\;\;\colon\;\;\; \array{ X &\mapsto & C^\infty(X) \\ {}^{\mathllap{ f }}\big\downarrow && \big\uparrow^{\mathrlap{ f^\ast : \phi \mapsto \phi \circ f }} \\ Y &\mapsto& C^\infty(Y) }

The statement of Milnor's exercise is that this this is a fully faithful functor, hence exhibiting a full subcategory-inclusion (Def. 8):

SmthMfdâ†ªAAAAAlg â„ op. SmthMfd \overset{\phantom{AAAA}}{ \hookrightarrow } Alg_{\mathbb{R}}^{op} \,.

These two statements, expressing categories of spaces as full subcategories of opposite categories of categories of algebras, are the starting point for many developments in geometry, such as algebraic geometry, supergeometry, noncommutative geometry and noncommutative topology.

\,

Since a fully faithful functor/full subcategory-embedding ð’žâ†ªð’Ÿ\mathcal{C} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{D} exhibits the objects of ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} as a consistent generalization of the objects of ð’ž\mathcal{C}, one may turn these examples around and define more general kinds of spaces as formal duals to certain algebras:

\,

infinitesimally thickened points and formal Cartesian spaces

The category of infinitesimally thickened points is, by definition, the full subcategory (Example 9) of the opposite category (Example 5) of that of commutative algebras (Example 2) over the real numbers

InfThckPoint â†ªAAAA Alg â„ op ð”» â†¦ C âˆž(ð”») â‰”â„âŠ•V \array{ InfThckPoint &\overset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\hookrightarrow}& Alg_{\mathbb{R}}^{op} \\ \mathbb{D} &\mapsto& C^\infty(\mathbb{D}) \\ && \coloneqq \mathbb{R} \oplus V }

on those with a unique maximal ideal VV which is a finite-dimensional as an â„\mathbb{R}-vector space and a nilradical: for each aâˆˆVa \in V there exists nâˆˆâ„•n \in \mathbb{N} such that a n=0a^n = 0.

The category of formal Cartesian spaces is, by definition, the full subcategory (Example 9) of the opposite category (Example 5) of that of commutative algebras (Example 2) over the real numbers

FormalCartSp â†ªAAAA Alg â„ op â„ nÃ—ð”» â†¦ C âˆž(â„ nÃ—ð”») â‰”C âˆž(â„ n)âŠ— â„(â„âŠ•V) \array{ FormalCartSp &\overset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\hookrightarrow}& Alg_{\mathbb{R}}^{op} \\ \mathbb{R}^n \times \mathbb{D} &\mapsto& C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^n \times \mathbb{D}) \\ && \coloneqq C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^n) \otimes_{\mathbb{R}}(\mathbb{R} \oplus V) }

on those which are tensor products of algebras, of an algebra of smooth functions on a Cartesian space â„ n\mathbb{R}^n, for some nâˆˆâ„¤n \in \mathbb{Z}, and the algebra of functions on an infinitesimally thickened point.

Notice that the formal Cartesian spaces â„ n|q\mathbb{R}^{n\vert q} are fully defined by this assignment.

\,

super points and super Cartesian spaces

The category of super points is by definition, the full subcategory (Example 9) of the opposite category (Example 5) of that of supercommutative algebras (Example 2) over the real numbers

SuperPoint â†ªAAAA sCAlg â„ op â„ 0|q â†¦ Î› q \array{ SuperPoint &\overset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\hookrightarrow}& sCAlg_{\mathbb{R}}^{op} \\ \mathbb{R}^{0\vert q} &\mapsto& \Lambda_q }

on the Grassmann algebras:

Î› qâ‰”â„[Î¸ 1,â‹¯,Î¸ q]/(Î¸ iÎ¸ j=âˆ’Î¸ jÎ¸ i)AAAAAqâˆˆâ„•. \Lambda_q \;\coloneqq\; \mathbb{R}[ \theta_1, \cdots, \theta_q ]/( \theta_i \theta_j = - \theta_j \theta_i ) \phantom{AAAAA} q \in \mathbb{N} \,.

More generally, the category of super Cartesian spaces is by definition, the full subcategory

SuperCartSp â†ªAAAA sCAlg â„ op â„ n|q maspto C âˆž(â„ n)âŠ— â„Î› q \array{ SuperCartSp &\overset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\hookrightarrow}& sCAlg_{\mathbb{R}}^{op} \\ \mathbb{R}^{n\vert q} &\maspto& C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^n) \otimes_{\mathbb{R}} \Lambda_q }

on the tensor product of algebras, over â„\mathbb{R} of the algebra of smooth functions on a Cartesian space, and a Grassmann algebra, as above.

Notice that the super Cartesian spaces â„ n|q\mathbb{R}^{n\vert q} are fully defined by this assignment.

\,

affine schemes and commutative algebras

The starting point of algebraic geometry is to consider affine schemes as the formal duals of finitely generated commutative algebras over some algebraically closed ground field ð•‚\mathbb{K}:

(1)Aff ð•‚â†ªAAAACAlg ð•‚. Aff_{\mathbb{K}} \overset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\hookrightarrow} CAlg_{\mathbb{K}} \,.

(The immediate identification (1) is often obscured by the definition of affine schemes as locally ringed spaces. While the latter is much more complicated, at face value, in the end it yields an equivalent category (Def. 14 below) to the simple formal dualization in (1). Already in 1973 Alexander Grothendieck had urged to abandon, as a foundational concept, the more complicated definition in favor of the simpler one (see Lawvere 03.)

\,

Natural transformations and presheaves

Given a system of (homo-)morphisms (â€œtransformationsâ€) in some category (Def. 1)

F XâŸ¶AÎ· XAG X F_X \overset{\phantom{A}\eta_X\phantom{A}}{\longrightarrow} G_X

between objects that depend on some variable XX, hence that are values of functors of XX (Def. 6), one says that this is natural, hence a natural transformation (Def. 9 below) if it is compatible with (homo-)morphisms of the variable itself.

These natural transformations are the evident homomorphisms between functors

FâŸ¶AÎ·AG, F \overset{\phantom{A}\eta\phantom{A}}{\longrightarrow} G \,,

and hence there is a category of functors between any two categories (Example 13 below).

A key class of such functor categories are those between an opposite category ð’ž op\mathcal{C}^{op} and the base category of sets, these are also called categories of presheaves (Example 14 below). It makes good sense (Remark 2 below) to think of these as categories of â€œgeneralized objects of ð’ž\mathcal{C}â€, a perspective which is made precise by the statement of the Yoneda lemma (Prop. 1 below) and the resulting Yoneda embedding (Prop. 2 below). This innocent-looking lemma is the heart that makes category theory tick.

\,

Definition

(natural transformation and natural isomorphism)

Given two categories ð’ž\mathcal{C} and ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} (Def. 1) and given two functors from ð’ž\mathcal{C} to ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} (Def. 6), then a natural transformation from FF to GG

ð’žAAâ‡“Î·AAâŸ¶GâŸ¶Fð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{G}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}} {\phantom{AA}\Downarrow \mathrlap{\eta} \phantom{AA}} \mathcal{D}

is

  • for each object XâˆˆObj ð’žX \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}} a morphism

    (2)F(X)âŸ¶Î· XG(X) F(X) \overset{ \eta_X }{\longrightarrow} G(X)

such that

  • for each morphism XâŸ¶fYX \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} Y we have a commuting square (Def. 2) of the form

    (3)Î· Yâˆ˜F(X)=G(Y)âˆ˜Î· XAAAAAAF(X) âŸ¶Î· X G(X) F(f)â†“ â†“ G(f) F(Y) âŸ¶Î· Y G(Y) \eta_Y\circ F(X) \;=\; G(Y)\circ \eta_X \phantom{AAAAAA} \array{ F(X) &\overset{\eta_X}{\longrightarrow}& G(X) \\ {}^{\mathllap{F(f)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{G(f)}} \\ F(Y) &\underset{\eta_Y}{\longrightarrow}& G(Y) }

    (sometimes called the naturality square of the natural transformation).

If all the component morphisms Î· X\eta_X are isomorphisms (Def. 4), then the natural transformation Î·\eta is called a natural isomorphism.

For

ð’žAAâ‡“Î·AAâŸ¶GâŸ¶Fð’ŸAAandAAð’žAAâ‡“ÏAAâŸ¶HâŸ¶Gð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{G}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}} {\phantom{AA}\Downarrow \mathrlap{\eta} \phantom{AA}} \mathcal{D} \phantom{AA} \text{and} \phantom{AA} \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{H}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{G}{\longrightarrow}} {\phantom{AA}\Downarrow \mathrlap{\rho} \phantom{AA}} \mathcal{D}

two natural transformations as shown, their composition is the natural transformation

ð’žAâ‡“Ïâˆ˜Î·AAAAâŸ¶HâŸ¶Fð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{H}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}} {\phantom{A}\Downarrow \mathrlap{\rho \circ \eta} \phantom{AAAA}} \mathcal{D}

whose components (2) are the compositions of the components of Î·\eta and Ï\rho:

(4)(Ïâˆ˜Î·) Xâ‰”Ï Xâˆ˜Î· XAAAAAF(X) âŸ¶Î· X G(X) âŸ¶Ï X H(X) F(f)â†“ â†“ G(f) â†“ H(f) F(Y) âŸ¶Î· Y G(Y) âŸ¶Ï Y H(Y) (\rho \circ \eta)_X \;\coloneqq\; \rho_{X} \circ \eta_X \phantom{AAAAA} \array{ F(X) &\overset{\eta_X}{\longrightarrow}& G(X) &\overset{\rho_X}{\longrightarrow}& H(X) \\ {}^{\mathllap{F(f)}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{G(f)}} && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{H(f)}} \\ F(Y) &\underset{\eta_Y}{\longrightarrow}& G(Y) &\underset{\rho_Y}{\longrightarrow}& H(Y) }
Example

(reduction of formal Cartesian spaces)

On the category FormalCartSp of formal Cartesian spaces Example 11, consider the endofunctor

FormalCartSp âŸ¶AAâ„œAA FormalCartSp â„ nÃ—ð”» â†¦ â„ n \array{ FormalCartSp &\overset{ \phantom{AA}\Re \phantom{AA} }{\longrightarrow}& FormalCartSp \\ \mathbb{R}^n \times \mathbb{D} &\mapsto& \mathbb{R}^n }

which sends each formal Cartesian space to the underlying ordinary Cartesian space, forgetting the infinitesimally thickened point-factor. Moreover, on morphisms this functor is defined via the retraction

id: â„ n âŸ¶i â„ nÃ—ð”» âŸ¶r â„ n C âˆž(â„ n) âŸµquotient projectioni * C âˆž(â„ n)âŠ— â„(RâŠ•V) âŸµfâ†¦fâŠ—1r * C âˆž(â„ n) \array{ id \colon & \mathbb{R}^n &\overset{i}{\longrightarrow}& \mathbb{R}^n \times \mathbb{D} &\overset{r}{\longrightarrow}& \mathbb{R}^n \\ & C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^n) &\underoverset{\text{quotient projection}}{i^\ast}{\longleftarrow}& C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^n) \otimes_{\mathbb{R}} (R \oplus V) &\underoverset{f \mapsto f \otimes 1}{r^\ast}{\longleftarrow}& C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^n) }

as

C âˆž(â„ nÃ—ð”») AAA C âˆž(â„ n) âŸµi * C âˆž(â„ nÃ—ð”») f *â†‘ â„œ(f *)â‰”i *âˆ˜f *âˆ˜r *â†‘ â†‘ f * C âˆž(â„ nâ€²Ã—ð”»â€²) C âˆž(â„ nâ€²) âŸ¶r * C âˆž(â„ nâ€²Ã—ð”»â€²) \array{ C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^n \times \mathbb{D}) &\phantom{AAA}&& C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^n) &\overset{i^\ast}{\longleftarrow}& C^\infty( \mathbb{R}^n \times \mathbb{D} ) \\ {}^{\mathllap{ f^\ast }}\big\uparrow && & {}^{ \mathllap{\Re( f^\ast ) \coloneqq i^\ast \circ f^\ast \circ r^\ast } }\big\uparrow && \big\uparrow^{ \mathrlap{ f^\ast } } \\ C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^{n'} \times {\mathbb{D}}') &&& C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^{n'}) &\overset{r^\ast}{\longrightarrow}& C^\infty( \mathbb{R}^{n'} \times {\mathbb{D}}') }

This is indeed functorial due to the fact that any algebra homomorphism f *f^\ast needs to send nilpotent elements to nilpoten elements, so that the following identity holds:

(5)i *âˆ˜f *=i *âˆ˜f *âˆ˜i *âˆ˜r *. i^\ast \circ f^\ast \;=\; i^\ast \circ f^\ast \circ i^\ast \circ r^\ast \,.

Then there is a natural transformation (Def. 9) from this functor to the identity functor

â„œâŸ¶AÎ· â„œAId \Re \overset{ \phantom{A} \eta^{\Re} \phantom{A} }{\longrightarrow} Id

whose components inject the underlying Cartesian space along the unit point inclusion of the infinitesimally thickened point:

â„œ(â„ nÃ—ð”»)â‰” â„ n âŸ¶AÎ· â„ nÃ—ð”» â„œ â„ nÃ—ð”» C âˆž(â„ n) âŸµi * C âˆž(â„ nÃ—ð”») i *âˆ˜f *âˆ˜r *â†‘ â†‘ f * C âˆž(â„ nâ€²) âŸµi * C âˆž(â„ nâ€²Ã—ð”»â€²) \array{ \Re\left( \mathbb{R}^n \times \mathbb{D} \right) \coloneqq & \mathbb{R}^n &\overset{ \phantom{A} \eta^\Re_{\mathbb{R}^n \times \mathbb{D}} }{\longrightarrow}& \mathbb{R}^n \times \mathbb{D} \\ & C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^n) &\overset{i^\ast}{\longleftarrow}& C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^n \times \mathbb{D}) \\ & {}^{ \mathllap{ i^\ast \circ f^\ast \circ r^\ast } }\big\uparrow && \big\uparrow^{\mathrlap{ f^\ast }} \\ & C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^{n'}) &\overset{i^\ast}{\longleftarrow}& C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^{n'} \times \mathbb{D}') }

The commutativity of this naturality square commutes is again the identity (5).

Example

(functor category)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} and ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be categories (Def. 1). Then the category of functors between them, to be denoted [ð’ž,ð’Ÿ][\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}], is the category whose objects are the functors ð’žâ†’Fð’Ÿ\mathcal{C} \overset{F}{\to} \mathcal{D} (Def. 6) and whose morphisms are the natural transformations Fâ‡’Î·GF \overset{\eta}{\Rightarrow} G between functors (Def. 9) and whose composition operation is the composition of natural transformations (4).

Example

(category of presheaves)

Given a category ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Def. 1), a functor (Def. 6) of the form

F:ð’ž opâŸ¶Set, F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \longrightarrow Set \,,

hence out of the opposite category of ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Def. 5), into the category of sets (Example 1) is also called a presheaf (for reasons discussed below) on ð’ž\mathcal{C} or over ð’ž\mathcal{C}.

The corresponding functor category (Example 13)

PSh(ð’ž)â‰”[ð’ž op,Set] PSh(\mathcal{C}) \;\coloneqq\; [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set]

is hence called the category of presheaves over ð’ž\mathcal{C}.

Example

(representable presheaves)

Given a category ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Def. 1), the hom-functor (Example 8) gives the following functor (Def. 6) from ð’ž\mathcal{C} to its category of presheaves (Def. 14):

(6)y : ð’ž âŸ¶ [ð’ž op,Set] c 1 âŸ¶g c 2 X â†¦ Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,X) AA:AA Hom ð’ž(c 1,X) âŸµHom ð’ž(g,X) Hom ð’ž(c 2,X) fâ†“ â†“ Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,f) â†“ Hom ð’ž(c 2,f) â†“ Hom ð’ž(c 1,f) Y â†¦ Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,Y) AA:AA Hom ð’ž(c 1,Y) âŸµHom ð’ž(g,Y) Hom ð’ž(c 2,Y) \array{ y & \colon & \mathcal{C} &\longrightarrow& [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] \\ \\ && && && c_1 &\overset{g}{\longrightarrow}& c_2 \\ && X &\mapsto& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,X) &\phantom{AA}\colon\phantom{AA}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c_1,X) &\overset{Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( g, X ) }{\longleftarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c_2, X) \\ && {}^{\mathllap{ f }}\big\downarrow && \big\downarrow^{ \mathrlap{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,f) } } && \big\downarrow^{ \mathrlap{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( c_2, f ) } } && \big\downarrow^{ \mathrlap{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c_1,f) } } \\ && Y &\mapsto& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,Y) &\phantom{AA}\colon\phantom{AA}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c_1,Y) &\overset{Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( g, Y ) }{\longleftarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c_2, Y) }

The presheaves y(X)â‰”Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,X)y(X) \coloneqq Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,X) in the image of this functor are called the representable presheaves and XâˆˆObj ð’žX \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}} is called their representing object.

The functor (6) is also called the Yoneda embedding, due to Prop. 2 below.

Remark

(presheaves as generalized spaces)

If a given category ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Def. 1) is thought of as a category of spaces of sorts, as those in Example 11, then it will be most useful to think of the corresponding category of presheaves [ð’ž op,Set][\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] (Def. 14) as a category of generalized spaces probe-able by the test spaces in ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Lawvere 86, p. 17).

Namely, imagine a generalized space X\mathbf{X} which is at least probe-able by spaces in ð’ž\mathcal{C}. This should mean that for each object câˆˆð’žc \in \mathcal{C} there is some set of geometric maps â€œcâ†’Xc \to \mathbf{X}â€. Here the quotation marks are to warn us that, at this point, X\mathbf{X} is not defined yet; and even if it were, it is not expected to be an object of ð’ž\mathcal{C}, so that, at this point, an actual morphism from cc to X\mathbf{X} is not definable. But we may anyway consider some abstract set

(7)X(c)"=Hom(c,X)" \mathbf{X}(c) \; \text{"=} Hom(c,\mathbf{X})"

whose elements we do want to think of maps (homomorphisms of spaces) from cc to X\mathbf{X}.

That this is indeed consistent, in that we may actually remove the quotation remarks on the right of (7), is the statement of the Yoneda lemma, which we discuss as Prop. 1 below.

A minimum consistency condition for this to make sense (we will consider further conditions later on when we discuss sheaves) is that we may consistently pre-compose the would-be maps from cc to X\mathbf{X} with actual morphisms dâ†’fcd \overset{f}{\to} c in ð’ž\mathcal{C}. This means that for every such morphism there should be a function between these sets of would-be maps

c X(d) fâ†“ â†‘ X(f)"=(âˆ’)âˆ˜f" d X(c) \array{ c && \mathbf{X}(d) \\ {}^{\mathllap{ f }}\big\downarrow && \big\uparrow{}^{\mathrlap{ \mathbf{X}(f) \, \text{"=}(-)\circ f"}} \\ d && \mathbf{X}(c) }

which respects composition and identity morphisms. But in summary, this says that what we have defined thereby is actually a presheaf on ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Def. 14), namely a functor

X:ð’ž opâŸ¶Set. \mathbf{X} \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \longrightarrow Set \,.

For consistency of regarding this presheaf as a presheaf of sets of plots of a generalized space, it ought to be true that every â€œordinary spaceâ€, hence every object Xâˆˆð’žX \in \mathcal{C}, is also an example of a â€œgeneralized space probe-able byâ€ object of ð’ž\mathcal{C}, since, after all, these are the spaces which may manifestly be probed by objects câˆˆð’žc \in \mathcal{C}, in that morphisms câ†’Xc \to X are already defined.

Hence the incarnation of Xâˆˆð’žX \in \mathcal{C} as a generalized space probe-able by objects of ð’ž\mathcal{C} should be the presheaf Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,X)Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,X), hence the presheaf represented by XX (Example 15), via the Yoneda functor (6).

At this point, however, a serious consistency condition arises: The â€œordinary spacesâ€ now exist as objects of two different categories: on the one hand there is the original Xâˆˆð’žX \in \mathcal{C}, on the other hand there is its Yoneda image y(X)âˆˆ[ð’ž op,Set]y(X) \in [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] in the category of generalized spaces. Hence we need to know that these two perspectives are compatible, notably that maps Xâ†’YX \to Y between ordinary spaces are the same whether viewed in ð’ž\mathcal{C} or in the more general context of [ð’ž op,Set][\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set].

That this, too, holds true, is the statement of the Yoneda embedding, which we discuss as Prop. 2 below.

Eventually one will want to impose one more consistency condition, namely that plots are determined by their local behaviour. This is the sheaf condition (Def. 36 below) and is what leads over from category theory to topos theory below.

Proposition

(Yoneda lemma)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a category (Def. 1), Xâˆˆð’žX \in \mathcal{C} any object, and Yâˆˆ[ð’ž op,Set]\mathbf{Y} \in [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] a presheaf over ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Def. 14).

Then there is a bijection

Hom [ð’ž op,Set](y(X),(Y)) âŸ¶â‰ƒ Y(X) Î· â†¦ Î· X(id X) \array{ Hom_{[\mathcal{C}^{op},Set]}( y(X), \mathbf(Y) ) &\overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}& \mathbf{Y}(X) \\ \eta &\mapsto& \eta_X(id_X) }

between the hom-set of the category of presheaves from the presheaf represented by XX (6) to Y\mathbf{Y}, and the set which is assigned by Y\mathbf{Y} to XX.

Proof

By Example 13, an element in the set on the left is a natural transformation (Def. 9) of the form

ð’ž opAAâ‡“Î·AAâŸ¶YâŸ¶y(X)Set \mathcal{C}^{op} \underoverset {\underset{\mathbf{Y}}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{y(X)}{\longrightarrow}} {\phantom{AA} \Downarrow \mathrlap{\eta} \phantom{AA}} Set

hence given by component functions (2)

Hom ð’ž(c,X)âŸ¶Î· cY(X) Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c,X) \overset{\eta_c}{\longrightarrow} \mathbf{Y}(X)

for each câˆˆð’žc \in \mathcal{C}. In particular there is the component at c=Xc = X

Hom ð’ž(X,X) âŸ¶Î· X Y(X) id X â†¦ Î· X(id X) \array{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,X) &\overset{\eta_X}{\longrightarrow}& \mathbf{Y}(X) \\ id_X &\mapsto& \eta_X(id_X) }

and the identity morphism id Xid_X on XX is a canonical element in the set on the left. The statement to be proven is hence equivalently that for every element in Y(X)\mathbf{Y}(X) there is precisely one Î·\eta such that this element equals Î· X(id X)\eta_X(id_X).

Now the condition to be satisfied by Î·\eta is that it makes its naturality squares (3) commute (Def. 2). This includes those of the form

id Xâˆˆ Hom ð’ž(X,X) âŸ¶Î· X Y(X) Hom ð’ž(f,X)â†“ â†“ Y(f) Hom ð’ž(Y,X) âŸ¶Î· Y Y(Y)AAAA{id X} âŸ¶ {Î· X(id X)} â†“ â†“ {f} âŸ¶ {Î· Y(F)=Y(f)(Î· X(id X))} \array{ id_X \in & Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X,X) &\overset{\eta_X}{\longrightarrow}& \mathbf{Y}(X) \\ & {}^{\mathllap{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(f,X) }} \big\downarrow && \big\downarrow{}^{\mathrlap{\mathbf{Y}(f)}} \\ & Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Y,X) &\underset{\eta_Y}{\longrightarrow}& \mathbf{Y}(Y) } \phantom{AAAA} \array{ \{id_X\} &\longrightarrow& \{\eta_X(id_X)\} \\ \big\downarrow && \big\downarrow \\ \{f\} &\longrightarrow& \big\{ \eta_Y(F) = \mathbf{Y}(f)( \eta_X(id_X) ) \big\} }

for any morphism

(YâŸ¶fX)âˆˆHom ð’ž(Y,X). (Y \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} X) \;\in\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Y,X) \,.

As the diagram chase of elements on the right shows, this commutativity (Def. 2) fixes Î· Y(f)\eta_Y(f) for all Yâˆˆð’žY \in \mathcal{C} and all fâˆˆHom ð’ž(Y,X)f \in Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Y,X) uniquely in terms of the element Î· X(id X)\eta_{X}(id_X).

It remains only to see that there is no condition on the element Î· X(id X)\eta_X(id_X), hence that with Î· Y(f)\eta_Y(f) defined this way, the commutativity of all the remaining naturality squares is implies: The general naturality square for a morphism Y 2âŸ¶gY 1Y_2 \overset{g}{\longrightarrow} Y_1 is of the form

Hom ð’ž(Y 1,X) âŸ¶Î· Y 1 Y(Y 1) Hom ð’ž(g,X)â†“ â†“ Y(g) Hom ð’ž(Y 2,X) âŸ¶Î· Y 2 Y(Y 2)AAAA{f 1} âŸ¶ {Y(f 1)(Î· X(id X))} â†“ â†“ {f 2=f 1âˆ˜g} âŸ¶ {Y(f 2)(Î· X(id X))=Y(g)âˆ˜Y(f 1)(Î· X(id X))} \array{ & Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Y_1,X) &\overset{\eta_{Y_1}}{\longrightarrow}& \mathbf{Y}(Y_1) \\ & {}^{\mathllap{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(g,X) }} \big\downarrow && \big\downarrow{}^{\mathrlap{\mathbf{Y}(g)}} \\ & Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Y_2,X) &\underset{\eta_{Y_2}}{\longrightarrow}& \mathbf{Y}(Y_2) } \phantom{AAAA} \array{ \{f_1\} &\longrightarrow& \{ \mathbf{Y}(f_1)( \eta_X(id_X) ) \} \\ \big\downarrow && \big\downarrow \\ \{f_2 = f_1\circ g\} &\longrightarrow& \{\mathbf{Y}(f_2)( \eta_X(id_X) ) = \mathbf{Y}(g) \circ \mathbf{Y}(f_1) ( \eta_X(id_X) ) \} }

As shown on the right, the commutativity of this diagram now follows from the functoriality Y(f 2)=Y(f 1âˆ˜g)\mathbf{Y}(f_2) = \mathbf{Y}(f_1 \circ g) of the presheaf Y\mathbf{Y}.

As a direct corollary, we obtain the statement of the Yoneda embedding:

Proposition

(Yoneda embedding)

The assignment (6) of represented presheaves (Example 15) is a fully faithful functor (Def. 8), hence exhibits a full subcategory inclusion

y:ð’ž â†ªAAAA [ð’ž op,Set] X â†¦ Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,X) y \;\;\colon\;\; \array{ \mathcal{C} &\overset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\hookrightarrow}& [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] \\ X &\mapsto& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,X) }

of the given category ð’ž\mathcal{C} into its category of presheaves.

Proof

We need to show that for all X 1,X 2âˆˆObj ð’žX_1, X_2 \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}} the function

(8)Hom ð’ž(X 1,X 2) âŸ¶ Hom [ð’ž op,Set](Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,X 1),Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,X 2)) f â†¦ Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,f) \array{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X_1, X_2) &\overset{ }{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{[\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set]} \big( Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,X_1) \;,\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,X_2) \big) \\ f &\mapsto& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,f) }

is a bijection. But the Yoneda lemma (Prop. 1) states a bijection the other way around

Hom [ð’ž op,Set](Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,X 1),Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,X 2)) âŸ¶â‰ƒ Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,X 2)(X 1) = Hom ð’ž(X 1,X 2) Î· â†¦ Î· X 1(id X 1) Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,f) â†¦ Hom ð’ž(X 1,f)(id X 1)=f \array{ Hom_{[\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set]} \big( Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,X_1) \;,\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,X_2) \big) &\overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,X_2)(X_1) &=& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X_1, X_2) \\ \eta && \mapsto && \eta_{X_1}( id_{X_1} ) \\ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,f) && \mapsto && Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X_1,f)(id_{X_1}) = f }

and hence it is sufficient to see that this is a left inverse to (8). This follows by inspection, as shown in the third line above.

\,

Adjunctions

We discuss four equivalent definitions of adjunctions:

  1. via hom-isomorphism (Def. 10 below);

  2. via adjunction unit and -counit satisfying triangle identities (Prop. 4);

  3. via representing objects (Prop. 5);

  4. via universal morphisms (Prop. 6 below).

Then we discuss some key properties:

  1. uniqueness of adjoints (Prop. 7 below),

  2. epi/mono/iso-characterization of adjunction (co-)units (Prop. 8 below).

\,

Definition

(adjoint functors)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} and ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be two categories (Def. 1), and let

ð’ŸâŸ¶RâŸµLð’ž \mathcal{D} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}}{\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}}{} \mathcal{C}

be a pair of functors between them (Def. 6), as shown. Then this is called a pair of adjoint functors (or an adjoint pair of functors) with LL left adjoint and RR right adjoint, denoted

ð’ŸâŠ¥âŸ¶RâŸµLð’ž \mathcal{D} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}}{\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}}{\bot} \mathcal{C}

if there exists a natural isomorphism (Def. 9) between the hom-functors (Example 8) of the following form:

(9)Hom ð’Ÿ(L(âˆ’),âˆ’)â‰ƒHom ð’ž(âˆ’,R(âˆ’)). Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(-),-) \;\simeq\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,R(-)) \,.

This means that for all objects câˆˆð’žc \in \mathcal{C} and dâˆˆð’Ÿd \in \mathcal{D} there is a bijection of hom-sets

Hom ð’Ÿ(L(c),d) âŸ¶â‰ƒ Hom ð’ž(c,R(d)) (L(c)â†’fd) â†¦ (câ†’fËœR(d)) \array{ Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(c),d) &\overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c,R(d)) \\ ( L(c) \overset{f}{\to} d ) &\mapsto& (c \overset{\widetilde f}{\to} R(d)) }

which is natural in cc and dd. This isomorphism is called the adjunction hom-isomorphism and the image fËœ\widetilde f of amorphism ff under this bijections is called the adjunct of ff. Conversely, ff is called the adjunct of fËœ\widetilde f.

Naturality here means that for every morphism g:c 2â†’c 1g \colon c_2 \to c_1 in ð’ž\mathcal{C} and for every morphisms h:d 1â†’d 2h\colon d_1\to d_2 in ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D}, the resulting square

(10)Hom ð’Ÿ(L(c 1),d 1) âŸ¶â‰ƒ(âˆ’)Ëœ Hom ð’ž(c 1,R(d 1)) Hom ð’Ÿ(L(g),h)â†“ â†“ Hom ð’ž(g,R(h)) Hom ð’Ÿ(L(c 2),d 2) âŸ¶â‰ƒ(âˆ’)Ëœ Hom ð’ž(c 2,R(d 2)) \array{ Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(c_1), d_1) &\underoverset{\simeq}{\widetilde{(-)}}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c_1, R(d_1)) \\ {}^{\mathllap{Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(g), h)}}\big\downarrow && \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(g, R(h))}} \\ Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(c_2),d_2) &\underoverset{\simeq}{\widetilde{(-)}}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c_2,R(d_2)) }

commutes (Def. 2), where the vertical morphisms are given by the hom-functor (Example 8).

Explicitly, this commutativity, in turn, means that for every morphism f:L(c 1)â†’d 1f \;\colon\; L(c_1) \to d_1 with adjunct fËœ:c 1â†’R(d 1)\widetilde f \;\colon\; c_1 \to R(d_1), the adjunct of the composition is

L(c 1) âŸ¶f d 1 L(g)â†‘ â†“ h L(c 2) d 2Ëœ=c 1 âŸ¶fËœ R(d 1) gâ†‘ â†“ R(h) c 2 R(d 2) \widetilde{ \array{ L(c_1) &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& d_1 \\ {}^{\mathllap{L(g)}}\big\uparrow && \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{h}} \\ L(c_2) && d_2 } } \;\;\;=\;\;\; \array{ c_1 &\overset{\widetilde f}{\longrightarrow}& R(d_1) \\ {}^{\mathllap{g}}\big\uparrow && \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{R(h)}} \\ c_2 && R(d_2) }
Definition

(adjunction unit and counit)

Given a pair of adjoint functors

ð’žâŠ¥âŸ¶RâŸµLð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}}{\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}}{\bot} \mathcal{D}

according to Def. 10, one says that

  1. for any câˆˆð’žc \in \mathcal{C} the adjunct of the identity morphism on L(c)L(c) is the unit morphism of the adjunction at that object, denoted

    Î· câ‰”id L(c)Ëœ:câŸ¶R(L(c)) \eta_c \coloneqq \widetilde{id_{L(c)}} \;\colon\; c \longrightarrow R(L(c))

  2. for any dâˆˆð’Ÿd \in \mathcal{D} the adjunct of the identity morphism on R(d)R(d) is the counit morphism of the adjunction at that object, denoted

    Ïµ d:L(R(d))âŸ¶d \epsilon_d \;\colon\; L(R(d)) \longrightarrow d
Proposition

(general adjuncts in terms of unit/counit)

Consider a pair of adjoint functors

ð’žâŠ¥âŸ¶RâŸµLð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}}{\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}}{\bot} \mathcal{D}

according to Def. 10, with adjunction units Î· c\eta_c and adjunction counits Ïµ d\epsilon_d according to Def. 3.

Then

  1. The adjunct fËœ\widetilde f of any morphism L(c)â†’fdL(c) \overset{f}{\to} d is obtained from RR and Î· c\eta_c as the composite

    (11)fËœ:câŸ¶Î· cR(L(c))âŸ¶R(f)R(d) \widetilde f \;\colon\; c \overset{\eta_c}{\longrightarrow} R(L(c)) \overset{R(f)}{\longrightarrow} R(d)

    Conversely, the adjunct ff of any morphism câŸ¶fËœR(d)c \overset{\widetilde f}{\longrightarrow} R(d) is obtained from LL and Ïµ d\epsilon_d as

    (12)f:L(c)âŸ¶L(fËœ)R(L(d))âŸ¶Ïµ dd f \;\colon\; L(c) \overset{L(\widetilde f)}{\longrightarrow} R(L(d)) \overset{\epsilon_d}{\longrightarrow} d

  2. The adjunction units Î· c\eta_c and adjunction counits Ïµ d\epsilon_d are components of natural transformations of the form

    Î·:Id ð’žâ‡’Râˆ˜L \eta \;\colon\; Id_{\mathcal{C}} \Rightarrow R \circ L

    and

    Ïµ:Lâˆ˜Râ‡’Id ð’Ÿ \epsilon \;\colon\; L \circ R \Rightarrow Id_{\mathcal{D}}

  3. The adjunction unit and adjunction counit satisfy the triangle identities, saying that

    (13)id L(c):L(c)âŸ¶L(Î· c)L(R(L(c)))âŸ¶Ïµ L(c)L(c) id_{L(c)} \;\colon\; L(c) \overset{L(\eta_c)}{\longrightarrow} L(R(L(c))) \overset{\epsilon_{L(c)}}{\longrightarrow} L(c)

    and

    id R(d):R(d)âŸ¶Î· R(d)R(L(R(d)))âŸ¶R(Ïµ d)R(d) id_{R(d)} \;\colon\; R(d) \overset{\eta_{R(d)}}{\longrightarrow} R(L(R(d))) \overset{R(\epsilon_d)}{\longrightarrow} R(d)
Proof

For the first statement, consider the naturality square (10) in the form

id L(c)âˆˆ Hom ð’Ÿ(L(c),L(c)) âŸ¶â‰ƒ(âˆ’)Ëœ Hom ð’ž(c,R(L(c))) Hom ð’Ÿ(L(id),f)â†“ â†“ Hom ð’ž(id,R(f)) Hom ð’Ÿ(L(c),d) âŸ¶â‰ƒ(âˆ’)Ëœ Hom ð’ž(c,R(d)) \array{ id_{L(c)} \in & Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(c), L(c)) &\underoverset{\simeq}{\widetilde{(-)}}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c, R(L(c))) \\ & {}^{\mathllap{Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(id), f)}}\big\downarrow && \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(id, R(f))}} \\ & Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(c), d) &\underoverset{\simeq}{\widetilde{(-)}}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( c, R(d) ) }

and consider the element id L(c 1)id_{L(c_1)} in the top left entry. Its image under going down and then right in the diagram is fËœ\widetilde f, by Def. 10. On the other hand, its image under going right and then down is R(f)âˆ˜Î· c R(f)\circ \eta_{c}, by Def. 11. Commutativity of the diagram means that these two morphisms agree, which is the statement to be shown, for the adjunct of ff.

The converse formula follows analogously.

The third statement follows directly from this by applying these formulas for the adjuncts twice and using that the result must be the original morphism:

id L(c) =id L(c)ËœËœ =câ†’Î· cR(L(c))Ëœ =L(c)âŸ¶L(Î· c)L(R(L(c)))âŸ¶Ïµ L(c)L(c) \begin{aligned} id_{L(c)} & = \widetilde \widetilde { id_{L(c)} } \\ & = \widetilde{ c \overset{\eta_c}{\to} R(L(c)) } \\ & = L(c) \overset{L(\eta_c)}{\longrightarrow} L(R(L(c))) \overset{\epsilon_{L(c)}}{\longrightarrow} L(c) \end{aligned}

For the second statement, we have to show that for every moprhism f:c 1â†’c 2f \colon c_1 \to c_2 the following square commutes:

c 1 âŸ¶f c 2 Î· c 1â†“ â†“ Î· c 2 R(L(c 1)) âŸ¶R(L(f)) R(L(c 2)) \array{ c_1 &\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}& c_2 \\ {}^{\mathllap{\eta_{c_1}}}\big\downarrow && \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{\eta_{c_2}}} \\ R(L(c_1)) &\underset{ R(L(f)) }{\longrightarrow}& R(L(c_2)) }

To see this, consider the naturality square (10) in the form

id L(c 2)âˆˆ Hom ð’Ÿ(L(c 2),L(c 2)) âŸ¶â‰ƒ(âˆ’)Ëœ Hom ð’ž(c 2,R(L(c 2))) Hom ð’Ÿ(L(f),id L(c 2))â†“ â†“ Hom ð’ž(f,R(id L(c 2))) Hom ð’Ÿ(L(c 1),L(c 2)) âŸ¶â‰ƒ(âˆ’)Ëœ Hom ð’ž(c 1,R(L(c 1))) \array{ id_{L(c_2)} \in & Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(c_2), L(c_2)) &\underoverset{\simeq}{\widetilde{(-)}}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c_2, R(L(c_2))) \\ & {}^{\mathllap{Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(f),id_{L(c_2)})}}\big\downarrow && \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(f, R(id_{L(c_2)}))}} \\ & Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(c_1),L(c_2)) &\underoverset{\simeq}{\widetilde{(-)}}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c_1,R(L(c_1))) }

The image of the element id L(c 2)id_{L(c_2)} in the top left along the right and down is fâˆ˜Î· c 2 f \circ \eta_{c_2}, by Def. 11, while its image down and then to the right is L(f)Ëœ=R(L(f))âˆ˜Î· c 1\widetilde {L(f)} = R(L(f)) \circ \eta_{c_1}, by the previous statement. Commutativity of the diagram means that these two morphisms agree, which is the statement to be shown.

The argument for the naturality of Ïµ\epsilon is directly analogous.

Proposition

(adjoint functors equivalent to adjunction in Cat)

Two functors

ð’ŸâŸ¶RâŸµLð’ž \mathcal{D} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}}{\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}}{} \mathcal{C}

are an adjoint pair in the sense that there is a natural isomorphism (9) according to Def. 10, precisely if they participate in an adjunction in the 2-category Cat, meaning that

  1. there exist natural transformations

    Î·:Id ð’žâ‡’Râˆ˜L \eta \;\colon\; Id_{\mathcal{C}} \Rightarrow R \circ L

    and

    Ïµ:Lâˆ˜Râ‡’Id ð’Ÿ \epsilon \;\colon\; L \circ R \Rightarrow Id_{\mathcal{D}}

  2. which satisfy the triangle identities

    id L(c):L(c)âŸ¶L(Î· c)L(R(L(c)))âŸ¶Ïµ L(c)L(c) id_{L(c)} \;\colon\; L(c) \overset{L(\eta_c)}{\longrightarrow} L(R(L(c))) \overset{\epsilon_{L(c)}}{\longrightarrow} L(c)

    and

    id R(d):R(d)âŸ¶Î· R(d)R(L(R(d)))âŸ¶R(Ïµ d)R(d) id_{R(d)} \;\colon\; R(d) \overset{\eta_{R(d)}}{\longrightarrow} R(L(R(d))) \overset{R(\epsilon_d)}{\longrightarrow} R(d)
Proof

That a hom-isomorphism (9) implies units/counits satisfying the triangle identities is the statement of the second two items of Prop. 3.

Hence it remains to show the converse. But the argument is along the same lines as the proof of Prop. 3: We now define forming of adjuncts by the formula (11). That the resulting assignment fâ†¦fËœf \mapsto \widetilde f is an isomorphism follows from the computation

fËœËœ =câ†’Î· cR(L(c))â†’R(f)R(d)Ëœ =L(c)â†’L(Î· c)L(R(L(c)))â†’L(R(f))L(R(d))â†’Ïµ dd =L(c)â†’L(Î· c)L(R(L(c)))â†’Ïµ L(c)L(c)âŸ¶fd =L(c)âŸ¶fd \begin{aligned} \widetilde {\widetilde f} & = \widetilde{ c \overset{\eta_c}{\to} R(L(c)) \overset{R(f)}{\to} R(d) } \\ & = L(c) \overset{L(\eta_c)}{\to} L(R(L(c))) \overset{L(R(f))}{\to} L(R(d)) \overset{\epsilon_d}{\to} d \\ & = L(c) \overset{L(\eta_c)}{\to} L(R(L(c))) \overset{ \epsilon_{L(c)} }{\to} L(c) \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} d \\ & = L(c) \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} d \end{aligned}

where, after expanding out the definition, we used naturality of Ïµ\epsilon and then the triangle identity.

Finally, that this construction satisfies the naturality condition (10) follows from the functoriality of the functors involved, and the naturality of the unit/counit:

c 2 âŸ¶Î· c 2 R(L(c 2)) gâ†“ â†“ R(L(g)) â†˜ R(L(g)âˆ˜f) c 1 âŸ¶Î· c 1 R(L(c 1)) âŸ¶R(f) R(d 1) R(hâˆ˜f)â†˜ â†“ R(h) R(d 2) \array{ c_2 &\overset{ \eta_{c_2} }{\longrightarrow}& R(L(c_2)) \\ {}^{\mathllap{g}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{R(L(g))}} & \searrow^{\mathrlap{ R( L(g) \circ f ) }} \\ c_1 &\overset{\eta_{c_1}}{\longrightarrow}& R(L(c_1)) &\overset{R(f)}{\longrightarrow}& R(d_1) \\ && & {}_{R( h\circ f)}\searrow & \downarrow^{\mathrlap{ R(h) }} \\ && && R(d_2) }

The condition (9) on adjoint functors LâŠ£RL \dashv R in Def. 10 implies in particular that for every object dâˆˆð’Ÿd \in \mathcal{D} the functor Hom ð’Ÿ(L(âˆ’),d)Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(-),d) is a representable functor with representing object R(d)R(d). The following Prop. 5 observes that the existence of such representing objects for all dd is, in fact, already sufficient to imply that there is a right adjoint functor.

This equivalent perspective on adjoint functors makes manifest that adjoint functors are, if they exist, unique up to natural isomorphism, this is Prop. 7 below.

Proposition

(adjoint functor from objectwise representing objects)

A functor L:ð’žâŸ¶ð’ŸL \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D} has a right adjoint R:ð’Ÿâ†’ð’žR \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{C}, according to Def. 10, already if for all objects dâˆˆð’Ÿd \in \mathcal{D} there is an object R(d)âˆˆð’žR(d) \in \mathcal{C} such that there is a natural isomorphism

Hom ð’Ÿ(L(âˆ’),d)âŸ¶â‰ƒ(âˆ’)ËœHom ð’ž(âˆ’,R(d)), Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(-),d) \underoverset{\simeq}{\widetilde{(-)}}{\longrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,R(d)) \,,

hence for each object câˆˆð’žc \in \mathcal{C} a bijection

Hom ð’Ÿ(L(c),d)âŸ¶â‰ƒ(âˆ’)ËœHom ð’ž(c,R(d)) Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(c),d) \underoverset{\simeq}{\widetilde{(-)}}{\longrightarrow} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c,R(d))

such that for each morphism g:c 2â†’c 1g \;\colon\; c_2 \to c_1, the following diagram commutes

(14)Hom ð’Ÿ(L(c 1),d) âŸ¶â‰ƒ(âˆ’)Ëœ Hom ð’ž(c 1,R(d)) Hom ð’ž(L(g),id d)â†“ â†“ Hom ð’ž(f,id R(d)) Hom ð’Ÿ(L(c 2),d) âŸ¶â‰ƒ(âˆ’)Ëœ Hom ð’ž(c 2,R(d)) \array{ Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(c_1),d) &\underoverset{\simeq}{\widetilde{(-)}}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c_1,R(d)) \\ {}^{\mathllap{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(L(g),id_d) }} \big\downarrow && \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( f, id_{R(d)} ) }} \\ Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(c_2),d) &\underoverset{\simeq}{\widetilde{(-)}}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c_2,R(d)) }

(This is as in (10), except that only naturality in the first variable is required.)

In this case there is a unique way to extend RR from a function on objects to a function on morphisms such as to make it a functor R:ð’Ÿâ†’ð’žR \colon \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{C} which is right adjoint to LL. , and hence the statement is that with this, naturality in the second variable is already implied.

Proof

Notice that

  1. in the language of presheaves (Example 14) the assumption is that for each dâˆˆð’Ÿd \in \mathcal{D} the presheaf

    Hom ð’Ÿ(L(âˆ’),d)âˆˆ[ð’Ÿ op,Set] Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(-),d) \;\in\; [\mathcal{D}^{op}, Set]

    is represented (6) by the object R(d)R(d), and naturally so.

  2. In terms of the Yoneda embedding (Prop. 2)

    y:ð’Ÿâ†ª[ð’Ÿ op,Set] y \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \hookrightarrow [\mathcal{D}^{op}, Set]

    we have

    (15)Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,R(d))=y(R(d)) Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,R(d)) = y(R(d))

The condition (10) says equivalently that RR has to be such that for all morphisms h:d 1â†’d 2h \;\colon\; d_1 \to d_2 the following diagram in the category of presheaves [ð’ž op,Set][\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] commutes

Hom ð’Ÿ(L(âˆ’),d 1) âŸ¶â‰ƒ(âˆ’)Ëœ Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,R(d 1)) Hom ð’ž(L(âˆ’),h)â†“ â†“ Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,R(h)) Hom ð’Ÿ(L(âˆ’),d 2) âŸ¶â‰ƒ(âˆ’)Ëœ Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,R(d 2)) \array{ Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(-),d_1) &\underoverset{\simeq}{\widetilde{(-)}}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,R(d_1)) \\ {}^{\mathllap{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( L(-) , h ) }} \big\downarrow && \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( -, R(h) ) }} \\ Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(-),d_2) &\underoverset{\simeq}{\widetilde{(-)}}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-, R(d_2)) }

This manifestly has a unique solution

y(R(h))=Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,R(h)) y(R(h)) \;=\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,R(h))

for every morphism h:d 1â†’d 2h \colon d_1 \to d_2 under y(R(âˆ’))y(R(-)) (15). But the Yoneda embedding yy is a fully faithful functor (Prop. 2), which means that thereby also R(h)R(h) is uniquely fixed.

We consider one more equivalent characterization of adjunctions:

Definition

(universal morphism)

Let ð’ž,ð’Ÿ\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D} be two categories (Def. 1) and let R:ð’Ÿâ†’ð’žR \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{C} be a functor (Def. 6)

Then for câˆˆð’žc\in \mathcal{C} an object, a universal morphism from cc to RR is

  1. an object L(c)âˆˆð’ŸL(c)\in \mathcal{D},

  2. a morphism Î· c:câ†’R(L(c))\eta_c \;\colon\; c \to R(L(c)), to be called the unit,

such that for any dâˆˆð’Ÿd\in \mathcal{D}, any morphism f:câ†’R(d)f \colon c\to R(d) factors through this unit Î· c\eta_c as

(16)f=Î· câˆ˜R(fËœ)AAAA c Î· câ†™ â†˜ f R(L(c)) âŸ¶R(fËœ) R(d) L(c) âŸ¶fËœ d f \;=\; \eta_c \circ R(\widetilde f) \phantom{AAAA} \array{ && c \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\eta_c}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ R(L(c)) &&\underset{R (\widetilde f)}{\longrightarrow}&& R(d) \\ \\ L(c) &&\underset{ \widetilde f}{\longrightarrow}&& d }

for a unique morphism fËœ:L(c)âŸ¶d\widetilde f \;\colon\; L(c) \longrightarrow d, to be called the adjunct of ff.

Proposition

(collection of universal morphisms equivalent to adjoint functor)

Let R:ð’Ÿâ†’ð’žR \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{C} be a functor (Def. 6). Then the following are equivalent:

  1. RR has a left adjoint functor L:ð’žâ†’ð’ŸL \colon \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{D} according to Def. 10,

  2. For every object câˆˆð’žc \in \mathcal{C} there is a universal morphism câŸ¶Î· cR(L(c))c \overset{\eta_c}{\longrightarrow} R(L(c)), according to Def. 12.

Proof

In one direction, assume a left adjoint LL is given. Define the would-be universal arrow at câˆˆð’žc \in \mathcal{C} to be the unit of the adjunction Î· c\eta_c via Def. 11. Then the statement that this really is a universal arrow is implied by Prop. 3.

In the other direction, assume that universal arrows Î· c\eta_c are given. The uniqueness clause in Def. 12 immediately implies bijections

Hom ð’Ÿ(L(c),d) âŸ¶â‰ƒ Hom ð’ž(c,R(d)) (L(c)â†’fËœd) â†¦ (câ†’Î· cR(L(c))â†’R(fËœ)R(d)) \array{ Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L(c),d) &\overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(c,R(d)) \\ \left( L(c) \overset{\widetilde f}{\to} d \right) &\mapsto& \left( c \overset{\eta_c}{\to} R(L(c)) \overset{ R(\widetilde f) }{\to} R(d) \right) }

Hence to satisfy (9) it remains to show that these are natural in both variables. In fact, by Prop. 5 it is sufficient to show naturality in the variable dd. But this is immediate from the functoriality of RR applied in (16): For h:d 1â†’d 2h \colon d_1 \to d_2 any morphism, we have

c Î· câ†™ â†˜ f R(L(c)) âŸ¶R(fËœ) R(d 1) R(hâˆ˜fËœ)â†˜ â†“ R(h) R(d 2) \array{ && c \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\eta_c}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ R (L(c)) &&\underset{R (\widetilde f)}{\longrightarrow}&& R(d_1) \\ && {}_{\mathllap{ R( h\circ \widetilde f ) }}\searrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{R(h)}} \\ && && R(d_2) }

\,

After these equivalent characterizations of adjoint functors, we now consider some of their main properties:

Proposition

(adjoint functors are unique up to natural isomorphism)

The left adjoint or right adjoint to a functor (Def. 10), if it exists, is unique up to natural isomorphism (Def. 9).

Proof

Suppose the functor L:ð’Ÿâ†’ð’žL \colon \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{C} is given, and we are asking for uniqueness of its right adjoint, if it exists. The other case is directly analogous.

Suppose that R 1,R 2:ð’žâ†’ð’ŸR_1, R_2 \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{D} are two functors which both are right adjoint to LL. Then for each dâˆˆð’Ÿd \in \mathcal{D} the corresponding two hom-isomorphisms (9) combine to say that there is a natural isomorphism/

Î¦ d:Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,R 1(d))â‰ƒHom ð’ž(âˆ’,R 2(d)) \Phi_d \;\colon\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,R_1(d)) \;\simeq\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,R_2(d))

As in the proof of Prop. 5, the Yoneda lemma implies that

Î¦ d=y(Ï• d) \Phi_d \;=\; y( \phi_d )

for some isomorphism

Ï• d:R 1(d)â†’â‰ƒR 2(d). \phi_d \;\colon\; R_1(d) \overset{\simeq}{\to} R_2(d) \,.

But then the uniqueness statement of Prop. 5 implies that the collection of these isomorphisms for each object constitues a natural isomorphism between the functors (Def. 9).

Proposition

(characterization of epi/mono/iso (co-)unit of adjunction)

Let LâŠ£RL \dashv R be a pair of adjoint functors (Def. 10). Then the following holds:

  • RR is faithful precisely if the component of the counit over every object xx is an epimorphism LRxâ†’xL R x \stackrel{}{\to} x (Def. 7);

  • RR is full precisely if the component of the counit over every object xx is a split monomorphism LRxâ†’xL R x \stackrel{}{\to} x ;

  • LL is faithful precisely if the component of the unit over every object xx is a monomorphism xâ†ªRLxx \hookrightarrow R L x ;

  • LL is full precisely if the component of the unit over every object xx is a split epimorphism xâ†’RLxx \to R L x ;

  • RR is full and faithful (exhibits a reflective subcategory) precisely if the counit is a natural isomorphism Ïµ:Lâˆ˜Râ†’â‰ƒId D\epsilon : L \circ R \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} Id_D

  • LL is full and faithful (exhibits a coreflective subcategory) precisely if the unit is a natural isomorphism Î·:Id Câ†’â‰ƒRâˆ˜L\eta : Id_C \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} R \circ L.

  • The following are equivalent:

    • LL and RR are both full and faithful;

    • LL is an equivalence;

    • RR is an equivalence.

Proof

For the characterization of faithful RR by epi counit components, use from Def. 7 that LRxâ†’xL R x \to x being an epimorphism means that the induced function

Hom(x,a)â†’Hom(LRx,a) Hom(x, a) \to Hom(L R x, a)

is an injection for all objects aa. By the adjunction hom-isomorphism (9)

Hom(LRx,a)â†’â‰ƒHom(Rx,Ra), Hom(L R x , a ) \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} Hom(R x, R a) \,,

the formula for adjuncts (Prop. 3) and the triangle identity (13), this is such that the composite

R x,a:Hom(x,a)â†’Hom(LRx,a)â†’â‰ƒHom(Rx,Ra) R_{x,a} : Hom(x,a) \to Hom(L R x, a) \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} Hom(R x, R a)

is the component map of the functor RR:

(xâ†’fa) â†¦(LRxâ†’xâ†’fa) â†¦(RLRxâ†’Rxâ†’RfRa) â†¦(Rxâ†’RLRxâ†’Rxâ†’RfRa) =(Rxâ†’RfRa). \begin{aligned} (x \stackrel{f}{\to} a) & \mapsto (L R x \to x \stackrel{f}{\to} a) \\ & \mapsto (R L R x \to R x \stackrel{R f}{\to} R a) \\ & \mapsto (R x \to R L R x \to R x \stackrel{R f}{\to} R a) \\ & = (R x \stackrel{R f}{\to} R a) \end{aligned} \,.

Therefore R x,aR_{x,a} is injective for all x,ax,a, hence RR is faithful, precisely if LRxâ†’xL R x \to x is an epimorphism for all xx. The characterization of RR full is just the same reasoning applied to the fact that Ïµ x:LRxâ†’x\epsilon_x \colon L R x \to x is a split monomorphism iff for all objects aa the induced function

(17)Hom(x,a)â†’Hom(LRx,a) Hom(x, a) \to Hom(L R x, a)

is a surjection.

For the characterization of faithful LL by monic units notice that analogously (as discussed at monomorphism) xâ†’RLxx \to R L x is a monomorphism if for all objects aa the function

Hom(a,x)â†’Hom(a,RLx) Hom(a,x ) \to Hom(a, R L x)

is an injection. Analogously to the previous argument we find that this is equivalent to

L a,x:Hom(a,x)â†’Hom(a,RLx)â†’â‰ƒHom(La,Lx) L_{a,x} : Hom(a,x ) \to Hom(a, R L x) \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} Hom(L a, L x)

being an injection. So LL is faithful precisely if all xâ†’RLxx \to R L x are monos. For LL full, itâ€™s just the same applied to xâ†’RLxx \to R L x split epimorphism iff the induced function

Hom(a,x)â†’Hom(a,RLx) Hom(a,x ) \to Hom(a, R L x)

is a surjection, for all objects aa.

The proof of the other statements proceeds analogously.

\,

Equivalences

Definition

(adjoint equivalence of categories)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C}, ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be two categories (Def. 1). Then an adjoint equivalence of categories between them is a pair adjoint functors (Def. 10)

ð’žAAâ‰ƒAAâŸ¶RâŸµLð’Ÿ \array{ \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {\phantom{AA} \simeq \phantom{AA}} \mathcal{D} }

such that their unit Î·\eta and counit Ïµ\epsilon (Def. 11) are natural isomorphisms (as opposed to just being natural transformations)

Î·:id ð’Ÿâ‡’â‰ƒRâˆ˜LAAAandAAAÏµ:Lâˆ˜Râ‡’â‰ƒid ð’ž. \eta\;\colon\; id_{\mathcal{D}} \overset{\simeq}{\Rightarrow} R \circ L \phantom{AAA} \text{and} \phantom{AAA} \epsilon\;\colon\; L \circ R \overset{\simeq}{\Rightarrow} id_{\mathcal{C}} \,.

There is also the following, seemingly weaker, notion:

Definition

(equivalence of categories)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C}, ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be two categories (Def. 1). Then an equivalence of categories

ð’žAAâ‰ƒAAâŸ¶RâŸµLð’Ÿ \array{ \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {\phantom{AA} \simeq \phantom{AA}} \mathcal{D} }

is a pair of functors back and forth, as shown (Def. 6), together with natural isomorphisms (Def. 9) between their composition and the identity functors:

id ð’Ÿâ‡’â‰ƒRâˆ˜LAAAandAAALâˆ˜Râ‡’â‰ƒid ð’ž. id_{\mathcal{D}} \overset{\simeq}{\Rightarrow} R \circ L \phantom{AAA} \text{and} \phantom{AAA} L \circ R \overset{\simeq}{\Rightarrow} id_{\mathcal{C}} \,.

If a functor participates in an equivalence of categories, that functor alone is usually already called an equivalence of categories. If there is any equivalence of categories between two categories, these categories are called equivalent.

Proposition

(every equivalence of categories comes from an adjoint equivalence of categories)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} and ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be two categories (Def. 1). Then the they are equivalent (Def. 14) precisely if there exists an adjoint equivalence of categories between them (Def. 13).

Moreover, let R:ð’žâŸ¶ð’ŸR \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D} be a functor (Def. 6) which participates in an equivalence of categories (Def. 14). Then for every functor L:ð’Ÿâ†’ð’žL \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{C} equipped with a natural isomorphism

Î·:id ð’Ÿâ‡’â‰ƒRâˆ˜L \eta \;\colon\; id_{\mathcal{D}} \overset{\simeq}{\Rightarrow} R \circ L

there exists a natural isomorphism

Ïµ:Lâˆ˜Râ‡’â‰ƒid ð’ž \epsilon \;\colon\; L \circ R \overset{\simeq}{\Rightarrow} id_{\mathcal{C}}

which completes this to an adjoint equivalence of categories (Def. 13).

\,

Modalities

Generally, a full subcategory-inclusion (Def. 8) may be thought of as a consistent proposition about objects in a category: The objects in the full subcategory are those that have the given property.

This basic situation becomes particularly interesting when the inclusion functor has a left adjoint or a right adjoint (Def. 10), in which case one speaks of a reflective subcategory, or a coreflective subcategory, respectively (Def. 15 below). The adjunction now implies that each object is reflected or coreflected into the subcategory, and equipped with a comparison morphism to or from its (co-)reflection (the adjunction (co-)unit, Def. 11). This comparison morphism turns out to always be an idempotent (co-)projection, in a sense made precise by Prop. 11 below.

This means that, while any object may not fully enjoy the property that defines the subcategory, one may ask for the â€œaspectâ€ of it that does, which is what is (co-)projected out. Regarding objects only via these aspects of them hence means to regard them only locally (where they exhibit that aspect) or only in the mode of focus on this aspect. Therefore one also calls the (co-)reflection operation into the given subcategory a (co-)localization or (co-)modal operator, or modality, for short (Def. 16 below).

One finds that (co-)modalities are a fully equivalent perspective on the (co-)reflective subcategories of their fully (co-)modal objects (Def. 17 below), this is the statement of Prop. 10 below.

\,

Definition

(reflective subcategory and coreflective subcategory)

Let ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be a category (Def. 1) and

ð’žâ†ªAAÎ¹AAð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \overset{\phantom{AA}\iota \phantom{AA}}{\hookrightarrow} \mathcal{D}

a full subcategory-inclusion (hence a fully faithful functor Def. 8). This is called:

  1. a reflective subcategory inclusion if the inclusion functor Î¹\iota has a left adjoint LL def. 10)

    ð’žâŠ¥â†ªAAÎ¹AAâŸµLð’Ÿ, \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{\phantom{AA} \iota \phantom{AA}}{\hookrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{D} \,,

    then called the reflector;

  2. a coreflective subcategory-inclusion if the inclusion functor Î¹\iota has a right adjoint RR (def. 10)

    ð’žâŠ¥âŸµRâ†ªAAÎ¹AAð’Ÿ, \mathcal{C} \underoverset \underset{R}{\longleftarrow} {\overset{\phantom{AA} \iota \phantom{AA}}{\hookrightarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{D} \,,

    then called the coreflector.

Example
