(reflective subcategory inclusion of sets into small groupoids)

There is a reflective subcategory-inclusion (Def. 15)

SetâŠ¥â†ªAAAAâŸµÏ€ 0Grp Set \underoverset {\underset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\hookrightarrow}} {\overset{\pi_0}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} Grp

of the category of sets (Example 1) into the category Grpd (Example 7) of small groupoids (Example 5) where

  • the right adjoint full subcategory inclusion (Def. 8) sends a set SS to the groupoid with set of objects being SS, and the only morphisms being the identity morphisms on these objects (also called the discrete groupoid on SS, but this terminology is ambiguous)

  • the left adjoint reflector sends a small groupoid ð’¢\mathcal{G} to its set of connected components, namely to the set of equivalence classes under the equivalence relation on the set of objects, which regards two objects as equivalent, if there is any morphism between them.

Definition

(modality)

Let ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be a category (Def. 1). Then

  1. a modal operator on ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} is

    1. an endofunctor

      â—¯:ð’Ÿâ†’ð’Ÿ \bigcirc \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{D}

      whose full essential image we denote by

      Im(â—¯)â†ªAAÎ¹AAð’Ÿ, Im(\bigcirc) \overset{\phantom{AA} \iota \phantom{AA}}{\hookrightarrow} \mathcal{D} \,,

    2. a natural transformation (Def. 9)

      (18)XâŸ¶Î· Xâ—¯X X \overset{\eta_X}{\longrightarrow} \bigcirc X

      for all objects Xâˆˆð’ŸX \in \mathcal{D}, to be called the unit morphism;

    such that:

    • for every object YâˆˆIm(â—¯)â†ªð’ŸY \in Im(\bigcirc) \hookrightarrow \mathcal{D} in the essential image of â—¯\bigcirc, every morphism ff into YY factors uniquely through the unit (18)

      X Î· Xâ†™ â†˜ f â—¯X âŸ¶âˆƒ! Y âˆˆIm(â—¯) \array{ && X \\ & {}^{\mathllap{ \eta_X }}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ \mathrlap{\bigcirc X\;\;\;\;} && \underset{\exists !}{\longrightarrow} && Y & \in Im(\bigcirc) }

  2. a comodal operator on ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} is

    1. an endofunctor

      â–¡:ð’Ÿâ†’ð’Ÿ \Box \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{D}

      whose full essential image we denote by

      Im(â–¡)â†ªAAÎ¹AAð’Ÿ Im( \Box ) \overset{\phantom{AA} \iota \phantom{AA}}{\hookrightarrow} \mathcal{D}

    2. a natural transformation (Def. 9)

      (19)â–¡XâŸ¶Ïµ XX \Box X \overset{ \epsilon_X }{\longrightarrow} X

      for all objects Xâˆˆð’ŸX \in \mathcal{D}, to be called the counit morphism;

    such that:

    • for every object YâˆˆIm(â–¡)â†ªð’ŸY \in Im( \Box ) \hookrightarrow \mathcal{D} in the essential image of â–¡\Box, every morphism ff out of YY factors uniquely through the counit (18)

      X Ïµ Xâ†— â†– f â–¡X âŸµâˆƒ! YâˆˆIm(â–¡) \array{ && X \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\epsilon_X}}\nearrow && \nwarrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ \mathrlap{\Box X\;\;\;} && \underset{\exists !}{\longleftarrow} && Y \in Im( \Box ) }
Proposition

(modal operators equivalent to reflective subcategories)

If

ð’žâŠ¥â†ªAAÎ¹AAâŸµLð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{\phantom{AA} \iota \phantom{AA}}{\hookrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{D}

is a reflective subcategory-inclusion (Def. 15). Then the composite

â—¯â‰”Î¹âˆ˜L:ð’ŸâŸ¶ð’Ÿ \bigcirc \;\coloneqq\; \iota \circ L \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}

equipped with the adjunction unit natural transformation (Def. 11)

XâŸ¶Î· Xâ—¯X X \overset{\eta_X}{\longrightarrow} \bigcirc X

is a modal operator on ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} (Def. 16).

Dually, if

ð’žâŠ¥âŸµRâ†ªAAÎ¹AAð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longleftarrow}} {\overset{\phantom{AA} \iota \phantom{AA}}{\hookrightarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{D}

is a coreflective subcategory-inclusion (Def. 15). Then the composite

â–¡â‰”Î¹âˆ˜R:ð’ŸâŸ¶ð’Ÿ \Box \;\coloneqq\; \iota \circ R \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}

equipped with the adjunction counit natural transformation (Def. 11)

â–¡XâŸ¶Ïµ XX \Box X \overset{ \epsilon_X }{\longrightarrow} X

is a comodal operator on ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} (Def. 16).

Conversely:

If an endofunctor â—¯:ð’Ÿâ†’ð’Ÿ\bigcirc \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{D} with natural transformation Xâ†’Î· Xâ—¯XX \overset{\eta_X}{\to} \bigcirc X is a modal operator on a category ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} (Def. 16), then the inclusion of its full essential image is a reflective subcategory inclusion (Def. 15) with reflector given by the corestriction of â—¯\bigcirc to its image:

Im(â—¯)â†ªAAÎ¹AAâŸµâ—¯ð’Ÿ. Im( \bigcirc ) \underoverset {\underset{ \phantom{AA} \iota \phantom{AA} }{\hookrightarrow}} {\overset{ \bigcirc }{\longleftarrow}} {} \mathcal{D} \,.

Dually, if an endofunctor â–¡:ð’Ÿâ†’ð’Ÿ\Box \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{D} with natural transformation â–¡XâŸ¶Ïµ XX\Box X \overset{\epsilon_X}{\longrightarrow} X is a comodal operator (Def. 16), then the inclusion of its full essential image is a coreflective subcategory inclusion (Def. 15) with coreflector given by the corestriction of â–¡\Box to its image

Im(â–¡)âŸµâ–¡â†ªAAÎ¹AAð’Ÿ. Im( \Box ) \underoverset {\underset{ \Box }{\longleftarrow}} {\overset{ \phantom{AA} \iota \phantom{AA} }{\hookrightarrow}} {} \mathcal{D} \,.
Proof

The first two statements are immedialy a special case of the characterization of adjunctions via universal morphisms in Prop. 6: Using that R=Î¹R = \iota is here assumed to be fully faithful, the uniqueness of fËœ\tilde f in the universal morphism-factorization condition (16)

c Î· câ†™ â†˜ f R(L(c)) âŸ¶R(fËœ) R(d) L(c) âŸ¶âˆƒ!fËœ d \array{ && c \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\eta_c}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{f}} \\ R(L(c)) &&\underset{R (\widetilde f)}{\longrightarrow}&& R(d) \\ \\ L(c) &&\underset{ \exists ! \, \widetilde f}{\longrightarrow}&& d }

implies that also R(fËœ)=Î¹(fËœ)R(\widetilde f) = \iota(\widetilde f) is the unique morphism making that triangle commute.

Similarly for the converse: The assumption on a modal operator â—¯\bigcirc is just so as to make its unit Î·\eta be a universal morphism (Def. 12) into the inclusion functor Î¹\iota of its essential image.

Proposition

(modal operator is idempotent)

Let ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be a category (Def. 1).

For â—¯\bigcirc a modal operator on ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D}, with unit Î·\eta (Def. 10), it is idempotent, in that it is naturally isomorphic (Def. 9) to the composition with itself:

â—¯â‰ƒâ—¯â—¯. \bigcirc \;\simeq\; \bigcirc \bigcirc \,.

In fact, the image under â—¯\bigcirc of its unit is such an isomorphism

â—¯(Xâ†’Î· Xâ—¯X):â—¯XâŸ¶â‰ƒâ—¯(â—¯X) \bigcirc\left( X \overset{\eta_X}{\to} \bigcirc X \right) \;\;\colon\;\; \bigcirc X \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} \bigcirc ( \bigcirc X )

as is its unit on its image

Î· â—¯X:â—¯XâŸ¶â‰ƒâ—¯(â—¯X). \eta_{\bigcirc X} \;\;\colon\;\; \bigcirc X \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} \bigcirc ( \bigcirc X ) \,.

Dually, for â–¡\Box a comodal operator on ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D}, with counit Ïµ\epsilon (Def. 10), it is idempotent, in that it is naturally isomorphic (Def. 9) to the composition with itsef:

â–¡âˆ˜â–¡â‰ƒâ–¡. \Box \circ \Box \;\simeq\; \Box \,.

In fact, the image under â–¡\Box of its counit is such an isomorphism

â–¡(â–¡Xâ†’Ïµ XX):â–¡(â–¡X)âŸ¶â‰ƒâ–¡X \Box\left( \Box X \overset{\epsilon_X}{\to} X \right) \;\;\colon\;\; \Box (\Box X) \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} \Box X

as is its counit on its image

Ïµ â–¡X:â–¡(â–¡X)âŸ¶â‰ƒâ–¡X. \epsilon_{\Box X} \;\;\colon\;\; \Box ( \Box X ) \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} \Box X \,.
Proof

We discuss the first case. The second is formally dual.

By Prop. 10, the modal operator is equivalent to the composite Î¹âˆ˜L\iota \circ L obtained from the reflective subcategory-inclusion (Def. 15) of its essential image of modal objects:

Im(â—¯)âŠ¥â†ªAAÎ¹AAâŸµAALAAð’Ÿ. Im(\bigcirc) \underoverset {\underset{\phantom{AA}\iota \phantom{AA}}{\hookrightarrow}} {\overset{\phantom{AA}L \phantom{AA} }{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{D} \,.

and its unit is the corresponding adjunction unit (Def. 11)

XâŸ¶Î· XÎ¹âˆ˜L. X \overset{\eta_X}{\longrightarrow} \iota \circ L \,.

Hence it is sufficient to show that the morphisms and L(Î· X)L( \eta_X ) and Î· Î¹Y\eta_{\iota Y} are isomorphisms.

Now, the triangle identities (13) for the adjunction LâŠ£Î¹L \dashv \iota, which hold by Prop. 3, say that their composition with the adjunction counit is the identity morphism

Ïµ L(Î· X)âˆ˜L(Î· X)=id L(X)AAandAAÎ¹(Ïµ Y)âˆ˜Î· Î¹(Y)=id Î¹(Y). \epsilon_{L(\eta_X)} \circ L(\eta_X) \;=\; id_{L(X)} \phantom{AA} \text{and} \phantom{AA} \iota( \epsilon_Y )\circ \eta_{\iota(Y)} \;=\; id_{\iota(Y)} \,.

But by Prop. 8, the counit Ïµ\epsilon is a natural isomorphism, since Î¹\iota is fully faithful. Hence we may cancel it on both sides of the triangle identities and find that L(Î· X)L(\eta_X) and Î· Î¹(Y)\eta_{\iota(Y)} are indeed isomorphisms.

Definition

(modal objects)

Let ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be a category (Def. 1).

For â—¯\bigcirc a modal operator on ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} (Def. 16), we say:

  1. a â—¯\bigcirc-modal object is an object Xâˆˆð’ŸX \in \mathcal{D} such that the following conditions hold (which are all equivalent, by Prop. 11):

    • it is in the â—¯\bigcirc-essential image: XâˆˆIm(â—¯)â†ªð’ŸX \in Im( \bigcirc ) \hookrightarrow \mathcal{D},

    • it is isomorphic to its own â—¯\bigcirc-image: Xâ‰ƒâ—¯XX \simeq \bigcirc X,

    • specifically its â—¯\bigcirc-unit is an isomorphism Î· X:Xâ†’â‰ƒâ—¯X\eta_X \;\colon\; X \overset{\simeq}{\to} \bigcirc X.

  2. a â—¯\bigcirc-submodal object is an object Xâˆˆð’ŸX \in \mathcal{D}, such that

    • its â—¯\bigcirc-unit is a monomorphism (Def. 7): Î· X:Xâ†ªâ—¯X\eta_X \;\colon\; X \hookrightarrow \bigcirc X.

Dually:

For â–¡\Box a comodal operator on ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} (Def. 16), we say:

  1. a â–¡\Box-comodal object is an object Xâˆˆð’ŸX \in \mathcal{D} such that the following conditions hold (which are all equivalent, by Prop. 11):

    • it is in the â–¡\Box-essential image: XâˆˆIm(â–¡)â†ªð’ŸX \in Im( \Box ) \hookrightarrow \mathcal{D},

    • it is isomorphic to its own â–¡\Box-image: â–¡Xâ‰ƒX\Box X \simeq X,

    • specifically its â–¡\Box-counit is an isomorphism Ïµ X:â–¡XâŸ¶â‰ƒX\epsilon_X \;\colon\; \Box X \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} X

  2. a â–¡\Box-supcomodal object is an object Xâˆˆð’ŸX \in \mathcal{D}, such that

    • its â–¡\Box-counit is an epimorphism (Def. 7): Ïµ X:â–¡XâŸ¶epiX\epsilon_X \;\colon\; \Box X \overset{epi}{\longrightarrow} X.

(â€¦)

\,

Basic notions of Categorical algebra

We have seen that the existence of Cartesian products in a category ð’ž\mathcal{C} equips is with a functor of the form

ð’žÃ—ð’žâŸ¶(âˆ’)Ã—(âˆ’)ð’ž \mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{C} \overset{ (-) \times (-) }{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{C}

which is directly analogous to the operation of multiplication in an associative algebra or even just in a semigroup (or monoid), just â€œcategorifiedâ€ (Example 17 below). This is made precise by the concept of a monoidal category (Def. 18 below).

This relation between category theory and algebra leads to the fields of categorical algebra and of universal algebra.

Here we are mainly interested in monoidal categories as a foundations for enriched category theory, to which we turn below.

\,

Monoidal categories

Definition

(monoidal category)

An_monoidal category_ is a category ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Def. 1) equipped with

  1. a functor (Def. 6)

    âŠ—:ð’žÃ—ð’žâŸ¶ð’ž \otimes \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}

    out of the product category of ð’ž\mathcal{C} with itself (Example 6), called the tensor product,

  2. an object

    1âˆˆObj ð’ž 1 \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}}

    called the unit object or tensor unit,

  3. a natural isomorphism (Def. 9)

    a:((âˆ’)âŠ—(âˆ’))âŠ—(âˆ’)âŸ¶â‰ƒ(âˆ’)âŠ—((âˆ’)âŠ—(âˆ’)) a \;\colon\; ((-)\otimes (-)) \otimes (-) \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} (-) \otimes ((-)\otimes(-))

    called the associator,

  4. a natural isomorphism

    â„“:(1âŠ—(âˆ’))âŸ¶â‰ƒ(âˆ’) \ell \;\colon\; (1 \otimes (-)) \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} (-)

    called the left unitor, and a natural isomorphism

    r:(âˆ’)âŠ—1âŸ¶â‰ƒ(âˆ’) r \;\colon\; (-) \otimes 1 \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} (-)

    called the right unitor,

such that the following two kinds of diagrams commute, for all objects involved:

  1. triangle identity:

    (xâŠ—1)âŠ—y âŸ¶a x,1,y xâŠ—(1âŠ—y) Ï xâŠ—1 yâ†˜ â†™ 1 xâŠ—Î» y xâŠ—y \array{ & (x \otimes 1) \otimes y &\stackrel{a_{x,1,y}}{\longrightarrow} & x \otimes (1 \otimes y) \\ & {}_{\rho_x \otimes 1_y}\searrow && \swarrow_{1_x \otimes \lambda_y} & \\ && x \otimes y && }

  2. the pentagon identity:

    (wâŠ—x)âŠ—(yâŠ—z) Î± wâŠ—x,y,zâ†— â†˜ Î± w,x,yâŠ—z ((wâŠ—x)âŠ—y)âŠ—z (wâŠ—(xâŠ—(yâŠ—z))) Î± w,x,yâŠ—id zâ†“ â†‘ id wâŠ—Î± x,y,z (wâŠ—(xâŠ—y))âŠ—z âŸ¶Î± w,xâŠ—y,z wâŠ—((xâŠ—y)âŠ—z) \array{ && (w \otimes x) \otimes (y \otimes z) \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\alpha_{w \otimes x, y, z}}}\nearrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{\alpha_{w,x,y \otimes z}}} \\ ((w \otimes x ) \otimes y) \otimes z && && (w \otimes (x \otimes (y \otimes z))) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\alpha_{w,x,y}} \otimes id_z }\downarrow && && \uparrow^{\mathrlap{ id_w \otimes \alpha_{x,y,z} }} \\ (w \otimes (x \otimes y)) \otimes z && \underset{\alpha_{w,x \otimes y, z}}{\longrightarrow} && w \otimes ( (x \otimes y) \otimes z ) }
Example

(cartesian monoidal category)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a category in which all finite products exist. Then ð’ž\mathcal{C} becomes a monoidal category (Def. 18) by

  1. taking the tensor product to be the Cartesian product

    XâŠ—Yâ‰”XÃ—Y X \otimes Y \;\coloneqq\; X \times Y

  2. taking the unit object to be the terminal object

    Iâ‰”* I \;\coloneqq\; \ast

Monoidal categories of this form are called cartesian monoidal categories.

Lemma

(Kelly 64)

Let (ð’ž,âŠ—,1)(\mathcal{C}, \otimes, 1) be a monoidal category, def. 18. Then the left and right unitors â„“\ell and rr satisfy the following conditions:

  1. â„“ 1=r 1:1âŠ—1âŸ¶â‰ƒ1\ell_1 = r_1 \;\colon\; 1 \otimes 1 \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} 1;

  2. for all objects x,yâˆˆð’žx,y \in \mathcal{C} the following diagrams commutes:

    (1âŠ—x)âŠ—y Î± 1,x,yâ†“ â†˜ â„“ xâŠ—id y 1âŠ—(xâŠ—y) âŸ¶â„“ xâŠ—y xâŠ—y; \array{ (1 \otimes x) \otimes y & & \\ {}^\mathllap{\alpha_{1, x, y}} \downarrow & \searrow^\mathrlap{\ell_x \otimes id_y} & \\ 1 \otimes (x \otimes y) & \underset{\ell_{x \otimes y}}{\longrightarrow} & x \otimes y } \,;

    and

    xâŠ—(yâŠ—1) Î± 1,x,y âˆ’1â†“ â†˜ id xâŠ—r y (xâŠ—y)âŠ—1 âŸ¶r xâŠ—y xâŠ—y; \array{ x \otimes (y \otimes 1) & & \\ {}^\mathllap{\alpha^{-1}_{1, x, y}} \downarrow & \searrow^\mathrlap{id_x \otimes r_y} & \\ (x \otimes y) \otimes 1 & \underset{r_{x \otimes y}}{\longrightarrow} & x \otimes y } \,;

For proof see at monoidal category this lemma and this lemma.

Remark

Just as for an associative algebra it is sufficient to demand 1a=a1 a = a and a1=aa 1 = a and (ab)c=a(bc)(a b) c = a (b c) in order to have that expressions of arbitrary length may be re-bracketed at will, so there is a coherence theorem for monoidal categories which states that all ways of freely composing the unitors and associators in a monoidal category (def. 18) to go from one expression to another will coincide. Accordingly, much as one may drop the notation for the bracketing in an associative algebra altogether, so one may, with due care, reason about monoidal categories without always making all unitors and associators explicit.

(Here the qualifier â€œfreelyâ€ means informally that we must not use any non-formal identification between objects, and formally it means that the diagram in question must be in the image of a strong monoidal functor from a free monoidal category. For example if in a particular monoidal category it so happens that the object XâŠ—(YâŠ—Z)X \otimes (Y \otimes Z) is actually equal to (XâŠ—Y)âŠ—Z(X \otimes Y)\otimes Z, then the various ways of going from one expression to another using only associators and this equality no longer need to coincide.)

Definition

(braided monoidal category)

A braided monoidal category, is a monoidal category ð’ž\mathcal{C} (def. 18) equipped with a natural isomorphism (Def. 9)

(20)Ï„ x,y:xâŠ—yâ†’yâŠ—x \tau_{x,y} \colon x \otimes y \to y \otimes x

called the braiding, such that the following two kinds of diagrams commute for all objects involved (â€œhexagon identitiesâ€):

(xâŠ—y)âŠ—z â†’a x,y,z xâŠ—(yâŠ—z) â†’Ï„ x,yâŠ—z (yâŠ—z)âŠ—x â†“ Ï„ x,yâŠ—Id â†“ a y,z,x (yâŠ—x)âŠ—z â†’a y,x,z yâŠ—(xâŠ—z) â†’IdâŠ—Ï„ x,z yâŠ—(zâŠ—x) \array{ (x \otimes y) \otimes z &\stackrel{a_{x,y,z}}{\to}& x \otimes (y \otimes z) &\stackrel{\tau_{x,y \otimes z}}{\to}& (y \otimes z) \otimes x \\ \downarrow^{\tau_{x,y}\otimes Id} &&&& \downarrow^{a_{y,z,x}} \\ (y \otimes x) \otimes z &\stackrel{a_{y,x,z}}{\to}& y \otimes (x \otimes z) &\stackrel{Id \otimes \tau_{x,z}}{\to}& y \otimes (z \otimes x) }

and

xâŠ—(yâŠ—z) â†’a x,y,z âˆ’1 (xâŠ—y)âŠ—z â†’Ï„ xâŠ—y,z zâŠ—(xâŠ—y) â†“ IdâŠ—Ï„ y,z â†“ a z,x,y âˆ’1 xâŠ—(zâŠ—y) â†’a x,z,y âˆ’1 (xâŠ—z)âŠ—y â†’Ï„ x,zâŠ—Id (zâŠ—x)âŠ—y, \array{ x \otimes (y \otimes z) &\stackrel{a^{-1}_{x,y,z}}{\to}& (x \otimes y) \otimes z &\stackrel{\tau_{x \otimes y, z}}{\to}& z \otimes (x \otimes y) \\ \downarrow^{Id \otimes \tau_{y,z}} &&&& \downarrow^{a^{-1}_{z,x,y}} \\ x \otimes (z \otimes y) &\stackrel{a^{-1}_{x,z,y}}{\to}& (x \otimes z) \otimes y &\stackrel{\tau_{x,z} \otimes Id}{\to}& (z \otimes x) \otimes y } \,,

where a x,y,z:(xâŠ—y)âŠ—zâ†’xâŠ—(yâŠ—z)a_{x,y,z} \colon (x \otimes y) \otimes z \to x \otimes (y \otimes z) denotes the components of the associator of ð’ž âŠ—\mathcal{C}^\otimes.

Definition

A symmetric monoidal category is a braided monoidal category (def. 19) for which the braiding

Ï„ x,y:xâŠ—yâ†’yâŠ—x \tau_{x,y} \colon x \otimes y \to y \otimes x

satisfies the condition:

Ï„ y,xâˆ˜Ï„ x,y=1 xâŠ—y \tau_{y,x} \circ \tau_{x,y} = 1_{x \otimes y}

for all objects x,yx, y

Remark

In analogy to the coherence theorem for monoidal categories (remark 3) there is a coherence theorem for symmetric monoidal categories (def. 20), saying that every diagram built freely (see remark 4) from associators, unitors and braidings such that both sides of the diagram correspond to the same permutation of objects, coincide.

Definition

(symmetric closed monoidal category)

Given a symmetric monoidal category ð’ž\mathcal{C} with tensor product âŠ—\otimes (def. 20) it is called a closed monoidal category if for each Yâˆˆð’žY \in \mathcal{C} the functor YâŠ—(âˆ’)â‰ƒ(âˆ’)âŠ—YY \otimes(-)\simeq (-)\otimes Y has a right adjoint, denoted hom(Y,âˆ’)hom(Y,-)

(21)ð’žâŠ¥âŸ¶[Y,âˆ’]âŸµ(âˆ’)âŠ—Yð’ž, \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{ [Y,-]}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{(-) \otimes Y}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{C} \,,

hence if there are natural bijections

Hom ð’ž(XâŠ—Y,Z)â‰ƒHom ð’žC(X,[Y,Z]) Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X \otimes Y, Z) \;\simeq\; Hom_{\mathcal{C}}{C}(X, [Y,Z])

for all objects X,Zâˆˆð’žX,Z \in \mathcal{C}.

Since for the case that X=1X = 1 is the tensor unit of ð’ž\mathcal{C} this means that

Hom ð’ž(1,[Y,Z])â‰ƒHom ð’ž(Y,Z), Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(1, [Y,Z]) \simeq Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Y,Z) \,,

the object [Y,Z]âˆˆð’ž[Y,Z] \in \mathcal{C} is an enhancement of the ordinary hom-set Hom ð’ž(Y,Z)Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Y,Z) to an object in ð’ž\mathcal{C}. Accordingly, it is also called the internal hom between YY and ZZ.

Example

(Set is a cartesian closed category)

The category Set of all sets (Example 1) equipped with its cartesian monoidal category-structure (Example 17) is a closed monoidal category (Def. 21), hence a [[cartesian closed category]. The Cartesian product is the original Cartesian product of sets, and the internal hom is the function set [X,Y][X,Y] of functions from XX to YY

Example

(Cat and Grpd are cartesian closed category)

The category Cat (Example 7) of all small categories (Example 3) is a cartesian monoidal category-structure (Example 17) with Cartesian product given by forming product categories (Example 6).

Inside this, the full subcategory (Example 9) Grpd (Example 7) of all small groupoids (Example 5) is itself a cartesian monoidal category-structure (Example 17) with Cartesian product given by forming product categories (Example 6).

In both cases this yields a closed monoidal category (Def. 21), hence a cartesian closed category: the internal hom is given by the functor category construction (Example 13).

Example

(tensor product of abelian groups is closed monoidal category symmetric monoidal category-structure)

The category Ab of abelian groups (as in Example 2) becomes a symmetric monoidal category (Def. 20) with tensor product the actual tensor product of abelian groups âŠ— â„¤\otimes_{\mathbb{Z}} and with tensor unit the additive group â„¤\mathbb{Z} of integers. Again the associator, unitor and braiding isomorphism are the evident ones coming from the underlying sets, as in example \ref{TopAsASymmetricMonoidalCategory}.

This is a closed monoidal category with internal hom hom(A,B)hom(A,B) being the set of homomorphisms Hom Ab(A,B)Hom_{Ab}(A,B) equipped with the pointwise group structure for Ï• 1,Ï• 2âˆˆHom Ab(A,B)\phi_1, \phi_2 \in Hom_{Ab}(A,B) then (Ï• 1+Ï• 2)(a)â‰”Ï• 1(a)+Ï• 2(b)âˆˆB(\phi_1 + \phi_2)(a) \coloneqq \phi_1(a) + \phi_2(b) \; \in B.

This is the archetypical case that motivates the notation â€œâŠ—\otimesâ€ for the pairing operation in a monoidal category.

The internal hom (Def. 21) turns out to share all the abstract properties of the ordinary (external) hom-functor (Def. 8), even though this is not completely manifest from its definition. We make this explicit by the following three propositions.

Proposition

(internal hom bifunctor)

For ð’ž\mathcal{C} a closed monoidal category (Def. 21), there is a unique functor (Def. 6) out of the product category (Def. 6) of ð’ž\mathcal{C} with its opposite category (Def. 5)

[âˆ’,âˆ’]:ð’ž opÃ—ð’žâŸ¶ð’ž [-,-] \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}

such that for each Xâˆˆð’žX \in \mathcal{C} it coincides with the internal hom [X,âˆ’][X,-] (21) as a functor in the second variable, and such that there is a natural isomorphism

Hom(X,[Y,Z])â‰ƒHom(XâŠ—Y,Z) Hom(X, [Y,Z]) \;\simeq\; Hom(X \otimes Y, Z)

which is natural not only in XX and ZZ, but also in YY.

Proof

We have a natural isomorphism for each fixed YY, and hence in particular for fixed YY and fixed ZZ by (21). With this the statement follows by Prop. 5.

In fact the 3-variable adjunction from Prop. 12 even holds internally:

Proposition

(internal tensor/hom-adjunction)

In a symmetric closed monoidal category (def. 21) there are natural isomorphisms

[XâŠ—Y,Z]â‰ƒ[X,[Y,Z]] [X \otimes Y, Z] \;\simeq\; [X, [Y,Z]]

whose image under Hom ð’ž(1,âˆ’)Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(1,-) (see also Example 22 below) are the defining natural bijections of Prop. 12.

Proof

Let Aâˆˆð’žA \in \mathcal{C} be any object. By applying the natural bijections from Prop. 12, there are composite natural bijections

Hom ð’ž(A,[XâŠ—Y,Z]) â‰ƒHom ð’ž(AâŠ—(XâŠ—Y),Z) â‰ƒHom ð’ž((AâŠ—X)âŠ—Y,Z) â‰ƒHom ð’ž(AâŠ—X,[Y,Z]) â‰ƒHom ð’ž(A,[X,[Y,Z]]) \begin{aligned} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(A , [X \otimes Y, Z]) & \simeq Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(A \otimes (X \otimes Y), Z) \\ & \simeq Hom_{\mathcal{C}}((A \otimes X)\otimes Y, Z) \\ & \simeq Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(A \otimes X, [Y,Z]) \\ & \simeq Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(A, [X, [Y,Z]]) \end{aligned}

Since this holds for all AA, the fully faithfulness of the Yoneda embedding (Prop. 2) says that there is an isomorphism [XâŠ—Y,Z]â‰ƒ[X,[Y,Z]][ X\otimes Y, Z ] \simeq [X, [Y,Z]]. Moreover, by taking A=1A = 1 in the above and using the left unitor isomorphisms AâŠ—(XâŠ—Y)â‰ƒXâŠ—YA \otimes (X \otimes Y) \simeq X \otimes Y and AâŠ—Xâ‰ƒXA\otimes X \simeq X we get a commuting diagram

Hom ð’ž(1,[XâŠ—Y,Z)) âŸ¶â‰ƒ Hom ð’ž(1,[X,[Y,Z]]) â‰ƒâ†“ â†“ â‰ƒ Hom ð’ž(XâŠ—Y,Z) âŸ¶â‰ƒ Hom ð’ž(X,[Y,Z]). \array{ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(1, [X\otimes Y, Z )) &\overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(1, [X, [Y,Z]]) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\simeq}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\simeq}} \\ Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X \otimes Y, Z) &\overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}& Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X, [Y,Z]) } \,.

Also the key respect? of the hom-functor for limits is inherited by internal hom-functors

Proposition

(internal hom preserves limits)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a symmetric closed monoidal category with internal hom-bifunctor [âˆ’,âˆ’][-,-] (Prop. 12). Then this bifunctor preserves limits in the second variable, and sends colimits in the first variable to limits:

[X,limâŸµjâˆˆð’¥Y(j)]â‰ƒlimâŸµjâˆˆð’¥[X,Y(j)] [X, \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} Y(j)] \;\simeq\; \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} [X, Y(j)]

and

[limâŸ¶jâˆˆð’¥Y(j),X]â‰ƒlimâŸµjâˆˆð’¥[Y(j),X] [\underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} Y(j),X] \;\simeq\; \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} [Y(j),X]
Proof

For Xâˆˆð’³X \in \mathcal{X} any object, [X,âˆ’][X,-] is a right adjoint by definition, and hence preserves limits by Prop. 17.

For the other case, let Y:â„’â†’ð’žY \;\colon\; \mathcal{L} \to \mathcal{C} be a diagram in ð’ž\mathcal{C}, and let Câˆˆð’žC \in \mathcal{C} be any object. Then there are isomorphisms

Hom ð’ž(C,limâŸ¶jâˆˆð’¥Y(j),X) â‰ƒHom ð’ž(CâŠ—limâŸ¶jâˆˆð’¥Y(j),X) â‰ƒHom ð’ž(limâŸ¶jâˆˆð’¥(CâŠ—Y(j)),X) â‰ƒlimâŸµjâˆˆð’¥Hom ð’ž((CâŠ—Y(j)),X) â‰ƒlimâŸµjâˆˆð’¥Hom ð’ž(C,[Y(j),X]) â‰ƒHom ð’ž(C,limâŸµjâˆˆð’¥[Y(j),X]) \begin{aligned} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(C, \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} Y(j), X ) & \simeq Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( C \otimes \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} Y(j), X ) \\ & \simeq Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} (C \otimes Y(j)), X ) \\ & \simeq \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( (C \otimes Y(j)), X ) \\ & \simeq \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( C, [Y(j), X] ) \\ & \simeq Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( C, \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} [Y(j), X] ) \end{aligned}

which are natural in Câˆˆð’žC \in \mathcal{C}, where we used that the ordinary hom-functor preserves limits (Prop. 16), and that the left adjoint CâŠ—(âˆ’)C \otimes (-) preserves colimits, since left adjoints preserve colimits (Prop. 17).

Hence by the fully faithfulness of the Yoneda embedding, there is an isomorphism

[limâŸ¶jâˆˆð’¥Y(j),X]âŸ¶â‰ƒlimâŸµjâˆˆð’¥[Y(j),X]. \left[ \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} Y(j), X \right] \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} [Y(j), X] \,.

\,

Now that we have seen monoidal categories with various extra properties, we next look at functors which preserve these:

Definition

(monoidal functors)

Let (ð’ž,âŠ— ð’ž,1 ð’ž)(\mathcal{C},\otimes_{\mathcal{C}}, 1_{\mathcal{C}}) and (ð’Ÿ,âŠ— ð’Ÿ,1 ð’Ÿ)(\mathcal{D},\otimes_{\mathcal{D}}, 1_{\mathcal{D}} ) be two monoidal categories (def. 18). A lax monoidal functor between them is

  1. a functor (Def. 6)

    F:ð’žâŸ¶ð’Ÿ, F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D} \,,

  2. a morphism

    (22)Ïµ:1 ð’ŸâŸ¶F(1 ð’ž) \epsilon \;\colon\; 1_{\mathcal{D}} \longrightarrow F(1_{\mathcal{C}})

  3. a natural transformation (Def. 9)

    (23)Î¼ x,y:F(x)âŠ— ð’ŸF(y)âŸ¶F(xâŠ— ð’žy) \mu_{x,y} \;\colon\; F(x) \otimes_{\mathcal{D}} F(y) \longrightarrow F(x \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} y)

    for all x,yâˆˆð’žx,y \in \mathcal{C}

satisfying the following conditions:

  1. (associativity) For all objects x,y,zâˆˆð’žx,y,z \in \mathcal{C} the following diagram commutes

    (F(x)âŠ— ð’ŸF(y))âŠ— ð’ŸF(z) âŸ¶â‰ƒa F(x),F(y),F(z) ð’Ÿ F(x)âŠ— ð’Ÿ(F(y)âŠ— ð’ŸF(z)) Î¼ x,yâŠ—idâ†“ â†“ idâŠ—Î¼ y,z F(xâŠ— ð’žy)âŠ— ð’ŸF(z) F(x)âŠ— ð’Ÿ(F(xâŠ— ð’žy)) Î¼ xâŠ— ð’žy,zâ†“ â†“ Î¼ x,yâŠ— ð’žz F((xâŠ— ð’žy)âŠ— ð’žz) âŸ¶F(a x,y,z ð’ž) F(xâŠ— ð’ž(yâŠ— ð’žz)), \array{ (F(x) \otimes_{\mathcal{D}} F(y)) \otimes_{\mathcal{D}} F(z) &\underoverset{\simeq}{a^{\mathcal{D}}_{F(x),F(y),F(z)}}{\longrightarrow}& F(x) \otimes_{\mathcal{D}}( F(y)\otimes_{\mathcal{D}} F(z) ) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\mu_{x,y} \otimes id}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{id\otimes \mu_{y,z}}} \\ F(x \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} y) \otimes_{\mathcal{D}} F(z) && F(x) \otimes_{\mathcal{D}} ( F(x \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} y) ) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\mu_{x \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} y , z} } }\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\mu_{ x, y \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} z }}} \\ F( ( x \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} y ) \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} z ) &\underset{F(a^{\mathcal{C}}_{x,y,z})}{\longrightarrow}& F( x \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} ( y \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} z ) ) } \,,

    where a ð’ža^{\mathcal{C}} and a ð’Ÿa^{\mathcal{D}} denote the associators of the monoidal categories;

  2. (unitality) For all xâˆˆð’žx \in \mathcal{C} the following diagrams commutes

    1 ð’ŸâŠ— ð’ŸF(x) âŸ¶ÏµâŠ—id F(1 ð’ž)âŠ— ð’ŸF(x) â„“ F(x) ð’Ÿâ†“ â†“ Î¼ 1 ð’ž,x F(x) âŸµF(â„“ x ð’ž) F(1âŠ— ð’žx) \array{ 1_{\mathcal{D}} \otimes_{\mathcal{D}} F(x) &\overset{\epsilon \otimes id}{\longrightarrow}& F(1_{\mathcal{C}}) \otimes_{\mathcal{D}} F(x) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\ell^{\mathcal{D}}_{F(x)}}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\mu_{1_{\mathcal{C}}, x }}} \\ F(x) &\overset{F(\ell^{\mathcal{C}}_x )}{\longleftarrow}& F(1 \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} x ) }

    and

    F(x)âŠ— ð’Ÿ1 ð’Ÿ âŸ¶idâŠ—Ïµ F(x)âŠ— ð’ŸF(1 ð’ž) r F(x) ð’Ÿâ†“ â†“ Î¼ x,1 ð’ž F(x) âŸµF(r x ð’ž) F(xâŠ— ð’ž1), \array{ F(x) \otimes_{\mathcal{D}} 1_{\mathcal{D}} &\overset{id \otimes \epsilon }{\longrightarrow}& F(x) \otimes_{\mathcal{D}} F(1_{\mathcal{C}}) \\ {}^{\mathllap{r^{\mathcal{D}}_{F(x)}}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\mu_{x, 1_{\mathcal{C}} }}} \\ F(x) &\overset{F(r^{\mathcal{C}}_x )}{\longleftarrow}& F(x \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} 1 ) } \,,

    where â„“ ð’ž\ell^{\mathcal{C}}, â„“ ð’Ÿ\ell^{\mathcal{D}}, r ð’žr^{\mathcal{C}}, r ð’Ÿr^{\mathcal{D}} denote the left and right unitors of the two monoidal categories, respectively.

If Ïµ\epsilon and alll Î¼ x,y\mu_{x,y} are isomorphisms, then FF is called a strong monoidal functor.

If moreover (ð’ž,âŠ— ð’ž,1 ð’ž)(\mathcal{C},\otimes_{\mathcal{C}}, 1_{\mathcal{C}}) and (ð’Ÿ,âŠ— ð’Ÿ,1 ð’Ÿ)(\mathcal{D},\otimes_{\mathcal{D}}, 1_{\mathcal{D}} ) are equipped with the structure of braided monoidal categories (def. 19) with braidings Ï„ ð’ž\tau^{\mathcal{C}} and Ï„ ð’Ÿ\tau^{\mathcal{D}}, respectively, then the lax monoidal functor FF is called a braided monoidal functor if in addition the following diagram commutes for all objects x,yâˆˆð’žx,y \in \mathcal{C}

F(x)âŠ— ð’žF(y) âŸ¶Ï„ F(x),F(y) ð’Ÿ F(y)âŠ— ð’ŸF(x) Î¼ x,yâ†“ â†“ Î¼ y,x F(xâŠ— ð’žy) âŸ¶F(Ï„ x,y ð’ž) F(yâŠ— ð’žx). \array{ F(x) \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} F(y) &\overset{\tau^{\mathcal{D}}_{F(x), F(y)}}{\longrightarrow}& F(y) \otimes_{\mathcal{D}} F(x) \\ {}^{\mathllap{\mu_{x,y}}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\mu_{y,x}}} \\ F(x \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} y ) &\underset{F(\tau^{\mathcal{C}}_{x,y} )}{\longrightarrow}& F( y \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} x ) } \,.

A homomorphism f:(F 1,Î¼ 1,Ïµ 1)âŸ¶(F 2,Î¼ 2,Ïµ 2)f\;\colon\; (F_1,\mu_1, \epsilon_1) \longrightarrow (F_2, \mu_2, \epsilon_2) between two (braided) lax monoidal functors is a monoidal natural transformation, in that it is a natural transformation f x:F 1(x)âŸ¶F 2(x)f_x \;\colon\; F_1(x) \longrightarrow F_2(x) of the underlying functors

compatible with the product and the unit in that the following diagrams commute for all objects x,yâˆˆð’žx,y \in \mathcal{C}:

F 1(x)âŠ— ð’ŸF 1(y) âŸ¶f(x)âŠ— ð’Ÿf(y) F 2(x)âŠ— ð’ŸF 2(y) (Î¼ 1) x,yâ†“ â†“ (Î¼ 2) x,y F 1(xâŠ— ð’žy) âŸ¶f(xâŠ— ð’žy) F 2(xâŠ— ð’žy) \array{ F_1(x) \otimes_{\mathcal{D}} F_1(y) &\overset{f(x)\otimes_{\mathcal{D}} f(y)}{\longrightarrow}& F_2(x) \otimes_{\mathcal{D}} F_2(y) \\ {}^{\mathllap{(\mu_1)_{x,y}}}\downarrow && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{(\mu_2)_{x,y}}} \\ F_1(x\otimes_{\mathcal{C}} y) &\underset{f(x \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} y ) }{\longrightarrow}& F_2(x \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} y) }

and

1 ð’Ÿ Ïµ 1â†™ â†˜ Ïµ 2 F 1(1 ð’ž) âŸ¶f(1 ð’ž) F 2(1 ð’ž). \array{ && 1_{\mathcal{D}} \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\epsilon_1}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{\epsilon_2}} \\ F_1(1_{\mathcal{C}}) &&\underset{f(1_{\mathcal{C}})}{\longrightarrow}&& F_2(1_{\mathcal{C}}) } \,.

We write MonFun(ð’ž,ð’Ÿ)MonFun(\mathcal{C},\mathcal{D}) for the resulting category of lax monoidal functors between monoidal categories ð’ž\mathcal{C} and ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D}, similarly BraidMonFun(ð’ž,ð’Ÿ)BraidMonFun(\mathcal{C},\mathcal{D}) for the category of braided monoidal functors between braided monoidal categories, and SymMonFun(ð’ž,ð’Ÿ)SymMonFun(\mathcal{C},\mathcal{D}) for the category of braided monoidal functors between symmetric monoidal categories.

Remark

In the literature the term â€œmonoidal functorâ€ often refers by default to what in def. 22 is called a strong monoidal functor. But for the purpose of the discussion of functors with smash product below, it is crucial to admit the generality of lax monoidal functors.

If (ð’ž,âŠ— ð’ž,1 ð’ž)(\mathcal{C},\otimes_{\mathcal{C}}, 1_{\mathcal{C}}) and (ð’Ÿ,âŠ— ð’Ÿ,1 ð’Ÿ)(\mathcal{D},\otimes_{\mathcal{D}}, 1_{\mathcal{D}} ) are symmetric monoidal categories (def. 20) then a braided monoidal functor (def. 22) between them is often called a symmetric monoidal functor.

Proposition

For ð’žâŸ¶Fð’ŸâŸ¶Gâ„°\mathcal{C} \overset{F}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{D} \overset{G}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{E} two composable lax monoidal functors (def. 22) between monoidal categories, then their composite Fâˆ˜GF \circ G becomes a lax monoidal functor with structure morphisms

Ïµ Gâˆ˜F:1 â„°âŸ¶Ïµ GG(1 ð’Ÿ)âŸ¶G(Ïµ F)G(F(1 ð’ž)) \epsilon^{G\circ F} \;\colon\; 1_{\mathcal{E}} \overset{\epsilon^G}{\longrightarrow} G(1_{\mathcal{D}}) \overset{G(\epsilon^F)}{\longrightarrow} G(F(1_{\mathcal{C}}))

and

Î¼ c 1,c 2 Gâˆ˜F:G(F(c 1))âŠ— â„°G(F(c 2))âŸ¶Î¼ F(c 1),F(c 2) GG(F(c 1)âŠ— ð’ŸF(c 2))âŸ¶G(Î¼ c 1,c 2 F)G(F(c 1âŠ— ð’žc 2)). \mu^{G \circ F}_{c_1,c_2} \;\colon\; G(F(c_1)) \otimes_{\mathcal{E}} G(F(c_2)) \overset{\mu^{G}_{F(c_1), F(c_2)}}{\longrightarrow} G( F(c_1) \otimes_{\mathcal{D}} F(c_2) ) \overset{G(\mu^F_{c_1,c_2})}{\longrightarrow} G(F( c_1 \otimes_{\mathcal{C}} c_2 )) \,.

Enriched categories

The plain definition of categories in Def. 1 is phrased in terms of sets. Via Example 1 this assigns a special role to the category Set of all sets, as the â€œbaseâ€ on top, or the â€œcosmosâ€ inside which category theory takes place. For instance, the fact that hom-sets in a plain category are indeed sets, is what makes the hom-functor (Example 8) take values in Set, and this, in turn, governs the form of the all-important Yoneda lemma (Prop. 1) and Yoneda embedding (Prop. 2) as statements about presheaves of sets (Example 14).

At the same time, category theory witnesses the utility of abstracting away from concrete choices to their abstract properties that are actually used in constructions. This makes it natural to ask if one could replace the category Set by some other category ð’±\mathcal{V} which could similarly serve as a â€œcosmosâ€ inside which category theory may be developed.

Indeed, such ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category theory (see Example 25 below for the terminology) exists, beginning with the concept of ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 24 below) and from there directly paralleling, hence generalizing, plain category theory, as long as one assumes the â€œcosmosâ€ category ð’±\mathcal{V} to share a minimum of abstract properties with Set (Def. 23 below).

This turns out to be most useful. In fact, the perspective of enriched categories is helpful already when ð’±=\mathcal{V} = Set, in which case it reproduces plain category theory (Example 24 below), for instance in that it puts the (co)limits of the special form of (co)ends (Def. 32 below) to the forefront (discussed below).

\,

Definition

(cosmos)

A BÃ©nabou cosmos for enriched category theory, or just cosmos, for short, is a symmetric (Def. 20) closed monoidal category (Def. 21) ð’±\mathcal{V} which has all limits and colimits.

Example

(examples of cosmoi for enriched category theory)

The following are examples of cosmoi (Def. 23):

  1. Set (Def. 1) equipped with its cartesian closed category-structure (Example 18)

  2. Grpd (Def. 7) equipped with its cartesian closed category-structure (Example 19).

Example

underlying set of an object in a cosmos

Let ð’±\mathcal{V} be a cosmos (Def. 23), with 1âˆˆð’±1 \in \mathcal{V} its tensor unit (Def. 18). Then the hom-functor (Def. 8) out of 11

Hom ð’±(1,âˆ’):ð’±âŸ¶Set Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1,-) \;\colon\; \mathcal{V} \longrightarrow Set

admits the structure of a lax monoidal functor (Def. 22) to Set, with the latter regarded with its cartesian monoidal structure from Example 18.

Given Vâˆˆð’±V \in \mathcal{V}, we call

Hom ð’±(1,V)âˆˆSet Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1,V) \;\in\; Set

also the underlying set of VV.

Proof

Take the monoidal transformations (eqâ€œMonoidalComponentsOfMonoidalFunctor) to be

Hom ð’±(1,V 1)Ã—Hom ð’±(1,V 2)âŸ¶Hom ð’±(1,V 1âŠ—V 2) (1â†’f 1V 1,1â†’f 2V 2) â†¦ (1â†’â‰ƒ1âŠ—1âŸ¶f 1âŠ—f 2V 1âŠ—V 2) \array{ Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1, V_1) \times Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1, V_2) \longrightarrow Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1, V_1 \otimes V_2) \\ \big( 1 \overset{f_1}{\to} V_1\;,\; 1 \overset{f_2}{\to} V_2 \big) &\mapsto& \big( 1 \overset{\simeq}{\to} 1 \otimes 1 \overset{f_1 \otimes f_2}{\longrightarrow} V_1 \otimes V_2 \big) }

and take the unit transformation (22)

* âŸ¶ Hom ð’±(1,1) \array{ \ast &\longrightarrow& Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1,1) }

to pick id 1âˆˆHom ð’±(1,1)id_1 \in Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1,1).

Example

(underlying set of internal hom is hom-set)*

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), let X,YâˆˆObj ð’±X,Y \in Obj_{\mathcal{V}} be two objects. Then the underlying set (Def. 22) of their internal hom [X,Y]âˆˆð’±[X,Y] \in \mathcal{V} (Def. 21) is the hom-set (Def. 1):

â„‹â„´ð“‚ ð’±(1,[X,Y])â‰ƒHom ð’±(X,Y). \mathcal{Hom}_{\mathcal{V}}\left( 1, [X,Y]\right) \;\simeq\; Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(X,Y) \,.

This identification is the adjunction isomorphism (9) for the internal hom adjunction (21) followed composed with a unitor (Def. 18).

Definition

(enriched category)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category ð’ž\mathcal{C} is:

  1. a class Obj ð’žObj_{\mathcal{C}}, called the class of objects;

  2. for each a,bâˆˆObj ð’ža, b\in Obj_{\mathcal{C}}, an object

    ð’ž(a,b)âˆˆð’±, \mathcal{C}(a,b)\in \mathcal{V} \,,

    called the ð’±\mathcal{V}-object of morphisms between aa and bb;

  3. for each a,b,câˆˆObj(ð’ž)a,b,c\in Obj(\mathcal{C}) a morphism in ð’±\mathcal{V}

    âˆ˜ a,b,c:ð’ž(a,b)Ã—ð’ž(b,c)âŸ¶ð’ž(a,c) \circ_{a,b,c} \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(a,b)\times \mathcal{C}(b,c) \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}(a,c)

    out of the tensor product of hom-objects, called the composition operation;

  4. for each aâˆˆObj(ð’ž)a \in Obj(\mathcal{C}) a morphism Id a:*â†’ð’ž(a,a)Id_a \colon \ast \to \mathcal{C}(a,a), called the identity morphism on aa

such that the composition is associative and unital.

If the class Obj ð’žObj_{\mathcal{C}} happens to be a set (hence a small set instead of a proper class) then we say the ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category ð’ž\mathcal{C} is small, as in Def. 3.

Example

(Set-enriched categories are plain categories)

An enriched category (Def. 24) over the cosmos ð’±=\mathcal{V} = Set, as in Example 21, is the same as a plain category (Def. 1).

Example

(underlying category of an enriched category)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 24).

Using the lax monoidal structure (Def. 22) on the hom functor (Example 22)

Hom ð’±(1,âˆ’):ð’±âŸ¶Set Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1,-) \;\colon\; \mathcal{V} \longrightarrow Set

out of the tensor unit 1âˆˆð’ž1 \in \mathcal{C} this induces a Set-enriched category |ð’ž|\vert \mathcal{C}\vert with hence an ordinary category (Example 24), with

  • Obj |ð’ž|â‰”Obj ð’žObj_{\vert \mathcal{C}\vert} \;\coloneqq\; Obj_{\mathcal{C}};

  • Hom |ð’ž|(X,Y)â‰”Hom ð’±(1,ð’ž(X,Y))Hom_{\vert \mathcal{C}\vert}( X, Y ) \;\coloneqq\; Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(1, \mathcal{C}(X,Y)).

It is in this sense that ð’ž\mathcal{C} is a plain category |ð’ž|{\vert \mathcal{C}\vert} equipped with extra structure, and hence an â€œenriched categoryâ€.

The archetypical example is ð’±\mathcal{V} itself:

Example

(ð’±\mathcal{V} as a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category)

Evert cosmos ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Def. 23) canonically obtains the structure of a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category, def. 24:

the hom-objects are the internal homs

ð“‹(X,Y)â‰”[X,Y] \mathcal{v}(X,Y) \coloneqq [X,Y]

and with composition

[X,Y]Ã—[Y,Z]âŸ¶[X,Z] [X,Y] \times [Y,Z] \longrightarrow [X,Z]

given by the adjunct under the (Cartesian productâŠ£\dashv internal hom)-adjunction of the evaluation morphisms

XâŠ—[XmY]âŠ—[Y,Z]âŸ¶(ev,id)YâŠ—[Y,Z]âŸ¶evZ. X \otimes [XmY] \otimes [Y,Z] \overset{(ev, id)}{\longrightarrow} Y \otimes [Y,Z] \overset{ev}{\longrightarrow} Z \,.

The usual construction on categories, such as that of opposite categories (Def. 5) and product categories (Def. 6) have evident enriched analogs

Definition

(enriched opposite category and product category)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos, let ð’ž,ð’Ÿ\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D} be ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 24).

  1. The opposite enriched category ð’ž op\mathcal{C}^{op} is the enriched category with the same objects as ð’ž\mathcal{C}, with hom-objects

    ð’ž op(X,Y)â‰”ð’ž(Y,X) \mathcal{C}^{op}(X,Y) \coloneqq \mathcal{C}(Y,X)

    and with composition given by braiding (20) followed by the composition in ð’ž\mathcal{C}:

    ð’ž op(X,Y)âŠ—ð’ž op(Y,Z)=ð’ž(Y,X)âŠ—ð’ž(Z,Y)âŸ¶â‰ƒÏ„ð’ž(Z,Y)âŠ—ð’ž(Y,X)âŸ¶âˆ˜ Z,Y,Xð’ž(Z,X)=ð’ž op(X,Z). \mathcal{C}^{op}(X,Y) \otimes \mathcal{C}^{op}(Y,Z) = \mathcal{C}(Y,X) \otimes \mathcal{C}(Z,Y) \underoverset{\simeq}{\tau}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{C}(Z,Y) \otimes \mathcal{C}(Y,X) \overset{\circ_{Z,Y,X}}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{C}(Z,X) = \mathcal{C}^{op}(X,Z) \,.

  2. the enriched product category ð’žÃ—ð’Ÿ\mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{D} is the enriched category whose objects are pairs of objects (c,d)(c,d) with câˆˆð’žc \in \mathcal{C} and dâˆˆð’Ÿd\in \mathcal{D}, whose hom-spaces are the tensor product of the separate hom objects

    (ð’žÃ—ð’Ÿ)((c 1,d 1),(c 2,d 2))â‰”ð’ž(c 1,c 2)âŠ—ð’Ÿ(d 1,d 2) (\mathcal{C}\times \mathcal{D})((c_1,d_1),\;(c_2,d_2) ) \coloneqq \mathcal{C}(c_1,c_2)\otimes \mathcal{D}(d_1,d_2)

    and whose composition operation is the braiding (20) followed by the tensor product of the separate composition operations:

    (ð’žÃ—ð’Ÿ)((c 1,d 1),(c 2,d 2))âŠ—(ð’žÃ—ð’Ÿ)((c 2,d 2),(c 3,d 3)) =â†“ (ð’ž(c 1,c 2)âŠ—ð’Ÿ(d 1,d 2))âŠ—(ð’ž(c 2,c 3)âŠ—ð’Ÿ(d 2,d 3)) â†“ â‰ƒ Ï„ (ð’ž(c 1,c 2)âŠ—ð’ž(c 2,c 3))âŠ—(ð’Ÿ(d 1,d 2)âŠ—ð’Ÿ(d 2,d 3)) âŸ¶(âˆ˜ c 1,c 2,c 3)âŠ—(âˆ˜ d 1,d 2,d 3) ð’ž(c 1,c 3)âŠ—ð’Ÿ(d 1,d 3) â†“ = (ð’žÃ—ð’Ÿ)((c 1,d 1),(c 3,d 3)). \array{ (\mathcal{C}\times \mathcal{D})((c_1,d_1), \; (c_2,d_2)) \otimes (\mathcal{C}\times \mathcal{D})((c_2,d_2), \; (c_3,d_3)) \\ {}^{\mathllap{=}}\downarrow \\ \left(\mathcal{C}(c_1,c_2) \otimes \mathcal{D}(d_1,d_2)\right) \otimes \left(\mathcal{C}(c_2,c_3) \otimes \mathcal{D}(d_2,d_3)\right) \\ \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\tau}}_{\mathrlap{\simeq}} \\ \left(\mathcal{C}(c_1,c_2) \otimes \mathcal{C}(c_2,c_3)\right) \otimes \left( \mathcal{D}(d_1,d_2) \otimes \mathcal{D}(d_2,d_3)\right) &\overset{ (\circ_{c_1,c_2,c_3}) \otimes (\circ_{d_1,d_2,d_3}) }{\longrightarrow} & \mathcal{C}(c_1,c_3) \otimes \mathcal{D}(d_1,d_3) \\ && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{=}} \\ && (\mathcal{C}\times \mathcal{D})((c_1,d_1),\; (c_3,d_3)) } \,.
Definition

(enriched functor)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), let ð’ž\mathcal{C} and ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be two ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 24).

A ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched functor from ð’ž\mathcal{C} to ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D}

F:ð’žâŸ¶ð’Ÿ F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}

is

  1. a function

    F Obj:Obj ð’žâŸ¶Obj ð’Ÿ F_{Obj} \;\colon\; Obj_{\mathcal{C}} \longrightarrow Obj_{\mathcal{D}}

    of objects;

  2. for each a,bâˆˆObj ð’ža,b \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}} a morphism in ð’±\mathcal{V}

    F a,b:ð’ž(a,b)âŸ¶ð’Ÿ(F 0(a),F 0(b)) F_{a,b} \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(a,b) \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}(F_0(a), F_0(b))

    between hom-objects

such that this preserves composition and identity morphisms in the evident sense.

Example

(enriched hom-functor)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 24). Then there is a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched functor out of the enriched product category of ð’ž\mathcal{C} with its enriched opposite category (Def. 25)

ð’ž(âˆ’,âˆ’):ð’ž opÃ—ð’žâŸ¶ð’± \mathcal{C}(-,-) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

to ð’±\mathcal{V}, regarded as a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Example 26), which sends a pair of objects X,Yâˆˆð’žX,Y \in \mathcal{C} to the hom-object ð’ž(X,Y)âˆˆð’±\mathcal{C}(X,Y) \in \mathcal{V}, and which acts on morphisms by composition in the evident way.

Example

(enriched presheaves)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 24). Then a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched functor (Def. 26)

F:ð’žâŸ¶ð’± F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

to the archetypical ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category from Example 26 is:

  1. an object F aâˆˆObj ð’±F_a \in Obj_{\mathcal{V}} for each object aâˆˆObj ð’ža \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}};

  2. a morphism in ð’±\mathcal{V} of the form

    F aâŠ—ð’ž(a,b)âŸ¶F b F_a \otimes \mathcal{C}(a,b) \longrightarrow F_b

    for all pairs of objects a,bâˆˆObj(ð’ž)a,b \in Obj(\mathcal{C})

    (this is the adjunct of F a,bF_{a,b} under the adjunction (21) on ð’±\mathcal{V})

such that composition is respected, in the evident sense.

For every object câˆˆð’žc \in \mathcal{C}, there is an enriched representable functor, denoted

y(c)â‰”ð’ž(c,âˆ’) y(c) \;\coloneqq\; \mathcal{C}(c,-)

(where on the right we have the enriched hom-functor from Example 27)

which sends objects to

y(c)(d)=ð’ž(c,d)âˆˆð’± y(c)(d) = \mathcal{C}(c,d) \in \mathcal{V}

and whose action on morphisms is, under the above identification, just the composition operation in ð’ž\mathcal{C}.

More generally, the following situation will be of interest:

Example

(enriched functor on enriched product category with opposite category)

An ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched functor (Def. 26) into ð’±\mathcal{V} (Example 26) out of an enriched product category (Def. 25)

F:ð’žÃ—ð’ŸâŸ¶ð’± F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{D} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

(an â€œenriched bifunctorâ€) has component morphisms of the form

F (c 1,d 1),(c 2,d 2):ð’ž(c 1,c 2)âŠ—ð’Ÿ(d 1,d 2)âŸ¶[F 0((c 1,d 1)),F 0((c 2,d 2))]. F_{(c_1,d_1),(c_2,d_2)} \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c_1,c_2) \otimes \mathcal{D}(d_1,d_2) \longrightarrow \big[ F_0((c_1,d_1)),F_0((c_2,d_2)) \big] \,.

By functoriality and under passing to adjuncts (Def. 10) under (21) this is equivalent to two commuting actions

Ï c 1,c 2(d):ð’ž(c 1,c 2)âŠ—F 0((c 1,d))âŸ¶F 0((c 2,d)) \rho_{c_1,c_2}(d) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c_1,c_2) \otimes F_0((c_1,d)) \longrightarrow F_0((c_2,d))

and

Ï d 1,d 2(c):ð’Ÿ(d 1,d 2)âŠ—F 0((c,d 1))âŸ¶F 0((c,d 2)). \rho_{d_1,d_2}(c) \;\colon\; \mathcal{D}(d_1,d_2) \otimes F_0((c,d_1)) \longrightarrow F_0((c,d_2)) \,.

In the special case of a functor out of the enriched product category of some ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category ð’ž\mathcal{C} with its enriched opposite category (def. 25)

F:ð’ž opÃ—ð’žâŸ¶ð’± F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

then this takes the form of a â€œpullback actionâ€ in the first variable

Ï c 2,c 1(d):ð’ž(c 1,c 2)âŠ—F 0((c 2,d))âŸ¶F 0((c 1,d)) \rho_{c_2,c_1}(d) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c_1,c_2) \otimes F_0((c_2,d)) \longrightarrow F_0((c_1,d))

and a â€œpushforward actionâ€ in the second variable

Ï d 1,d 2(c):ð’ž(d 1,d 2)âŠ—F 0((c,d 1))âŸ¶F 0((c,d 2)). \rho_{d_1,d_2}(c) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(d_1,d_2) \otimes F_0((c,d_1)) \longrightarrow F_0((c,d_2)) \,.
Definition

(enriched natural transformation)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), let ð’ž\mathcal{C} and ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be two ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 24) and let

ð’žâŸ¶GâŸ¶Fð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{G}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}} {} \mathcal{D}

be two ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched functors (Def. 26) from ð’ž\mathcal{C} to ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D}.

Then a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched natural transformation

ð’žAAâ‡“Î·AAâŸ¶GâŸ¶Fð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{G}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{F}{\longrightarrow}} {\phantom{AA}\Downarrow{\mathrlap{\eta}}\phantom{AA}} \mathcal{D}

is

  • for each câˆˆObj ð’žc \in Obj_{\mathcal{C}} a choice of morphism

    Î· c:IâŸ¶ð’Ÿ(F(c),G(c)) \eta_c \;\colon\; I \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}(F(c),G(c))

    such that for each pair of objects c,dâˆˆð’žc,d \in \mathcal{C} the two morphisms (in ð’±\mathcal{V})

(24)Î· dâˆ˜F(âˆ’):ð’ž(c,d)â‰ƒrð’ž(c,d)âŠ—IâŸ¶G c,dâŠ—Î· cð’Ÿ(G(c),G(d))âŠ—ð’Ÿ(F(c),G(c))âŸ¶âˆ˜ F(c),G(c),G(d)ð’Ÿ(F(c),G(d)) \eta_d \circ F(-) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c,d) \overset{r}{\simeq} \mathcal{C}(c,d) \otimes I \overset{ G_{c,d} \otimes \eta_c }{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{D}(G(c),G(d)) \otimes \mathcal{D}( F(c), G(c) ) \overset{\circ_{F(c), G(c), G(d)}}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{D}(F(c), G(d))

and

(25)G(âˆ’)âˆ˜Î· c:ð’ž(c,d)â‰ƒâ„“IâŠ—ð’ž(c,d)âŸ¶Î· dâŠ—F c,dð’Ÿ(F(d),G(d))âŠ—ð’Ÿ(F(c),F(d))âŸ¶âˆ˜ F(c),F(d),G(d)ð’Ÿ(F(c),G(d)) G(-) \circ \eta_c \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}(c,d) \overset{\ell}{\simeq} I \otimes \mathcal{C}(c,d) \overset{ \eta_d \otimes F_{c,d} }{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{D}(F(d), G(d)) \otimes \mathcal{D}(F(c), F(d)) \overset{\circ_{F(c),F(d), G(d)}}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{D}(F(c), G(d))

agree.

Example

(functor category of enriched functors)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23) let ð’ž\mathcal{C}, ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be two ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 24). Then there is a category (Def. 1) of enriched functors (Def. 26), to be denoted

[ð’ž,ð’Ÿ] [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}]

whose objects are the enriched functors ð’žâ†’Fð’Ÿ\mathcal{C} \overset{F}{\to} \mathcal{D} and whose morphisms are the enriched natural transformations between these (Def. 27).

In the case that ð’±=\mathcal{V} = Set, via Def. 21, with SetSet-enriched categories identified with plain categories via Example 24, this coincides with the functor category from Example 13.

Notice that, at this point, [ð’ž,ð’Ÿ][\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}] is a plain category, not itself a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category, unless ð’±=\mathcal{V} = Set. But it may be enhanced to one, this is Def. 33 below.

Definition

(tensoring and powering of enriched presheaves)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category, def. 24, with [ð’ž,ð’±][\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] its functor category of enriched functors (Example 30).

  1. Define a functor

    (âˆ’)â‹…(âˆ’):[ð’ž,ð’±]Ã—ð’±âŸ¶[ð’ž,ð’±] (-)\cdot(-) \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] \times \mathcal{V} \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]

    by forming objectwise tensor products

    Fâ‹…X:câ†¦F(c)âŠ—X. F \cdot X \;\colon\; c \mapsto F(c) \otimes X \,.

    This is called the tensoring of [ð’ž,ð’±][\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] over ð’±\mathcal{V}.

  2. Define a functor

    (âˆ’) (âˆ’):ð’± opÃ—[ð’ž,ð’±]âŸ¶[ð’ž,ð’±] (-)^{(-)} \;\colon\; \mathcal{V}^{op} \times [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]

    by forming objectwise internal homs (Def. 21)

    F X:câ†¦[X,F(c)]. F^X \;\colon\; c \mapsto [X,F(c)] \,.

    This is called the powering of [ð’ž,ð’±][\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] over ð’±\mathcal{V}.

There is now the following evident generalization of the concept of adjoint functors (Def. 10) from plain category theory to enriched category theory:

Definition

(enriched adjunction)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), let ð’ž\mathcal{C}, ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be two ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 24). Then an adjoint pair of ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched functors or enriched adjunction

ð’žâŠ¥âŸ¶RâŸµLð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{D}

is a pair of ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched functors (Def. 26), as shown, such that there is a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched natural isomorphism (Def. 27) between enriched hom-functors (Def. 27) of the form

(26)ð’ž(L(âˆ’),âˆ’)â‰ƒð’Ÿ(âˆ’,R(âˆ’)). \mathcal{C}(L(-),-) \;\simeq\; \mathcal{D}(-,R(-)) \,.
Definition

(enriched equivalence of categories)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), let ð’ž\mathcal{C}, ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be two ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 24). Then an equivalence of enriched categories

ð’žAAâ‰ƒAAâŸ¶RâŸµLð’Ÿ \array{ \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{R}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{L}{\longleftarrow}} {\phantom{AA} \simeq \phantom{AA}} \mathcal{D} }

is a pair of ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched functors back and forth, as shown (Def. 26), together with ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched natural isomorphisms (Def. 27) between their composition and the identity functors:

id ð’Ÿâ‡’â‰ƒRâˆ˜LAAAandAAALâˆ˜Râ‡’â‰ƒid ð’ž. id_{\mathcal{D}} \overset{\simeq}{\Rightarrow} R \circ L \phantom{AAA} \text{and} \phantom{AAA} L \circ R \overset{\simeq}{\Rightarrow} id_{\mathcal{C}} \,.

Universal constructions

What makes category theory be theory, as opposed to just a language, is the concept of universal constructions. This refers to the idea of objects with a prescribed property which are universal with this property, in that they â€œknow aboutâ€ or â€œsubsumeâ€ every other object with that same kind of property. Category theory allows to make precise what this means, and then to discover and prove theorems about it.

Universal constructions are all over the place in mathematics. Iteratively finding the universal constructions in a prescribed situation essentially amounts to systematically following the unravelling of the given situation or problem or theory that one is studying.

There are several different formulations of the concept of universal constructions, discussed below:

  • Limits and colimits

  • Ends and coends

  • Left and right Kan extensions

But these three kinds of constructions all turn out to be special cases of each other, hence they really reflect different perspectives on a single topic of universal constructions. In fact, all three are also special cases of the concept of adjunction (Def. 10), thus re-amplifying that category theory is really the theory of adjunctions and hence if we follow (Lambek 82)of duality.

\,

Limits and colimits

Definition

(limit and colimit)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a small category (Def. 3), and let ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be any category (Def. 1). In this case one also says that a functor

F:ð’žâŸ¶ð’Ÿ F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}

is a diagram of shape ð’ž\mathcal{C} in ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D}.

Recalling the functor category (Example 13) [ð’ž,ð’Ÿ][\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}], there is the constant diagram-functor

const:ð’ŸâŸ¶[ð’ž,ð’Ÿ] const \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}]

which sends an object Xâˆˆð’ŸX \in \mathcal{D} to the functor that sends every câˆˆð’žc \in \mathcal{C} to XX, and every morphism in ð’ž\mathcal{C} to the identity morphism on XX. Accordingly, every morphism in ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} is sent by constconst to the natural transformation (Def. 9) all whose components are equal to that morphism.

Now:

  1. if constconst has a right adjoint (Def. 10), this is called the construction of forming the limiting cone of ð’ž\mathcal{C}-shaped diagrams in ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D}, or just limit (or inverse limit) for short, and denoted

    limâŸµð’ž:[ð’ž,ð’Ÿ]âŸ¶ð’Ÿ \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}] \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}

  2. if constconst has a left adjoint (Def. 10), this is called the construction of forming the colimiting cocone of ð’ž\mathcal{C}-shaped diagrams in ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D}, or just colimit (or direct limit) for short, and denoted

    limâŸ¶ð’ž:[ð’ž,ð’Ÿ]âŸ¶ð’Ÿ \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}] \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}
[ð’ž,ð’Ÿ]âŸ¶AAlimâŸ¶ð’žAA âŸµAAconstAA âŸ¶AAlimâŸµð’žAAð’Ÿ. [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D}] \array{ \overset{ \phantom{AA}\underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \phantom{AA} }{\longrightarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AA} const \phantom{AA} }{ \longleftarrow } \\ \overset{ \phantom{AA} \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} \phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow} } \mathcal{D} \,.
Proposition

(hom-functor preserves limits)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a category and write

Hom ð’ž:ð’ž opÃ—ð’žâŸ¶Set Hom_{\mathcal{C}} \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow Set

for its hom-functor. This preserves limits (Def. 31) in both its arguments (recalling that a limit in the opposite category ð’ž op\mathcal{C}^{op} is a colimit in ð’ž\mathcal{C}).

More in detail, let X â€¢:â„âŸ¶ð’žX_\bullet \colon \mathcal{I} \longrightarrow \mathcal{C} be a diagram. Then:

  1. If the limit limâŸµ iX i\underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i X_i exists in ð’ž\mathcal{C} then for all Yâˆˆð’žY \in \mathcal{C} there is a natural isomorphism

    Hom ð’ž(Y,limâŸµ iX i)â‰ƒlimâŸµ i(Hom ð’ž(Y,X i)), Hom_{\mathcal{C}}\left(Y, \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i X_i \right) \simeq \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i \left( Hom_{\mathcal{C}}\left( Y, X_i \right) \right) \,,

    where on the right we have the limit over the diagram of hom-sets given by

    Hom ð’ž(Y,âˆ’)âˆ˜X:â„âŸ¶Xð’žâŸ¶Hom ð’ž(Y,âˆ’)Set. Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Y,-) \circ X \;\colon\; \mathcal{I} \overset{X}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{C} \overset{Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(Y,-) }{\longrightarrow} Set\,.

  2. If the colimit limâŸ¶ iX i\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_i X_i exists in ð’ž\mathcal{C} then for all Yâˆˆð’žY \in \mathcal{C} there is a natural isomorphism

    Hom ð’ž(limâŸ¶ iX i,Y)â‰ƒlimâŸµ i(Hom ð’ž(X i,Y)), Hom_{\mathcal{C}}\left(\underset{\longrightarrow}{\lim}_i X_i ,Y\right) \simeq \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_i \left( Hom_{\mathcal{C}}\left( X_i , Y\right) \right) \,,

    where on the right we have the limit over the diagram of hom-sets given by

    Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,Y)âˆ˜X:â„ opâŸ¶Xð’ž opâŸ¶Hom ð’ž(âˆ’,Y)Set. Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,Y) \circ X \;\colon\; \mathcal{I}^{op} \overset{X}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{C}^{op} \overset{Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(-,Y) }{\longrightarrow} Set\,.
Proof

We give the proof of the first statement. The proof of the second statement is formally dual.

First observe that, by the very definition of limiting cones, maps out of some YY into them are in natural bijection with the set Cones(Y,X â€¢)Cones\left(Y, X_\bullet \right) of cones over the diagram X â€¢X_\bullet with tip YY:

Hom(Y,limâŸµ iX i)â‰ƒCones(Y,X â€¢). Hom\left( Y, \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_{i} X_i \right) \;\simeq\; Cones\left( Y, X_\bullet \right) \,.

Hence it remains to show that there is also a natural bijection like so:

Cones(Y,X â€¢)â‰ƒlimâŸµ i(Hom(Y,X i)). Cones\left( Y, X_\bullet \right) \;\simeq\; \underset{\longleftarrow}{\lim}_{i} \left( Hom(Y,X_i) \right) \,.

Now, again by the very definition of limiting cones, a single element in the limit on the right is equivalently a cone of the form

{ * const p iâ†™ â†˜ const p j Hom(Y,X i) âŸ¶X Î±âˆ˜(âˆ’) Hom(Y,X j)} i,jâˆˆObj(â„),Î±âˆˆHom â„(i,j). \left\{ \array{ && \ast \\ & {}^{\mathllap{const_{p_i}}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{const_{p_j}}} \\ Hom(Y,X_i) && \underset{X_\alpha \circ (-)}{\longrightarrow} && Hom(Y,X_j) } \right\}_{i, j \in Obj(\mathcal{I}), \alpha \in Hom_{\mathcal{I}}(i,j) } \,.

This is equivalently for each object iâˆˆâ„i \in \mathcal{I} a choice of morphism p i:Yâ†’X ip_i \colon Y \to X_i , such that for each pair of objects i,jâˆˆâ„i,j \in \mathcal{I} and each Î±âˆˆHom â„(i,j)\alpha \in Hom_{\mathcal{I}}(i,j) we have X Î±âˆ˜p i=p jX_\alpha \circ p_i = p_j. And indeed, this is precisely the characterization of an element in the set Cones(Y,X â€¢}) Cones\left( Y, X_\bullet\} \right).

Example

(initial and terminal object in terms of adjunction)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a category (Def. 1).

  1. The following are equivalent:

    1. ð’ž\mathcal{C} has a terminal object;

    2. the unique functor ð’žâ†’*\mathcal{C} \to \ast (Def. 6) to the terminal category (Example 3) has a right adjoint (Def. 10)

      *âŠ¥âŸ¶âŸµð’ž \ast \underoverset {\underset{}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{C}

    Under this equivalence, the terminal object is identified with the image under the right adjoint of the unique object of the terminal category.

  2. Dually, the following are equivalent:

    1. ð’ž\mathcal{C} has an initial object;

    2. the unique functor ð’žâ†’*\mathcal{C} \to \ast to the terminal category has a left adjoint

      ð’žâŠ¥âŸ¶âŸµ* \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \ast

    Under this equivalence, the initial object is identified with the image under the left adjoint of the unique object of the terminal category.

Proof

Since the unique hom-set in the terminal category is the singleton, the hom-isomorphism (9) characterizing the adjoint functors is directly the universal property of an initial object in ð’ž\mathcal{C}

Hom ð’ž(L(*),X)â‰ƒHom *(*,R(X))=* Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( L(\ast) , X ) \;\simeq\; Hom_{\ast}( \ast, R(X) ) = \ast

or of a terminal object

Hom ð’ž(X,R(*))â‰ƒHom *(L(X),*)=*, Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( X , R(\ast) ) \;\simeq\; Hom_{\ast}( L(X), \ast ) = \ast \,,

respectively.

Proposition

(left adjoints preserve colimits and right adjoints preserve limits)

Let (LâŠ£R):ð’Ÿâ†’ð’ž(L \dashv R) \colon \mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{C} be a pair of adjoint functors (Def. 10). Then

  • LL preserves all colimits (Def. 31) that exist in ð’ž\mathcal{C},

  • RR preserves all limits (Def. 31) in ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D}.

Proof

Let y:Iâ†’ð’Ÿy : I \to \mathcal{D} be a diagram whose limit lim â† iy i\lim_{\leftarrow_i} y_i exists. Then we have a sequence of natural isomorphisms, natural in xâˆˆCx \in C

Hom ð’ž(x,Rlim â† iy i) â‰ƒHom ð’Ÿ(Lx,lim â† iy i) â‰ƒlim â† iHom ð’Ÿ(Lx,y i) â‰ƒlim â† iHom ð’ž(x,Ry i) â‰ƒHom ð’ž(x,lim â† iRy i), \begin{aligned} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(x, R {\lim_\leftarrow}_i y_i) & \simeq Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L x, {\lim_\leftarrow}_i y_i) \\ & \simeq {\lim_\leftarrow}_i Hom_{\mathcal{D}}(L x, y_i) \\ & \simeq {\lim_\leftarrow}_i Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( x, R y_i) \\ & \simeq Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( x, {\lim_\leftarrow}_i R y_i) \,, \end{aligned}

where we used the hom-isomorphism (9) and the fact that any hom-functor preserves limits (Def. 16). Because this is natural in xx the Yoneda lemma implies that we have an isomorphism

Rlim â† iy iâ‰ƒlim â† iRy i. R {\lim_\leftarrow}_i y_i \simeq {\lim_\leftarrow}_i R y_i \,.

The argument that shows the preservation of colimits by LL is analogous.

Proposition

(limits commute with limits)

Let ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} and ð’Ÿâ€²\mathcal{D}' be small categories (Def. 3) and let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a category (Def. 1) which admits limits (Def. 31) of shape ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} as well as limits of shape ð’Ÿâ€²\mathcal{D}'. Then these limits â€œcommuteâ€ with each other, in that for F:ð’ŸÃ—ð’Ÿâ€²â†’ð’žF \;\colon\; \mathcal{D} \times {\mathcal{D}'} \to \mathcal{C} a functor (hence a diagram of shape the product category), with corresponding adjunct functors (via Example 19)

ð’Ÿâ€²âŸ¶F ð’Ÿ[ð’Ÿ,ð’ž]AAAð’ŸâŸ¶F ð’Ÿâ€²[ð’Ÿâ€²,ð’ž] {\mathcal{D}'} \overset{F_{\mathcal{D}}}{\longrightarrow} [\mathcal{D},\mathcal{C}] \phantom{AAA} {\mathcal{D}} \overset{F_{\mathcal{D}'}}{\longrightarrow} [{\mathcal{D}'}, \mathcal{C}]

we have that the canonical comparison morphism

(27)limFâ‰ƒlim ð’Ÿ(lim ð’Ÿâ€²F ð’Ÿ)â‰ƒlim ð’Ÿâ€²(lim ð’ŸF ð’Ÿâ€²) lim F \simeq lim_{\mathcal{D}} (lim_{\mathcal{D}'} F_{\mathcal{D}} ) \simeq lim_{\mathcal{D}'} (lim_{\mathcal{D}} F_{\mathcal{D}'} )

is an isomorphism.

Proof

Since the limit-construction is the right adjoint functor to the constant diagram-functor, this is a special case of right adjoints preserve limits (Prop. 17).

See limits and colimits by example for what formula (27) says for instance for the special case ð’ž=\mathcal{C} = Set.

Remark

(general non-commutativity of limits with colimits)

In general limits do not commute with colimits. But under a number of special conditions of interest they do. Special cases and concrete examples are discussed at commutativity of limits and colimits.

Ends and coends

For working with enriched categories (Def. 24) , a certain shape of limits/colimits (Def. 31) is particularly relevant: these are called ends and coends (Def. 32 below). We here introduce these and then derive some of their basic properties, such as notably the expression for Kan extension in terms of (co-)ends (prop. 23 below).

\,

Definition

((co)end)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a small ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 24). Let

F:ð’ž opÃ—ð’žâŸ¶ð’± F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

be an enriched functor (Def. 26) out of the enriched product category of ð’ž\mathcal{C} with its opposite category (Def. 25). Then:

  1. The coend of FF, denoted

    âˆ«câˆˆð’žF(c,c)âˆˆð’±, \overset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} F(c,c) \;\in\; \mathcal{V} \,,

    is the coequalizer in ð’±\mathcal{V} of the two actions encoded in FF via Example 29:

    âˆc,dâˆˆð’žð’ž(c,d)âŠ—F(d,c)AAAAAAAAâŸ¶âŠ”c,dÏ (d,c)(c)âŸ¶âŠ”c,dÏ (c,d)(d)âˆcâˆˆð’žF(c,c)âŸ¶coeqâˆ«câˆˆð’žF(c,c). \underset{c,d \in \mathcal{C}}{\coprod} \mathcal{C}(c,d) \otimes F(d,c) \underoverset {\underset{\underset{c,d}{\sqcup} \rho_{(d,c)}(c) }{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{\underset{c,d}{\sqcup} \rho_{(c,d)}(d) }{\longrightarrow}} {\phantom{AAAAAAAA}} \underset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\coprod} F(c,c) \overset{coeq}{\longrightarrow} \overset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} F(c,c) \,.

  2. The end of FF, denoted

    âˆ«câˆˆð’žF(c,c)âˆˆð’±, \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} F(c,c) \;\in\; \mathcal{V} \,,

    is the equalizer in ð’±\mathcal{V} of the adjuncts of the two actions encoded in FF via example 29:

    âˆ«câˆˆð’žF(c,c)âŸ¶equâˆcâˆˆð’žF(c,c)AAAAAAAAâŸ¶âŠ”c,dÏËœ (c,d)(c)âŸ¶âŠ”c,dÏËœ d,c(d)âˆcâˆˆð’ž[ð’ž(c,d),F(c,d)]. \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} F(c,c) \overset{\;\;equ\;\;}{\longrightarrow} \underset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\prod} F(c,c) \underoverset {\underset{\underset{c,d}{\sqcup} \tilde \rho_{(c,d)}(c) }{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{\underset{c,d}{\sqcup} \tilde\rho_{d,c}(d)}{\longrightarrow}} {\phantom{AAAAAAAA}} \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\prod} \big[ \mathcal{C}\left(c,d\right), \; F\left(c,d\right) \big] \,.
Example

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos, let Gâˆˆð’±G \in \mathcal{V} be a group object. There is the n the one-object ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category BG\mathbf{B}G as in Example 4.

Then a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched functor

(X,Ï l):BGâŸ¶ð’± (X,\rho_l) \;\colon\; \mathbf{B}G \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

is an object Xâ‰”F(*)âˆˆð’±X \coloneqq F(\ast) \; \in \mathcal{V} equipped with a morphism

Ï l:GâŠ—XâŸ¶X \rho_l \;\colon\; G \otimes X \longrightarrow X

satisfying the action property. Hence this is equivalently an action of GG on XX.

The opposite category (def. 25) (BG) op(\mathbf{B}G)^{op} comes from the opposite group-object

(BG) op=B(G op). (\mathbf{B}G)^{op} = \mathbf{B}(G^{op}) \,.

(The isomorphism Gâ‰ƒG opG \simeq G^{op} induces a canonical euqivalence of enriched categories (BG) opâ‰ƒBG(\mathbf{B}G)^{op} \simeq \mathbf{B}G.)

So an enriched functor

(Y,Ï r):(BG) opâŸ¶ð’± (Y,\rho_r) \;\colon\; (\mathbf{B} G)^{op} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

is equivalently a right action of GG.

Therefore the coend of two such functors (def. 32) coequalizes the relation

(xg,y)âˆ¼(x,gy) (x g,\;y) \sim (x,\; g y)

(where juxtaposition denotes left/right action) and is the quotient of the plain tensor product by the diagonal action of the group GG:

âˆ«*âˆˆB(G +)(Y,Ï r)(*)âŠ—(X,Ï l)(*)â‰ƒYâŠ— GX. \overset{\ast \in \mathbf{B}(G_+)}{\int} (Y,\rho_r)(\ast) \,\otimes\, (X,\rho_l)(\ast) \;\simeq\; Y \otimes_G X \,.
Example

(enriched natural transformations as ends)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a small enriched category (Def. 24). For F,G:ð’žâŸ¶ð’± F, G \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V} two enriched presheaves (Example 28), the end (def. 32) of the internal-hom-functor

[F(âˆ’),G(âˆ’)]:ð’ž opÃ—ð’žâŸ¶ð’± [F(-),G(-)] \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

is an object of ð’±\mathcal{V} whose underlying set (Example 22) is the set of enriched natural transformations Fâ‡’GF \Rightarrow G (Def. 27)

Hom ð’±(1,(âˆ«câˆˆð’ž[F(c),G(c)]))â‰ƒHom [ð’ž,ð’±](F,G). Hom_{\mathcal{V}}\left(1, \left( \underset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \big[ F(c),G(c) \big] \right) \right) \;\simeq\; Hom_{[\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]}(F,G) \,.
Proof

The underlying pointed set functor Hom ð’±(1,âˆ’):ð’±â†’SetHom_{\mathcal{V}}(1,-)\colon \mathcal{V}\to Set preserves all limits, since hom-functors preserve limits? (Prop. 16). Therefore there is an equalizer diagram in Set of the form

Hom ð’±(1,(âˆ«câˆˆð’ž[F(c),G(c)]))âŸ¶equâˆcâˆˆð’žHom ð’±(F(c),G(c))AAAAAAAAâŸ¶âŠ”c,dU(ÏËœ (c,d)(c))âŸ¶âŠ”c,dU(ÏËœ d,c(d))âˆc,dâˆˆð’žHom ð’±(ð’ž(c,d),[F(c),G(d)]), Hom_{\mathcal{V}}\left(1, \left( \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [F(c),G(c)] \right) \right) \overset{equ}{\longrightarrow} \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\prod} Hom_{\mathcal{V}}(F(c),G(c)) \underoverset {\underset{\underset{c,d}{\sqcup} U(\tilde \rho_{(c,d)}(c)) }{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{\underset{c,d}{\sqcup} U(\tilde\rho_{d,c}(d))}{\longrightarrow}} {\phantom{AAAAAAAA}} \underset{c,d\in \mathcal{C}}{\prod} Hom_{\mathcal{V}}( \mathcal{C}(c,d), [F(c),G(d)] ) \,,

where we used Example 23 to identify underlying sets of internal homs with hom-sets.

Here the object in the middle is just the set of indexed sets of component morphisms {F(c)â†’Î· cG(c)} câˆˆð’ž\left\{ F(c)\overset{\eta_c}{\to} G(c)\right\}_{c\in \mathcal{C}}. The two parallel maps in the equalizer diagram take such a collection to the indexed set of composites (24) and (25). Hence that these two are equalized is precisely the condition that the indexed set of components constitutes an enriched natural transformation.

Conversely, example 33 says that ends over bifunctors of the form [F(âˆ’),G(âˆ’))][F(-),G(-))] constitute hom-spaces between pointed topologically enriched functors:

Definition

(enriched presheaf category)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a small ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 24).

Then the ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched presheaf category [ð’ž,ð’±][\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] is ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched functor category from ð’ž\mathcal{C} to ð’±\mathcal{V}, hence is the following ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 24)

  1. the objects are the ð’ž\mathcal{C}-enriched functors ð’žâ†’Fð’±\mathcal{C} \overset{F}{\to}\mathcal{V} (Def. 26);

  2. the hom-objects are the ends

    (28)[ð’ž,ð’±](F,G)â‰”âˆ« câˆˆð’ž[F(c),G(c)] [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](F,G) \;\coloneqq\; \int_{c\in \mathcal{C}} [F(c),G(c)]

  3. the composition operation on these is defined to be the one induced by the composite maps

    (âˆ«câˆˆð’ž[F(c),G(c)])âŠ—(âˆ«câˆˆð’ž[G(c),H(c)])âŸ¶âˆcâˆˆð’ž[F(c),G(c)]âŠ—[G(c),H(c)]âŸ¶(âˆ˜ F(c),G(c),H(c)) câˆˆð’žâˆcâˆˆð’ž[F(c),H(c)], \left( \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [F(c),G(c)] \right) \otimes \left( \underset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [G(c),H(c)] \right) \overset{}{\longrightarrow} \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\prod} [F(c),G(c)] \otimes [G(c),H(c)] \overset{(\circ_{F(c),G(c),H(c)})_{c\in \mathcal{C}}}{\longrightarrow} \underset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\prod} [F(c),H(c)] \,,

    where the first morphism is degreewise given by projection out of the limits that defined the ends. This composite evidently equalizes the two relevant adjunct actions (as in the proof of example 33) and hence defines a map into the end

    (âˆ«câˆˆð’ž[F(c),G(c)])âŠ—(âˆ«câˆˆð’ž[G(c),H(c)])âŸ¶âˆ«câˆˆð’ž[F(c),H(c)]. \left( \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [F(c),G(c)] \right) \otimes \left( \underset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [G(c),H(c)] \right) \longrightarrow \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [F(c),H(c)] \,.

By Example 33, the underlying plain category (Example 25) of this enriched functor category is the plain functor category of enriched functors from Example 30.

Proposition

(enriched Yoneda lemma)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23) let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a small enriched category (Def. 24). For F:ð’žâ†’ð’±F \colon \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{V} an enriched presheaf (Example 28) and for câˆˆð’žc\in \mathcal{C} an object, there is a natural isomorphism

[ð’ž,ð’±](ð’ž(c,âˆ’),F)â‰ƒF(c) [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](\mathcal{C}(c,-),\; F) \;\simeq\; F(c)

between the hom-object of the enriched functor category (Def. 33), from the functor represented by cc to FF, and the value of FF on cc.

In terms of the ends (def. 32) defining these hom-objects (28), this means that

âˆ«dâˆˆð’ž[ð’ž(c,d),F(d)]â‰ƒF(c). \underset{d\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [\mathcal{C}(c,d), F(d)] \;\simeq\; F(c) \,.

In this form the statement is also known as Yoneda reduction.

Now that natural transformations are expressed in terms of ends (example 33), as is the enriched Yoneda lemma (prop. 19), it is natural to consider the dual statement involving coends:

Proposition

(enriched co-Yoneda lemma)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a small ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 24). For F:ð’žâ†’ð’±F \colon \mathcal{C}\to \mathcal{V} an enriched presheaf (Def. 28) and for câˆˆð’žc\in \mathcal{C} an object, there is a natural isomorphism

F(âˆ’)â‰ƒâˆ«câˆˆð’žð’ž(c,âˆ’)âŠ—F(c). F(-) \simeq \overset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \mathcal{C}(c,-) \otimes F(c) \,.

Moreover, the morphism that hence exhibits F(c)F(c) as the coequalizer of the two morphisms in def. 32 is componentwise the canonical action

ð’ž(c,d)âŠ—F(c)âŸ¶F(d) \mathcal{C}(c,d) \otimes F(c) \longrightarrow F(d)

which is adjunct to the component map ð’ž(d,c)â†’[F(c),F(d)]\mathcal{C}(d,c) \to [F(c),F(d)] of the enriched functor FF.

(e.g. MMSS 00, lemma 1.6)

Proof

By the definition of coends and the universal property of colimits, enriched natural transformations of the form

(âˆ«câˆˆð’žð’ž(c,âˆ’)âŠ—F(c))âŸ¶G \left( \overset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \mathcal{C}(c,-) \otimes F(c) \right) \longrightarrow G

are in natural bijection with systems of component morphisms

ð’ž(c,d)âŠ—F(c)âŸ¶G(d) \mathcal{C}(c,d) \otimes F(c) \longrightarrow G(d)

which satisfy some compatibility conditions in their dependence on cc and dd (natural in dd and â€œextranaturalâ€ in cc). By the internal hom adjunction, these are in natural bijection to systems of morphisms of the form

F(c)âŸ¶[ð’ž(c,d),G(d)] F(c) \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}(c,d), G(d)]

satisfying the analogous compatibility conditions. By Example 33 these are in natural bijection with systems of morphisms

F(c)âŸ¶[ð’ž,ð’±](ð’ž(c,âˆ’),G(âˆ’)) F(c) \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C},\mathcal{V}](\mathcal{C}(c,-), G(-))

natural in cc

By the enriched Yoneda lemma (Prop. 19), these, finally, are in natural bijection with systems of morphisms

F(c)âŸ¶G(c) F(c) \longrightarrow G(c)

natural in cc. Moreover, all these identifications are also natural in GG. Therefore, in summary, this shows that there is a natural isomorphism

Hom [ð’ž,ð’±](âˆ«câˆˆð’žð’ž(c,âˆ’)âŠ—F(c),(âˆ’))â‰ƒHom [ð’ž,ð’±](F,(âˆ’)). Hom_{[\mathcal{C},\mathcal{V}]} \left( \overset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \mathcal{C}(c,-) \otimes F(c) \;,\; (-) \right) \;\simeq\; Hom_{[\mathcal{C},\mathcal{V}]} \left( F, (-) \right) \,.

With this, the ordinary Yoneda lemma (Prop. 1) in the form of the Yoneda embedding of [ð’ž,ð’±][\mathcal{C},\mathcal{V}] implies the required isomorphism.

Example

(co-Yoneda lemma over Set)

Consider the co-Yoneda lemma (Prop. 20) in the special case ð’±=\mathcal{V} = Set (Example 21).

In this case the coequalizer in question is the set of equivalence classes of pairs

(câ†’c 0,x)âˆˆð’ž(c,c 0)âŠ—F(c), ( c \overset{}{\to} c_0,\; x ) \;\; \in \mathcal{C}(c,c_0) \otimes F(c) \,,

where two such pairs

(câ†’fc 0,xâˆˆF(c)),(dâ†’gc 0,yâˆˆF(d)) ( c \overset{f}{\to} c_0,\; x \in F(c) ) \,,\;\;\;\; ( d \overset{g}{\to} c_0,\; y \in F(d) )

are regarded as equivalent if there exists

câ†’Ï•d c \overset{\phi}{\to} d

such that

f=gâˆ˜Ï•,andy=Ï•(x). f = g \circ \phi \,, \;\;\;\;\;and\;\;\;\;\; y = \phi(x) \,.

(Because then the two pairs are the two images of the pair (g,x)(g,x) under the two morphisms being coequalized.)

But now considering the case that d=c 0d = c_0 and g=id c 0g = id_{c_0}, so that f=Ï•f = \phi shows that any pair

(câ†’Ï•c 0,xâˆˆF(c)) ( c \overset{\phi}{\to} c_0, \; x \in F(c))

is identified, in the coequalizer, with the pair

(id c 0,Ï•(x)âˆˆF(c 0)), (id_{c_0},\; \phi(x) \in F(c_0)) \,,

hence with Ï•(x)âˆˆF(c 0)\phi(x)\in F(c_0).

Remark

The statement of the co-Yoneda lemma in prop. 20 is a kind of categorification of the following statement in analysis (whence the notation with the integral signs):

For XX a topological space, f:Xâ†’â„f \colon X \to\mathbb{R} a continuous function and Î´(âˆ’,x 0)\delta(-,x_0) denoting the Dirac distribution, then

âˆ« xâˆˆXÎ´(x,x 0)f(x)=f(x 0). \int_{x \in X} \delta(x,x_0) f(x) = f(x_0) \,.

It is this analogy that gives the name to the following statement:

Proposition

(Fubini theorem for (co)-ends)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), let ð’ž 1,ð’ž 2\mathcal{C}_1, \mathcal{C}_2 be two ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 24) and

F:(ð’ž 1Ã—ð’ž 2) opÃ—(ð’ž 1Ã—ð’ž 2)âŸ¶ð’± F \;\colon\; \left( \mathcal{C}_1\times\mathcal{C}_2 \right)^{op} \times (\mathcal{C}_1 \times\mathcal{C}_2) \longrightarrow \mathcal{V}

a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched functor (Def. 26) from the product category with opposite categories (Def. 25), as shown.

Then its end and coend (def. 32) is equivalently formed consecutively over each variable, in either order:

âˆ«(c 1,c 2)F((c 1,c 2),(c 1,c 2))â‰ƒâˆ«c 1âˆ«c 2F((c 1,c 2),(c 1,c 2))â‰ƒâˆ«c 2âˆ«c 1F((c 1,c 2),(c 1,c 2)) \overset{(c_1,c_2)}{\int} F((c_1,c_2), (c_1,c_2)) \simeq \overset{c_1}{\int} \overset{c_2}{\int} F((c_1,c_2), (c_1,c_2)) \simeq \overset{c_2}{\int} \overset{c_1}{\int} F((c_1,c_2), (c_1,c_2))

and

âˆ«(c 1,c 2)F((c 1,c 2),(c 1,c 2))â‰ƒâˆ«c 1âˆ«c 2F((c 1,c 2),(c 1,c 2))â‰ƒâˆ«c 2âˆ«c 1F((c 1,c 2),(c 1,c 2)). \underset{(c_1,c_2)}{\int} F((c_1,c_2), (c_1,c_2)) \simeq \underset{c_1}{\int} \underset{c_2}{\int} F((c_1,c_2), (c_1,c_2)) \simeq \underset{c_2}{\int} \underset{c_1}{\int} F((c_1,c_2), (c_1,c_2)) \,.
Proof

Because limits commute with limits, and colimits commute with colimits.

Remark

(internal hom preserves ends)

Let ð’±\mathcal{V} be a cosmos (Def. 23). Since the internal hom-functor in ð’±\mathcal{V} (Def. 21) preserves limits in both variables (Prop. 14), in particular it preserves ends (Def. 32) in the second variable, and sends coends in the second variable to ends:

For all small ð’ž\mathcal{C}-enriched categories, ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched functors F:ð’ž opâŠ—ð’žâ†’ð’±F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \otimes \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{V} (Def. 26) and all objects Xâˆˆð’±X \in \mathcal{V} we have natural isomorphisms

[X,âˆ« câˆˆð’žF(c,c)]â‰ƒâˆ« câˆˆð’ž[X,F(c,c)] \left[ X , \int^{c \in \mathcal{C}} F(c,c) \right] \;\simeq\; \int^{c \in \mathcal{C}} \left[ X, F(c,c) \right]

and

[âˆ« câˆˆð’žF(c,c),X]â‰ƒâˆ« câˆˆð’ž[F(c,c),X]. \left[ \int_{c \in \mathcal{C}} F(c,c) , X \right] \;\simeq\; \int^{c \in \mathcal{C}} \left[ F(c,c), X \right] \,.

With this coend calculus in hand, there is an elegant proof of the defining universal property of the smash tensoring and powering enriched presheaves (Def. 28):

Proposition

(universal property of tensoring and powering of enriched presheaves)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a small ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched category (Def. 24), with [ð’ž,ð’±][\mathcal{C},\mathcal{V}] the corresponding enriched presheaf category.

Then there are natural isomorphisms

[ð’ž,ð’±](Xâ‹…K,Y)â‰ƒ[K,([ð’ž,ð’±](X,Y))] [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]( X \cdot K ,\, Y ) \;\simeq\; [K,\big( [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]\left( X, Y \right) \big)]

and
