[ð’ž,ð’±](X,Y K)â‰ƒ[K,([ð’ž,ð’ž](X,Y))] [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]\left( X,\, Y^K \right) \;\simeq\; [K, \big( [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{C}](X,Y) \big) ]

for all X,Yâˆˆ[ð’ž,ð’±]X,Y \in [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] and all Kâˆˆð’žK \in \mathcal{C}, where (âˆ’) K(-)^K is the powering and (âˆ’)â‹…K(-)\cdot K the tensoring from Def. 28.

In particular there is the composite natural isomorphism

[ð’ž,ð’±](Xâ‹…K,Y)â‰ƒ[ð’ž,ð’±](X,Y K) [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](X \cdot K, Y) \;\simeq\; [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]\left( X, Y^K \right)

exhibiting a pair of adjoint functors

[ð’ž,ð’±]âŠ¥âŸ¶(âˆ’) KâŸµ(âˆ’)â‹…K[ð’ž,ð’±]. [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] \underoverset {\underset{(-)^K}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{(-) \cdot K}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] \,.
Proof

Via the end-expression for [ð’ž,ð’±](âˆ’,âˆ’)[\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](-,-) from Example 33, and the fact (remark 8) that the internal hom-functor ends in the second variable, this reduces to the fact that [âˆ’,âˆ’][-,-] is the internal hom in the closed monoidal category ð’±\mathcal{V} (Example 26) and hence satisfies the internal tensor/hom-adjunction isomorphism (prop. 13):

[ð’ž,ð’±](Xâ‹…K,Y) =âˆ«c[(Xâ‹…K)(c),Y(c)] â‰ƒâˆ«c[X(c)âŠ—K,Y(x)] â‰ƒâˆ«c[K,[X(c),Y(c)]] â‰ƒ[K,âˆ«c[X(c),Y(c)]] =[K,([ð’ž,ð’±](X,Y))] \begin{aligned} [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](X \cdot K, Y) & = \underset{c}{\int} [ (X \cdot K)(c), Y(c) ] \\ & \simeq \underset{c}{\int} [X(c) \otimes K, Y(x)] \\ & \simeq \underset{c}{\int} [K,[X(c), Y(c)]] \\ & \simeq [K, \underset{c}{\int} [X(c),Y(c)]] \\ & = [K,\left( [\mathcal{C},\mathcal{V}](X,Y)\right)] \end{aligned}

and

[ð’ž,ð’±](X,Y K) =âˆ«c[X(c),Y K(c)] â‰ƒâˆ«c[X(c),[K,Y(c)]] â‰ƒâˆ«c[X(c)âŠ—K,Y(c)] â‰ƒâˆ«c[K,[X(c),Y(c)]] â‰ƒ[K,âˆ«c[X(c),Y(c)]] â‰ƒ[K,[ð’ž,ð’±](X,Y]. \begin{aligned} [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](X, Y^K) & = \underset{c}{\int} [X(c), Y^K(c)] \\ & \simeq \underset{c}{\int} [ X(c), [K,Y(c)] ] \\ & \simeq \underset{c}{\int} [ X(c) \otimes K, Y(c) ] \\ & \simeq \underset{c}{\int} [K, [X(c),Y(c)]] \\ & \simeq [K, \underset{c}{\int} [X(c),Y(c)] ] \\ & \simeq [K, [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](X,Y] \,. \end{aligned}

\,

Kan extensions

Proposition

(Kan extension)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), let ð’ž,ð’Ÿ\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{D} be small ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 24) and let

p:ð’žâŸ¶ð’Ÿ p \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \longrightarrow \mathcal{D}

be a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched functor (Def. 26). Then precomposition with pp constitutes a functor between the corresponding ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched presheaf categories (Def. 33)

(29)p *:[ð’Ÿ,ð’±] âŸ¶ [ð’ž,ð’±] G â†¦ Gâˆ˜p p^\ast \;\colon\; \array{ [\mathcal{D}, \mathcal{V}] &\longrightarrow& [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] \\ G &\mapsto& G \circ p }

  1. This enriched functor p *p^\ast (29) has a enriched left adjoint Lan pLan_p (Def. 29), called left Kan extension along pp

    [ð’Ÿ,ð’±]âŠ¥âŸ¶p *âŸµLan p[ð’ž,ð’±] [\mathcal{D}, \mathcal{V}] \underoverset {\underset{p^\ast}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{Lan_p }{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]

    which is given objectwise by the coend (def. 32):

    (30)(Lan pF):dâ†¦âˆ«câˆˆð’žð’Ÿ(p(c),d)âŠ—F(c). (Lan_p F) \;\colon\; d \;\mapsto \; \overset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \mathcal{D}(p(c),d) \otimes F(c) \,.

  2. The enriched functor p *p^\ast (29) has a enriched right adjoint Ran pRan_p (Def. 29), called right Kan extension along pp

    [ð’ž,ð’±]âŠ¥âŸ¶Ran pâŸµp *[ð’Ÿ,ð’±] [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}] \underoverset {\underset{Ran_p}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{p^\ast}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} [\mathcal{D}, \mathcal{V}]

    which is given objectwise by the end (def. 32):

    (31)(Ran pF):dâ†¦âˆ«câˆˆð’ž[ð’Ÿ(d,p(c)),F(c)]. (Ran_p F) \;\colon\; d \;\mapsto \; \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [\mathcal{D}(d,p(c)), F(c)] \,.

In summary, this means that the enriched functor

ð’žâŸ¶pð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \overset{p}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{D}

induces, via Kan extension, an adjoint triple of enriched functors

(32)Lan pâŠ£p *âŠ£Ran p:[ð’ž,ð’±]â†”[ð’Ÿ,ð’±]. Lan_p \;\dashv\; p^\ast \;\dashv\; Ran_p \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C},\mathcal{V}] \leftrightarrow [\mathcal{D}, \mathcal{V}] \,.
Proof

Use the expression of enriched natural transformations in terms of [[coends (example 33 and def. 33), then use the respect of [âˆ’,âˆ’][-,-] for ends/coends (remark 8), use the internal-hom adjunction (21), use the Fubini theorem (prop. 21) and finally use Yoneda reduction (prop. 19) to obtain a sequence of natural isomorphisms as follows:

[ð’Ÿ,ð’±](Lan pF,G) =âˆ«dâˆˆð’Ÿ[(Lan pF)(d),G(d)] =âˆ«dâˆˆð’Ÿ[âˆ«câˆˆð’žð’Ÿ(p(c),d)âŠ—F(c),G(d)] â‰ƒâˆ«dâˆˆð’Ÿâˆ«câˆˆð’ž[ð’Ÿ(p(c),d)âŠ—F(c),G(d)] â‰ƒâˆ«câˆˆð’žâˆ«dâˆˆð’Ÿ[F(c),[ð’Ÿ(p(c),d),G(d)]] â‰ƒâˆ«câˆˆð’ž[F(c),âˆ«dâˆˆð’Ÿ[ð’Ÿ(p(c),d),G(d)]] â‰ƒâˆ«câˆˆð’ž[F(c),G(p(c))] =[ð’ž,ð’±](F,p *G). \begin{aligned} [\mathcal{D}, \mathcal{V}]( Lan_p F, \, G ) & = \underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\int} [ (Lan_p F)(d), \, G(d) ] \\ & = \underset{d\in \mathcal{D}}{\int} \left[ \overset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \mathcal{D}(p(c),d) \otimes F(c) ,\; G(d) \right] \\ &\simeq \underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\int} \underset{c \in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [ \mathcal{D}(p(c),d) \otimes F(c) \,,\; G(d) ] \\ & \simeq \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \underset{d\in \mathcal{D}}{\int} [F(c), [ \mathcal{D}(p(c),d) , \, G(d) ] ] \\ & \simeq \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [F(c), \underset{d\in \mathcal{D}}{\int} [ \mathcal{D}(p(c),d) , \, G(d) ] ] \\ & \simeq \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [ F(c), G(p(c)) ] \\ & = [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}](F,p^\ast G) \end{aligned} \,.

and similarly:

[ð’Ÿ,ð’±](G,Ran pF) â‰ƒâˆ«dâˆˆð’Ÿ[G(d),(Ran pF)(d),] â‰ƒâˆ«dâˆˆð’Ÿ[G(d),âˆ«câˆˆð’ž[ð’Ÿ(d,p(c)),F(c)]] â‰ƒâˆ«dâˆˆð’Ÿâˆ«câˆˆð’ž[G(d)âŠ—ð’Ÿ(d,p(c)),F(c)] â‰ƒâˆ«câˆˆð’ž[âˆ«dâˆˆð’ŸG(d)âŠ—ð’Ÿ(d,p(c)),F(c)] â‰ƒâˆ«câˆˆð’Ÿ[G(p(c)),F(c)] â‰ƒ[ð’ž,ð’±](p *G,F) \begin{aligned} [\mathcal{D}, \mathcal{V}]( G,\, Ran_p F ) & \simeq \underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\int} [ G(d) ,\, (Ran_p F)(d), \, ] \\ & \simeq \underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\int} \left[ G(d) ,\, \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} [\mathcal{D}(d,p(c)), F(c)] \right] \\ & \simeq \underset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\int} \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \left[ G(d) \otimes \mathcal{D}(d,p(c)),\, F(c) \right] \\ & \simeq \underset{c\in \mathcal{C}}{\int} \left[ \overset{d \in \mathcal{D}}{\int} G(d) \otimes \mathcal{D}(d,p(c)),\, F(c) \right] \\ & \simeq \underset{c \in \mathcal{D}}{\int} \left[ G(p(c)),\, F(c) \right] \\ & \simeq [\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{V}]( p^\ast G , F ) \end{aligned}
Example

(coend formula for left Kan extension of ordinary presheaves)

Consider the cosmos to be ð’±=\mathcal{V} = Set, via Example 21, so that small ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 24) are just a plain small category (Def. 1) by Example 24, and ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched presheaves (Example 28) are just plain presheaves (Example 14).

Then for any plain functor (Def. 6)

ð’ž opâŸ¶AApAA(ð’žâ€²) op \mathcal{C}^{op} \overset{\phantom{AA} p \phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow} (\mathcal{C}')^{op}

the general formula (30) for left Kan extension

[ð’ž op,Set]âŸ¶Lan p[(ð’žâ€²) op,Set] [\mathcal{C}^{op},Set] \overset{Lan_p}{\longrightarrow} [(\mathcal{C}')^{op}, Set]

is

(Lan pF)(câ€²)â‰ƒâˆ« câˆˆCCâ€²(câ€²,p(c))Ã—F(c). (Lan_p F)(c') \simeq \int^{c \in C} C'(c', p(c)) \times F(c) \,.

Using here the Yoneda lemma (Prop. 1) to rewrite F(c)â‰ƒHom PSh(C)(c,F)F(c) \simeq Hom_{PSh(C)}(c,F), this is

(Lan pF)(câ€²)â‰ƒâˆ« câˆˆCHom Câ€²(câ€²,p(c))Ã—Hom PSh(C)(c,F). (Lan_p F)(c') \simeq \int^{c \in C} Hom_{C'}(c', p(c)) \times Hom_{PSh(C)}(c,F) \,.

Hence this coend-set consists of equivalence classes of pairs of morphisms

(câ€²â†’p(c),câ†’F) (c' \to p(c), c \to F)

where two such are regarded as equivalent whenever there is f:câ€² 1â†’câ€² 2f \colon c'_1 \to c'_2 such that

câ€² â†™ â†˜ p(c 1) âŸ¶p(f) p(c 2) c 1 âŸ¶f c 2 â†˜ â†™ F. \array{ && c' \\ & \swarrow && \searrow \\ p(c_1) && \stackrel{p(f)}{\longrightarrow} && p(c_2) \\ c_1 && \stackrel{f}{\longrightarrow} && c_2 \\ & \searrow && \swarrow \\ && F } \,.

This is particularly suggestive when pp is a full subcategory inclusion (Def. 8). For in that case we may imagine that a representative pair (câ€²â†’p(c),câ†’F)(c' \to p(c), c \to F) is a stand-in for the actual pullback of elements of FF along the would-be composite â€œcâ€²â†’câ†’Fc'\to c \to Fâ€, only that this composite need not be defined. But the above equivalence relation is precisely that under which this composite would be invariant.

Further properties

We collect here further key properties of the various universal constructions considered above.

\,

Proposition

(fully faithful adjoint triple)

Let FâŠ£GâŠ£HF \dashv G \dashv H be an adjoint triple of adjoint functors. Then FF is a fully faithful functor (Def. 8) precisely when HH is. (see this prop.)

Proposition

(left Kan extension preserves representable functors)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), let

ð’žâŸ¶pð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \overset{p}{\longrightarrow} \mathcal{D}

be a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched functor (Def. 26) between small ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 24).

Then the left Kan extension Lan pLan_p (Prop. 23) takes representable enriched presheaves ð’ž(c,âˆ’):ð’žâ†’ð’±\mathcal{C}(c,-) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{V} to their image under pp:

Lan pð’ž(c,âˆ’)â‰ƒð’Ÿ(p(c),âˆ’) Lan_p \mathcal{C}(c, -) \;\simeq\; \mathcal{D}(p(c), -)

for all câˆˆCc \in C.

Proof

By the coend forumla (30) have naturally in dâ€²âˆˆð’Ÿd' \in \mathcal{D} the expression

Lan pð’ž(c,âˆ’):dâ€²â†¦ âˆ« câ€²âˆˆCð’Ÿ(p(câ€²),dâ€²)âŠ—ð’ž(c,âˆ’)(câ€²) â‰ƒâˆ« câ€²âˆˆCð’Ÿ(p(câ€²),dâ€²)âŠ—ð’ž(c,câ€²) â‰ƒð’Ÿ(p(c),dâ€²), \begin{aligned} Lan_p \mathcal{C}(c,-) \;\colon\; d' \mapsto & \int^{c' \in C} \mathcal{D}(p(c'), d') \otimes \mathcal{C}(c,-)(c') \\ & \simeq \int^{c' \in C} \mathcal{D}(p(c'), d') \otimes \mathcal{C}(c,c') \\ & \simeq \mathcal{D}(p(c), d') \end{aligned} \,,

where the last step is the co-Yoneda lemma (Prop. 20).

Example

(Kan extension of adjoint pair is adjoint quadruple)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), let ð’ž\mathcal{C}, ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be two small ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 24) and let

ð’žâŠ¥âŸ¶pâŸµqð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \underoverset {\underset{p}{\longrightarrow}} {\overset{q}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{D}

be a ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched adjunction (Def. 29). Then there are ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched natural isomorphisms (Def. 27)

(q op) *â‰ƒLan p op:[ð’ž op,ð’±]âŸ¶[ð’Ÿ op,ð’±] (q^{op})^\ast \;\simeq\; Lan_{p^{op}} \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C}^{op},\mathcal{V}] \longrightarrow [\mathcal{D}^{op},\mathcal{V}]
(p op) *â‰ƒRan q op:[ð’Ÿ op,ð’±]âŸ¶[ð’ž op,ð’±] (p^{op})^\ast \;\simeq\; Ran_{q^{op}} \;\colon\; [\mathcal{D}^{op},\mathcal{V}] \longrightarrow [\mathcal{C}^{op},\mathcal{V}]

between the precomposition on enriched presheaves with one functor and the left/right Kan extension of the other (Def. 23).

By essential uniqueness of adjoint functors, this means that the two adjoint triples (32) of qq and pp

Lan q op âŠ£ (q op) * âŠ£ Ran q op Lan p op âŠ£ (p op) * âŠ£ Ran p op \array{ Lan_{q^{op}} &\dashv& (q^{op})^\ast &\dashv& Ran_{q^{op}} \\ && Lan_{p^{op}} &\dashv& (p^{op})^\ast &\dashv& Ran_{p^{op}} }

merge into an adjoint quadruple

Lan q op âŠ£ (q op) * âŠ£ (p op) * âŠ£ Ran p op:[ð’ž op,ð’±]â†”[ð’Ÿ op,ð’±] \array{ Lan_{q^{op}} &\dashv& (q^{op})^\ast &\dashv& (p^{op})^\ast &\dashv& Ran_{p^{op}} } \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C}^{op},\mathcal{V}] \leftrightarrow [\mathcal{D}^{op}, \mathcal{V}]
Proof

For every enriched presheaf F:ð’ž opâ†’ð’±F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \to \mathcal{V} we have a sequence of ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched natural isomorphism as follows

(Lan p opF)(d) â‰ƒâˆ« câˆˆð’žð’Ÿ(d,p(c))âŠ—F(c) â‰ƒâˆ« câˆˆð’žð’ž(q(d),c)âŠ—F(c) â‰ƒF(q(d)) =((q op) *F)(d). \begin{aligned} (Lan_{p^{op}} F)(d) & \simeq \int^{ c \in \mathcal{C} } \mathcal{D}(d,p(c)) \otimes F(c) \\ & \simeq \int^{ c \in \mathcal{C} } \mathcal{C}(q(d),c) \otimes F(c) \\ & \simeq F(q(d)) \\ & = \left( (q^{op})^\ast F\right) (d) \,. \end{aligned}

Here the first step is the coend-formula for left Kan extension (Prop. 23), the second step if the enriched adjunction-isomorphism (26) for qâŠ£pq \dashv p and the third step is the co-Yoneda lemma.

This shows the first statement, which, by essential uniqueness of adjoints, implies the following statements.

Proposition

(left Kan extension along fully faithful functor is fully faithful)

For ð’±\mathcal{V} a cosmos (Def. 23), let

ð’žâ†ªAApAAð’Ÿ \mathcal{C} \overset{\phantom{AA} p \phantom{AA}}{\hookrightarrow} \mathcal{D}

be a fully faithful ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched functor (Def. 26) between small ð’±\mathcal{V}-enriched categories (Def. 24).

Then for all câˆˆð’žc \in \mathcal{C}

p *(Lan pc)â‰ƒc p^* (Lan_p c) \simeq c

and in fact the (Lan FâŠ£F *)(Lan_F \dashv F^*)-unit of an adjunction is a natural isomorphism

Idâ†’â‰ƒp *âˆ˜Lan p. Id \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} p^* \circ Lan_{p} \,.
Proof

By the coend forumla (30) have naturally in dâ€²âˆˆð’Ÿd' \in \mathcal{D} the left Kan extension of any F:ð’žâ†’ð’±F \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{V} on the image of pp is

Lan pF:p(c)â†¦ âˆ« câ€²âˆˆCð’Ÿ(p(câ€²),p(c))â‹…F(câ€²) â‰ƒâˆ« câ€²âˆˆCð’ž(câ€²,c)â‹…F(câ€²) â‰ƒF(c), \begin{aligned} Lan_p F \;\colon\; p(c) \mapsto & \int^{c' \in C} \mathcal{D}(p(c'), p(c)) \cdot F(c') \\ & \simeq \int^{c' \in C} \mathcal{C}(c', c) \cdot F(c') \\ & \simeq F(c) \end{aligned} \,,

where in the second step we used the assumption of fully faithfulness of pp and in the last step we used the co-Yoneda lemma (Prop. 20).

Lemma

(colimit of representable is singleton)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a small category (Def. 3). Then the colimit of a representable presheaf (Def. 14), regarded as a functor

y(c):ð’ž opâŸ¶Set y(c) \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \longrightarrow Set

is the singleton set.

(33)limâŸ¶ð’Ÿ opy(c)â‰ƒ*. \underset{\underset{\mathcal{D}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} y(c) \;\simeq\; \ast \,.
Proof

One way to see this is to regard the colimit as the left Kan extension (Prop. 23) along the unique functor ð’ž opâ†’p*\mathcal{C}^{op} \overset{p}{\to} \ast to the terminal category (Def. 3). By the formula (30) this is

limâŸ¶ð’Ÿ opy(c) â‰ƒâˆ« c 1âˆˆð’ž*(âˆ’,p(c 1))âŸconst *(c 1)Ã—y(c)(c 1) â‰ƒâˆ« c 1âˆˆð’žconst *(c 1)Ã—ð’ž(c 1,c) â‰ƒconst *(c) â‰ƒ* \begin{aligned} \underset{\underset{\mathcal{D}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} y(c) & \simeq \int^{c_1 \in \mathcal{C}} \underset{const_\ast(c_1)}{\underbrace{\ast(-,p(c_1))}} \times y(c)(c_1) \\ & \simeq \int^{c_1 \in \mathcal{C}} const_\ast(c_1) \times \mathcal{C}(c_1,c) \\ & \simeq const_\ast(c) \\ & \simeq \ast \end{aligned}

where we made explicit the constant functor const *:ð’žâ†’Setconst_\ast \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \to Set, constant on the singleton set *\ast, and then applied the co-Yoneda lemma (Prop. 20).

Proposition

(categories with finite products are cosifted

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a small category (Def. 3) which has finite products. Then ð’ž\mathcal{C} is a cosifted category, equivalently its opposite category ð’ž op\mathcal{C}^{op} is a sifted category, equivalently colimits over ð’ž op\mathcal{C}^{op} with values in Set are sifted colimits, equivalently colimits over ð’ž op\mathcal{C}^{op} with values in Set commute with finite products, as follows:

For X,Yâˆˆ[ð’ž op,Set]\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] to functors on the opposite category of ð’ž\mathcal{C} (hence two presheaves on ð’ž\mathcal{C}, Example 14) we have a natural isomorphism (Def. 9)

limâŸ¶ð’ž op(XÃ—Y)â‰ƒ(limâŸ¶ð’ž opX)Ã—(limâŸ¶ð’ž opY) \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \left( \mathbf{X} \times \mathbf{Y} \right) \;\simeq\; \left( \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \mathbf{X} \right) \times \left( \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \mathbf{Y} \right)

between the colimit of their Cartesian product and the Cartesian product of their separate colimits.

Proof

First observe that for X,Yâˆˆ[ð’ž op,Set]\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] two presheaves, their Cartesian product is a colimit over presheaves represented by Cartesian products in ð’ž\mathcal{C}. Explicity, using coend-notation, we have:

(34)XÃ—Yâ‰ƒâˆ« c 1,c 2âˆˆð’žy(c 1Ã—c 2)Ã—X(c 1)Ã—Y(c 2), \mathbf{X} \times \mathbf{Y} \;\simeq\; \int^{c_1,c_2 \in \mathcal{C}} y(c_1 \times c_2) \times \mathbf{X}(c_1) \times \mathbf{Y}(c_2) \,,

where y:ð’žâ†ª[ð’ž op,Set]y \;\colon\; \mathcal{C} \hookrightarrow [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] denotes the Yoneda embedding.

This is due to the following sequence of natural isomorphisms:

(XÃ—Y)(c) â‰ƒ(âˆ« c 1âˆˆð’žð’ž(c,c 1)Ã—X(c 1))Ã—(âˆ« c 2âˆˆð’žð’ž(c,c 2)Ã—Y(c 2)) â‰ƒâˆ« c 1âˆˆð’žâˆ« c 2âˆˆð’žð’ž(c,c 1)Ã—ð’ž(c,c 2)âŸâ‰ƒð’¸(c,c 1Ã—c 2)Ã—(X(c 1)Ã—X(c 2)) â‰ƒâˆ« c 1âˆˆð’žâˆ« c 2âˆˆð’žð’ž(c,c 1Ã—c 2)Ã—X(c 1)Ã—X(c 2), \begin{aligned} (\mathbf{X} \times \mathbf{Y})(c) & \simeq \left( \int^{c_1 \in \mathcal{C}} \mathcal{C}(c,c_1) \times \mathbf{X}(c_1) \right) \times \left( \int^{c_2 \in \mathcal{C}} \mathcal{C}(c,c_2) \times \mathbf{Y}(c_2) \right) \\ & \simeq \int^{c_1 \in \mathcal{C}} \int^{c_2 \in \mathcal{C}} \underset{ \simeq \mathcal{c}(c, c_1 \times c_2) }{ \underbrace{ \mathcal{C}(c,c_1) \times \mathcal{C}(c,c_2) }} \times \left( \mathbf{X}(c_1) \times \mathbf{X}(c_2) \right) \\ & \simeq \int^{c_1 \in \mathcal{C}} \int^{c_2 \in \mathcal{C}} \mathcal{C}(c,c_1 \times c_2) \times \mathbf{X}(c_1) \times \mathbf{X}(c_2) \,, \end{aligned}

where the first step expands out both presheaves as colimits of representables separately, via the co-Yoneda lemma (Prop. 20), the second step uses that the Cartesian product of presheaves is a two-variable left adjoint (by the symmetric closed monoidal structure on presheaves) and as such preserves colimits (in particular coends) in each variable separately (Prop. 17), and under the brace we use the defining universal property of the Cartesian products, assumed to exist in ð’ž\mathcal{C}.

With this, we have the following sequence of natural isomorphisms:

limâŸ¶ð’Ÿ op(XÃ—Y) â‰ƒlimâŸ¶ð’Ÿ opâˆ« c 1,c 2âˆˆð’žy(c 1Ã—c 2)Ã—X(c 1)Ã—Y(c 2) â‰ƒâˆ« c 1,c 2âˆˆð’žlimâŸ¶ð’Ÿ op(y(c 1Ã—c 2)Ã—X(c 1)Ã—Y(c 2)) â‰ƒâˆ« c 1,c 2âˆˆð’ž(limâŸ¶ð’Ÿ opy(c 1Ã—c 2)âŸâ‰ƒ*)Ã—X(c 1)Ã—Y(c 2) â‰ƒâˆ« c 1,c 2âˆˆð’ž(X(c 1)Ã—Y(c 2)) â‰ƒ(âˆ« c 1âˆˆð’žX(c 1))Ã—(âˆ« c 2âˆˆð’žY(c 2)) â‰ƒ(limâŸ¶ð’ž opX)Ã—(limâŸ¶ð’ž opY) \begin{aligned} \underset{\underset{\mathcal{D}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \left( \mathbf{X} \times \mathbf{Y} \right) & \simeq \underset{\underset{\mathcal{D}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \int^{c_1,c_2 \in \mathcal{C}} y(c_1 \times c_2) \times \mathbf{X}(c_1) \times \mathbf{Y}(c_2) \\ & \simeq \int^{c_1,c_2 \in \mathcal{C}} \underset{\underset{\mathcal{D}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \left( y(c_1 \times c_2) \times \mathbf{X}(c_1) \times \mathbf{Y}(c_2) \right) \\ & \simeq \int^{c_1,c_2 \in \mathcal{C}} \left( \underset{ \simeq \ast }{ \underbrace{ \underset{\underset{\mathcal{D}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} y(c_1 \times c_2) }} \right) \times \mathbf{X}(c_1) \times \mathbf{Y}(c_2) \\ & \simeq \int^{c_1,c_2 \in \mathcal{C}} \left( \mathbf{X}(c_1) \times \mathbf{Y}(c_2) \right) \\ & \simeq \left( \int^{c_1\in \mathcal{C}} \mathbf{X}(c_1) \right) \times \left( \int^{c_2\in \mathcal{C}} \mathbf{Y}(c_2) \right) \\ & \simeq \left( \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \mathbf{X} \right) \times \left( \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \mathbf{Y} \right) \end{aligned}

Here the first step is (34), the second uses that colimits commute with colimits (Prop. 18), the third uses again that the Cartesian product respects colimits in each variable separately, the fourth is by Lemma 2, the last step is again the respect for colimits of the Cartesian product in each variable separately.

\,

Basic notions of Topos theory

We have explained in Remark 2 how presheaves on a category ð’ž\mathcal{C} may be thought of as generalized spaces probe-able by the objects of ð’ž\mathcal{C}, and that two consistency conditions on this interpretation are provided by the Yoneda lemma (Prop. 1) and the resulting Yoneda embedding (Prop. 2). Here we turn to a third consistency condition that one will want to impose:

Remark

(sheaf condition as local-to-global principle for generalized spaces)

If the objects of ð’ž\mathcal{C} are thought of as spaces of sorts, as in Remark 2, then there is typically a notion of locality in these spaces, reflected by a notion of what it means to cover a given space by (â€œsmallerâ€) spaces (a coverage, Def. 34 below).

But if a space Xâˆˆð’žX \in \mathcal{C} is covered, say by two other spaces U 1,U 2âˆˆð’žU_1, U_2 \in \mathcal{C}, via morphisms

U 1 U 2 i 1â†˜ â†™ i 2 X \array{ U_1 && && U_2 \\ & {}_{\mathllap{i_1}}\searrow && \swarrow_{\mathrlap{i_2}} \\ && X }

then this must be reflected in the behaviour of the probes of any generalized space Y\mathbf{Y} (in the sense of Remark 2) by these test spaces:

For ease of discussion, suppose that there is a sense in which these two patches above intersect in XX to form a space U 1âˆ© XU 2âˆˆð’žU_1 \cap_X U_2 \in \mathcal{C}. Then locality of probes should imply that the ways of mapping U 1U_1 and U 2U_2 into Y\mathbf{Y} such that these maps agree on the intersection U 1âˆ© XU 2U_1 \cap_X U_2, should be equivalent to the ways of mapping all of XX into Y\mathbf{Y}.

locality:{maps fromU 1andU 2toY that coincide onU 1âˆ© XU 2}â‰ƒ{maps fromXintoY} \text{locality} \;:\; \left\{ \array{ \text{maps from}\,U_1\,\text{and}\,U_2\,\text{to}\,\mathbf{Y} \\ \text{that coincide on}\,U_1 \cap_X U_2 } \right\} \;\simeq\; \left\{ \text{maps from}\,X\,\text{into}\,\mathbf{Y} \right\}

One could call this the condition of locality of probes of generalized spaces probeable by objects of ð’ž\mathcal{C}. But the established terminology is that this is the sheaf condition (40) on presheaves over ð’ž\mathcal{C}. Those presheaves which satisfy this condition are called the sheaves (Def. 36 below).

Remark

Warning

Most (if not all) introductions to sheaf theory insist on motivating the concept from the special case of sheaves on topological spaces. This is good motivation for what Grothendieck called â€œpetit toposâ€-theory. The motivation above, instead, naturally leads to the â€œgros toposâ€-perspective, which is more useful for discussing the synthetic higher supergeometry of physics. In fact, this is the perspective of functorial geometry that has been highlighted since Grothendieck 65, but which has maybe remained underappreciated.

\,

We now first introduce the sheaf-condition (Def. 36) below in its traditional form via â€œmatching familiesâ€ (Def. 35 below). Then we show (Prop. 31 below) how this is equivalently expressed in terms of Cech groupoids (Example 43 below). This second formulation is convenient for understanding and handling various constructions in ordinary topos theory (for instance the definition of cohesive sites) and it makes immediate the generalization to higher topos theory.

\,

Descent

Definition

(coverage and site)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a small category (Def. 3). Then a coverage on ð’ž\mathcal{C} is

  • for each object Xâˆˆð’žX \in \mathcal{C} a set of indexed sets of morphisms into XX

    {U iâ†’Î¹ iX} iâˆˆI \left\{ U_i \overset{\iota_i}{\to} X \right\}_{i \in I}

    called the coverings of XX,

such that

  • for every covering {U iâ†’Î¹ iX} iâˆˆI\left\{ U_i \overset{\iota_i}{\to} X \right\}_{i \in I} of XX and every morphism YâŸ¶fXY \overset{f}{\longrightarrow} X there exists a refining covering {V jâ†’Î¹ jY} jâˆˆJ\left\{ V_j \overset{\iota_j}{\to} Y \right\}_{j \in J} of YY, meaning that for each jâˆˆJj \in J there exists iâˆˆIi \in I and a morphism V jâ†’Î¹ j,iU iV_j \overset{\iota_{j,i}}{\to} U_i such that

    (35)fâˆ˜Î¹ j=Î¹ iâˆ˜Î¹ j,iAAAAAAAV j âŸ¶Î¹ j,i U i Î¹ jâ†“ â†“ Î¹ i Y âŸ¶f X f \circ \iota_j \;=\; \iota_i \circ \iota_{j,i} \phantom{AAAAAAA} \array{ V_j &\overset{\iota_{j,i}}{\longrightarrow}& U_i \\ {}^{\mathllap{ \iota_j }}\big\downarrow && \big\downarrow{}^{\mathrlap{ \iota_i}} \\ Y &\underset{f}{\longrightarrow}& X }

A small category ð’ž\mathcal{C} equipped with a coverage is called a site.

Example

(differentiably good open covers of smooth manifolds)

The category SmthMfd of smooth manifold (Example 2) carries a coverage (Def. 34), where for XâˆˆSmthMfdX \in SmthMfd any smooth manifold of dimension Dâˆˆâ„•D \in \mathbb{N}, its coverings are collections of smooth functions from the Cartesian space â„ D\mathbb{R}^D to XX whose image is the inclusion of an open ball.

Hence these are the usual open covers of XX, but with the extra condition that every pathch is diffeomorphic to a Cartesian space (hence to a smooth open ball).

One may further constrain this and ask that also all the non-empty finite intersections of these open balls are diffeomorphic to open balls. These are the differentiably good open covers.

To see that these coverings satisfy the condition (35): The plain pullback of an open cover along any continuous function is again an open cover, just not necessarily by patches diffeomorphic to open balls. But every open cover may be refined by one that is (see at good open cover), and this is sufficient for (35).

Example 37 is further developed in the chapters smooth sets and on smooth homotopy types.

Definition

(matching family â€“ descent object)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a small category equipped with a coverage, hence a site (Def. 34) and consider a presheaf Yâˆˆ[ð’ž op,Set]\mathbf{Y} \in [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] (Example 14) over ð’ž\mathcal{C}.

Given an object Xâˆˆð’žX \in \mathcal{C} and a covering {U iâ†’Î¹ iX} iâˆˆI\left\{ U_i \overset{\iota_i}{\to} X \right\}_{i \in I} of it (Def. 34) we say that a matching family (of probes of Y\mathbf{Y}) is a tuple (Ï• iâˆˆY(U i)) iâˆˆI(\phi_i \in \mathbf{Y}(U_i))_{i \in I} such that for all i,jâˆˆIi,j \in I and pairs of morphisms U iâ†Îº iVâ†’Îº jU jU_i \overset{\kappa_i}{\leftarrow} V \overset{\kappa_j}{\to} U_j satisfying

(36)Î¹ iâˆ˜Îº i=Î¹ jâˆ˜Îº jAAAAAAAA V Îº iâ†™ â†˜ Îº j U i U j Î¹ iâ†˜ â†™ Î¹ j X \iota_i \circ \kappa_i \;=\; \iota_j \circ \kappa_j \phantom{AAAAAAAA} \array{ && V \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\kappa_i}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{\kappa_j}} \\ U_i && && U_j \\ & {}_{\mathllap{\iota_i}}\searrow && \swarrow_{\mathrlap{\iota_j}} \\ && X }

we have

(37)Y(Îº i)(Ï• i)=Y(Îº j)(Ï• j). \mathbf{Y}(\kappa_i)(\phi_i) \;=\; \mathbf{Y}(\kappa_j)(\phi_j) \,.

We write

(38)Match({U i} iâˆˆI,Y)âŠ‚âˆiY(U i)âˆˆSet Match\big( \{U_i\}_{i \in I} \,,\, \mathbf{Y} \big) \subset \underset{i}{\prod} \mathbf{Y}(U_i) \;\in\; Set

for the set of matching families for the given presheaf and covering.

This is also called the descent object of Y\mathbf{Y} for descent along the covering {U iâ†’Î¹ iX}\{U_i \overset{\iota_i}{\to}X\}.

Example

(matching families that glue)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a small category equipped with a coverage, hence a site (Def. 34) and consider a presheaf Yâˆˆ[ð’ž op,Set]\mathbf{Y} \in [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] (Example 14) over ð’ž\mathcal{C}.

Given an object Xâˆˆð’žX \in \mathcal{C} and a covering {U iâ†’Î¹ iX} iâˆˆI\left\{ U_i \overset{\iota_i}{\to} X \right\}_{i \in I} of it (Def. 34), then every element

Ï•âˆˆY(X) \phi \;\in\; \mathbf{Y}(X)

induces a matching family (Def. 35) by

(Y(Î¹ i)(Ï•)) iâˆˆI. \big( \mathbf{Y}(\iota_i)(\phi) \big)_{i \in I} \,.

(That this indeed satisfies the matching condition follows immediately bu the functoriality of Y\mathbf{Y}.)

This construction provides a function of the form

(39)Y(X)âŸ¶Match({U i} iâˆˆI,Y) \mathbf{Y}(X) \longrightarrow Match\big( \{U_i\}_{i \in I} \,,\, \mathbf{Y} \big)

The matching families in the image of this function are hence those tuples of probes of Y\mathbf{Y} by the patches U iU_i of XX which glue to a global probe out of XX.

Definition

(sheaf)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a small category equipped with a coverage, hence a site (Def. 34) and consider a presheaf Yâˆˆ[ð’ž op,Set]\mathbf{Y} \in [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] (Example 14) over ð’ž\mathcal{C}.

The presheaf Y\mathbf{Y} is called a sheaf if for every object Xâˆˆð’žX \in \mathcal{C} and every covering {U iâ†’Î¹ iX} iâˆˆI\left\{ U_i \overset{\iota_i}{\to} X \right\}_{i \in I} of XX all matching families glue uniquely, hence if the comparison morphism (39) is a bijection

(40)Y(X)âŸ¶â‰ƒMatch({U i} iâˆˆI,Y). \mathbf{Y}(X) \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} Match\big( \{U_i\}_{i \in I} \,,\, \mathbf{Y} \big) \,.

The full subcategory (Example 9) of the category of presheaves over a given site ð’ž\mathcal{C}, on those that are sheaves is the category of sheaves, denoted

Sh(ð’ž)â†ªAAAA[ð’¸ op,Set]. Sh(\mathcal{C}) \overset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\hookrightarrow} [\mathcal{c}^{op}, Set] \,.

A category which is equivalent (Def. 14) to a category of sheaves is called a sheaf topos, or often just topos, for short.

Example

(trivial coverage)

For ð’ž\mathcal{C} a small category (Def. 3), the trivial coverage on it is the coverage (Def. 34) with no covering families at all, meaning that the sheaf condition (Def. 36) over the resulting site is empty, in that every presheaf is a sheaf for this coverage.

Hence the category of presheaves [ð’ž op,Set][\mathcal{C}^{op},Set] (Example 14) over a site ð’ž triv\mathcal{C}_{triv} with trivial coverage is already the corresponding category of sheaves, hence the corresponding sheaf topos:

Sh(ð’ž triv)â‰ƒ[ð’ž op,Set]. Sh\left( \mathcal{C}_{triv}\right) \;\simeq\; [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] \,.
Example

(sheaves on the terminal category are plain sets)

Consider the terminal category *\ast (Example 3) equipped with its trivial coverage (Example 39). Then there is a canonical equivalence of categories (Def. 14) between the category of sheaves on this site (Def. 36) and the category of sets (Example 1):

Sh(*)â‰ƒSet. Sh(\ast) \;\simeq\; Set \,.

Hence the category of sets is a sheaf topos.

Example

(induced coverage)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a site (Def. 34). Then a full subcategory (Def. 8)

ð’Ÿâ†ªð’ž \mathcal{D} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{C}

becomes a site itself, whose coverage consists of those coverings {U iâ†’Î¹ iY}\{U_i \overset{\iota_i}{\to} Y\} in ð’ž\mathcal{C} that happen to be in ð’Ÿâ†ªð’ž\mathcal{D} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{C}.

Definition

(dense subsite)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} and ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} be sites (Def. 34) with a a full subcategory-inclusion (Def. 8)

ð’Ÿâ†ªð’ž \mathcal{D} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{C}

and regard ð’Ÿ\mathcal{D} as equipped with the induced coverage (Def. 41).

This is called a dense subsite-inclusion if every object Xâˆˆð’žX \in \mathcal{C} has a covering {U iâ†’Î¹ iX} i\{U_i \overset{\iota_i}{\to} X\}_i such that for all ii the patches are in the subcategory:

U iâˆˆð’Ÿâ†ªð’ž. U_i \;\in\; \mathcal{D} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{C} \,.
Proposition

(comparison lemma)

Let ð’Ÿâ†ªÎ¹ð’ž\mathcal{D} \overset{\iota}{\hookrightarrow} \mathcal{C} be a dense subsite inclusion (def. 37). Then precomposition with Î¹\iota induces an equivalence of categories (Def. 14) between their categories of sheaves (Def. 36):

Î¹ *:Sh(ð’ž)âŸ¶â‰ƒSh(ð’Ÿ) \iota^\ast \;\colon\; Sh(\mathcal{C}) \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow} Sh(\mathcal{D})
Proposition

(recognition of epi-/mono-/isomorphisms of sheaves)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a site (Def. 34) with Sh(ð’ž)Sh(\mathcal{C}) its category of sheaves (Def. 36).

Then a morphisms f:Xâ†’Yf \;\colon\; \mathbf{X} \to \mathbf{Y} in Sh(ð’ž)Sh(\mathcal{C}) is

  1. a monomorphism (Def. 7) or isomorphism (Def. 4) precisely if it is so globally in that for each object Uâˆˆð’žU \in \mathcal{C} in the site, then the component f U:X(U)â†’Y(U)f_U \colon \mathbf{X}(U) \to \mathbf{Y}(U) is an injection or bijection of sets, respectively.

  2. an epimorphism (Def. 7) precisely if it is so locally, in that: for all UâˆˆCU \in C there is a covering {p i:U iâ†’U} iâˆˆI\{p_i : U_i \to U\}_{i \in I} such that for all iâˆˆIi \in I and every element yâˆˆY(U)y \in \mathbf{Y}(U) the element f(p i)(y)f(p_i)(y) is in the image of f(U i):X(U i)â†’Y(U i)f(U_i) : \mathbf{X}(U_i) \to \mathbf{Y}(U_i).

Proposition

(epi/mono-factorization through image)

Let Sh(ð’ž)Sh(\mathcal{C}) be a category of sheaves (Def. 36). Then every morphism f:Xâ†’Yf \;\colon\; \mathbf{X} \to \mathbf{Y} factors as an epimorphism followed by a monomorphism (Def. 7) uniquely up to unique isomorphism:

f:XâŸ¶epiim(f)âŸ¶monoY. f \;\colon\; \mathbf{X} \overset{epi}{\longrightarrow} im(f) \overset{mono}{\longrightarrow} \mathbf{Y} \,.

The object im(f)im(f), as a subobject of Y\mathbf{Y}, is called the image of ff.

In fact this is an orthogonal factorization system, in that for every commuting square where the left morphism is an epimorphism, and the right one a monomorphism, there exists a unique lift:

(41)A âŸ¶AAA B epiâ†“ âˆƒ!â†— â†“ mono C âŸ¶AAA D \array{ A &\overset{\phantom{AAA}}{\longrightarrow}& B \\ {}^{\mathllap{epi}}\big\downarrow &{}^{\exists!}\nearrow& \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{mono}} \\ C &\underset{\phantom{AAA}}{\longrightarrow}& D }

This implies that this is a functorial factorization, in that for every commuting square

X 1 âŸ¶f 1 Y 1 â†“ â†“ X 2 âŸ¶f 2 Y 2 \array{ \mathbf{X}_1 &\overset{f_1}{\longrightarrow}& \mathbf{Y}_1 \\ \big\downarrow && \big\downarrow \\ \mathbf{X}_2 &\underset{f_2}{\longrightarrow}& \mathbf{Y}_2 }

there is an induced morphism of images such that the resulting rectangular diagram commutes:

X 1 âŸ¶epi im(f 1) âŸ¶mono Y 1 â†“ â†“ â†“ X 2 âŸ¶epi im(f 2) âŸ¶mono Y 2 \array{ \mathbf{X}_1 &\overset{epi}{\longrightarrow}& im(f_1) &\overset{mono}{\longrightarrow}& \mathbf{Y}_1 \\ \big\downarrow && \big\downarrow && \big\downarrow \\ \mathbf{X}_2 &\overset{epi}{\longrightarrow}& im(f_2) &\overset{mono}{\longrightarrow}& \mathbf{Y}_2 }

(â€¦)

Definition

A sheaf topos is subtopos of presheaf topos

Sh(C)â†ªâ†(âˆ’)Â¯PSh(C). Sh(C) \stackrel{\overset{\overline{(-)}}{\leftarrow}}{\hookrightarrow} PSh(C) \,.
Remark

Here the left adjoint (âˆ’)Â¯\overline{(-)}, which is equivalently

  • the inverse image of the geometric embedding geometric morphism

  • the sheafification functor

is precisely such that for every covering {U iâ†’U} iâˆˆI\{U_i \to U\}_{i \in I} in the site CC the sieve inclusion

S({U i})â†ªUâˆˆPSh(C) S(\{U_i\}) \hookrightarrow U \;\;\;\; \in PSh(C)

(a dense monomorphism) is sent to an isomorphism.

Hence the sheaf topos is the left exact localization at the covering sieve inclusions.

Remark

The presheaf topos PSh(C)PSh(C) is the free cocompletion of the category CC, hence the category obtained from CC by freely forming colimits of its objects.

In contrast, the localization Sh(C)â†ªPSh(C)Sh(C) \hookrightarrow PSh(C) enforces relations between these free colimits.

Therefore in total we may think of Sh(C)Sh(C) as obtained by generators and relations from the site CC:

  • the objects of CC are the generators;

  • the coverings of CC are the relations.

Def. 38 is the â€œexternalâ€ characterization of sheaf toposes.

More intrinsically we have Giraud's theorem:

Theorem

A sheaf topos is equivalently a presentable category with

  1. universal colimits

  2. effective quotients

  3. disjoint coproducts

This characterization, or rather its refinement to (infinity,1)-categories of (infinity,1)-sheaves, is crucial, below, for the discussion of principal bundles and their associated fiber bundles.

For other general considerations we need rather that every sheaf topos is in particular an elementary topos

Definition

An elementary topos is

  • a locally cartesian closed category

  • with a subobject classifier.

The first of these says that the internal language is dependent type theory with dependent sum types and dependent product types, the second says that it has a type of propositions.

(â€¦)

Codescent

In order to understand the sheaf condition (40) better, it is useful to consider Cech groupoids (Def. 43 below). These are really presheaves of groupoids (Def. 40 below), a special case of the general concept of enriched presheaves. The key property of the Cech groupoid is that it co-represents the sheaf condition (Prop. 31 below). It is in this incarnation that the concept of sheaf seamlessly generalizes to homotopy theory via â€œhigher stacksâ€.

\,

Definition

(presheaves of groupoids)

For ð’ž\mathcal{C} a small category (Def. 3) consider the functor category (Example 13) from the opposite category of ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Example 5) to the category Grpd of small groupoids (Example 7)

(42)[ð’ž op,Grpd]. [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Grpd] \,.

By Example 21 we may regard Grpd as a cosmos for enriched category theory. Since the inclusion Setâ†ªGrpdSet \hookrightarrow Grpd (Example 16) is a strong monoidal functor (Def. 22) of cosmoi (Example 21), the plain category ð’ž\mathcal{C} may be thought of as a Grpd-enriched category (Def. 24) and hence a functor ð’ž opâ†’Grpd\mathcal{C}^{op} \to Grpd is equivalently a Grpd-enriched functor (Def. 26).

This means that the plain category of functors [ð’ž op,Grpd][\mathcal{C}^{op}, Grpd] enriches to Grpd-enriched category of Grpd-enriched presheaves (Example 28).

Hence we may speak of presheaves of groupoids.

Remark

(presheaves of groupoids as internal groupoids in presheaves)

From every presheaf of groupoids Yâˆˆ[ð’ž op,Grpd]\mathbf{Y} \in [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Grpd] (Def. 40), we obtain two ordinary presheaves of sets (Def. 14) called the

  • presheaf of objects

    Obj Y(âˆ’)âˆˆ[ð’ž op,Set] Obj_{\mathbf{Y}(-)} \in [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set]

  • the presheaf of morphisms

    Mor Y(âˆ’)â‰”âˆx,yâˆˆObj Y(âˆ’)Hom Y(âˆ’):[ð’ž op,Set] Mor_{\mathbf{Y}(-)} \;\coloneqq\; \underset{x,y \in Obj_{\mathbf{Y}(-)}}{\coprod} Hom_{{\mathbf{Y}(-)}} \;\colon\; [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set]

In more abstract language this assignment constitutes an equivalence of categories

(43)[ð’ž op,Grpd] âŸ¶â‰ƒ Grpd([ð’ž op,Grpd]) Y â†¦ (AAAâˆx,yâˆˆObj Y(âˆ’)Hom Y(âˆ’)âŸMor Y(âˆ’) (xâ†’fy) â†¦ xâ†“â†‘ x â†¦ xâ†’id xxxâ†’id xâ†“ (xâ†’fy) â†¦ y Obj Y(âˆ’)AAA). \array{ [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Grpd] &\overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}& Grpd\left( [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Grpd]\right) \\ \mathbf{Y} &\mapsto& \left( \phantom{AAA} \array{ \underset{ Mor_{\mathbf{Y}(-)} }{ \underbrace{ \underset{x,y \in Obj_{\mathbf{Y}(-)}}{\coprod} Hom_{{\mathbf{Y}(-)}} }} \\ {}^{\mathllap{ \array{(x \overset{f}{\to}y) \\ \mapsto\\ x} } }\Big\downarrow \;\;\;\; \Big\uparrow^{\mathrlap{ \array{ x \\ \mapsto \\ x \overset{id_x}{\to} x } }} \phantom{x \overset{id_x}{\to} } \Big\downarrow^{ \mathrlap{ \array{ (x \overset{f}{\to} y) \\ \mapsto \\ y } } } \\ Obj_{\mathbf{Y}(-)} } \phantom{AAA} \right) } \,.

from presheaves of groupoids to internal groupoids- in the category of presheaves over ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Def. 14).

Example

(presheaves of sets form reflective subcategory of presheaves of groupoids)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a small category (Def. 3). There is the reflective subcategory-inclusion (Def. 15) of the category of presheaves over ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Example 14) into the category of presheaves of groupoids over ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Def. 40)

[ð’ž op,Set]âŠ¥â†ªAAAAâŸµÏ€ 0[ð’ž op,Grpd] [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] \underoverset {\underset{\phantom{AAAA}}{\hookrightarrow}} {\overset{\pi_0}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Grpd]

which is given over each object of ð’ž\mathcal{C} by the reflective inclusion of sets into groupoids (Example 16).

Example

(Cech groupoid)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a site (Def. 34), and Xâˆˆð’žX \in \mathcal{C} an object of that site. For each covering family {U iâ†’Î¹ iX}\{ U_i \overset{\iota_i}{\to} X\} of XX in the given coverage, the Cech groupoid is the presheaf of groupoids (Def. 40)

C({U i})âˆˆ[ð’ž op,Grpd]â‰ƒGrpd([ð’ž op,Set]) C(\{U_i\}) \;\in\; [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Grpd] \;\simeq\; Grpd\left( [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] \right)

which, regarded as an internal groupoid in the category of presheaves over ð’ž\mathcal{C}, via (43), has as presheaf of objects the coproduct

Obj C({U i})â‰”âˆiy(U i) Obj_{C(\{U_i\})} \;\coloneqq\; \underset{i}{\coprod} y(U_i)

of the presheaves represented (under the Yoneda embedding, Prop. 2) by the covering objects U iU_i, and as presheaf of morphisms the coproduct over all fiber products of these:

Mor C({U i})â‰”âˆi,jy(U i)Ã— y(X)y(U j). Mor_{C(\{U_i\})} \;\coloneqq\; \underset{i,j}{\coprod} y(U_i) \times_{y(X)} y(U_j) \,.

This means equivalently that for any Vâˆˆð’žV \in \mathcal{C} the groupoid assigned by C({U i})C(\{U_i\}) has as set of objects pairs consisting of an index ii and a morphism Vâ†’Îº iU iV \overset{\kappa_i}{\to} U_i in ð’ž\mathcal{C}, and there is a unique morphism between two such objects

Îº iâŸ¶Îº j \kappa_i \longrightarrow \kappa_j

precisely if

(44)Î¹ iâˆ˜Îº i=Î¹ jâˆ˜Îº jAAAAAAAA V Îº iâ†™ â†˜ Îº j U i U j Î¹ iâ†˜ â†™ Î¹ j X \iota_i \circ \kappa_i \;=\; \iota_j \circ \kappa_j \phantom{AAAAAAAA} \array{ && V \\ & {}^{\mathllap{\kappa_i}}\swarrow && \searrow^{\mathrlap{\kappa_j}} \\ U_i && && U_j \\ & {}_{\mathllap{\iota_i}}\searrow && \swarrow_{\mathrlap{\iota_j}} \\ && X }

Condition (44) for morphisms in the Cech groupoid to be well-defined is verbatim the condition (36) in the definition of matching families. Indeed, Cech groupoids serve to conveniently summarize (and then generalize) the sheaf condition (Def. 36):

Proposition

(Cech groupoid co-represents matching families â€“ codescent)

For Grpd regarded as a cosmos (Example 21), and ð’ž\mathcal{C} a site (Def. 34), let

Yâˆˆ[ð’ž op,Set]â†ª[ð’ž op,Grpd] \mathbf{Y} \in [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] \hookrightarrow [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Grpd]

be a presheaf on ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Example 14), regarded as a Grpd-enriched presheaf via Example 42, let Xâˆˆð’žX \in \mathcal{C} be any object and {U iâ†’Î¹ iX} i\{U_i \overset{\iota_i}{\to} X\}_i a covering family (Def. 34) with induced Cech groupoid C({U i} i)C(\{U_i\}_i) (Example 43).

Then there is an isomorphism

[ð’ž op,Grpd](C({U i} i),Y)â‰ƒMatch({U i} i,Y) [\mathcal{C}^{op},Grpd] \left( C\left(\{U_i\}_i\right), \, \mathbf{Y} \right) \;\simeq\; Match\left( \{U_i\}_i, \, \mathbf{Y} \right)

between the hom-groupoid of Grpd-enriched presheaves (Def. 33) and the set of matching families (Def. 35).

Since hence the Cech-groupoid co-represents the descent object, it is sometimes called the codescent object along the given covering.

Moreover, under this identification the canonical morphism

(45)C({U i} i)âŸ¶p {U i} iy(X) C\left( \{U_i\}_i \right) \overset{p_{\{U_i\}_i}}{\longrightarrow} y(X)

induces the comparison morphism (39)

[ð’ž op,Grpd](y(X),Y) â‰ƒ Y(X) [ð’ž op,Grpd](p {U i} i,Y)â†“ â†“ [ð’ž op,Grpd](C({U i} i),Y) â‰ƒ Match({U i} i,Y). \array{ [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Grpd]\left( y(X), \, \mathbf{Y} \right) & \simeq & \mathbf{Y}(X) \\ {}^{ \mathllap{ [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Grpd](p_{\{U_i\}_i}, \mathbf{Y}) } }\downarrow && \downarrow \\ [\mathcal{C}^{op},Grpd] \left( C\left(\{U_i\}_i\right), \, \mathbf{Y} \right) &\simeq& Match\left( \{U_i\}_i, \, \mathbf{Y} \right) } \,.

In conclusion, this means that the presheaf Y\mathbf{Y} is a sheaf (Def. 36) precisely if homming Cech groupoid projections into it produces an isomorphism:

(46)Yis a sheafAAAAâ‡”AAAA[C({U i} i)â†’p {U i}Iy(X),Y]is iso, for all covering families{U iâ†’X} \mathbf{Y} \,\text{is a sheaf} \phantom{AAAA} \Leftrightarrow \phantom{AAAA} \left[ C\left( \{U_i\}_i \right) \overset{p_{\{U_i\}I}}{\to} y(X) \;,\; \mathbf{Y} \right] \, \text{is iso, for all covering families} \, \{U_i \to X\}

One also says in this case that Y\mathbf{Y} is a local object with respect to Cech covers/

Proof

By (28) the hom-groupoid is computed as the end

[ð’ž op,Grpd](C({U i} i),Y)=âˆ« Vâˆˆð’ž[C({U i} i)(V),Y(V)], [\mathcal{C}^{op},Grpd] \left( C\left(\{U_i\}_i\right), \, \mathbf{Y} \right) \;=\; \int_{V \in \mathcal{C}} \left[ C\left(\{U_i\}_i\right)(V), \, \mathbf{Y}(V) \right] \,,

where, by Example 21, the â€œintegrandâ€ is the functor category (here: a groupoid) from the Cech groupoid at a given VV to the set (regarded as a groupoid) assigned by Y\mathbf{Y} to VV.

Since Y(V)\mathbf{Y}(V) is just a set, that functor groupoid, too, is just a set, regarded as a groupoid. Its elements are the functors C({U i} i)(V)âŸ¶Y(V)C\left(\{U_i\}_i\right)(V) \longrightarrow \mathbf{Y}(V), which are equivalently those functions on sets of objects

âˆiy(U i)(V)=Obj C({U i} i)(V)âŸ¶Obj Y(V)=Y(V) \underset{i}{\coprod} y(U_i)(V) = Obj_{C\left(\{U_i\}_i\right)(V)} \longrightarrow Obj_{\mathbf{Y}(V)} = \mathbf{Y}(V)

which respect the equivalence relation induced by the morphisms in the Cech groupoid at VV.

Hence the hom-groupoid is a subset of the end of these function sets:

âˆ« Vâˆˆð’ž[C({U i} i)(V),Y(V)] â†ªâˆ« Vâˆˆð’ž[âˆiy(U i)(V),Y(V)] â‰ƒâˆ« Vâˆˆð’žâˆi[y(U i)(V),Y(V)] â‰ƒâˆiâˆ« Vâˆˆð’ž[y(U i)(V),Y(V)] â‰ƒâˆiY(U i) \begin{aligned} \int_{V \in \mathcal{C}} \left[ C\left(\{U_i\}_i\right)(V), \, \mathbf{Y}(V) \right] & \hookrightarrow \int_{V \in \mathcal{C}} \left[ \underset{i}{\coprod} y(U_i)(V), \, \mathbf{Y}(V) \right] \\ & \simeq \int_{V \in \mathcal{C}} \underset{i}{\prod} \left[ y(U_i)(V), \, \mathbf{Y}(V) \right] \\ & \simeq \underset{i}{\prod} \int_{V \in \mathcal{C}} \left[ y(U_i)(V), \, \mathbf{Y}(V) \right] \\ & \simeq \underset{i}{\prod} \mathbf{Y}(U_i) \end{aligned}

Here we used: first that the internal hom-functor turns colimits in its first argument into limits (Prop. 14), then that limits commute with limits (Prop. 18), hence that in particular ends commute with products , and finally the enriched Yoneda lemma (Prop. 19), which here is, via Example 33, just the plain Yoneda lemma (Prop. 1). The end result is hence the same Cartesian product set that also the set of matching families is defined to be a subset of, in (38).

This shows that an element in âˆ« Vâˆˆð’ž[C({U i} i)(V),Y(V)] \int_{V \in \mathcal{C}} \left[ C\left(\{U_i\}_i\right)(V), \, \mathbf{Y}(V) \right] is a tuple (Ï• iâˆˆY(U i)) i(\phi_i \in \mathbf{Y}(U_i))_i, subject to some condition. This condition is that for each Vâˆˆð’žV \in \mathcal{C} the assignment

C({U i} i)(V) âŸ¶ Y(V) (Vâ†’Îº iU i) â†¦ Îº i *Ï• i=Y(Îº i)(Ï• i) \array{ C\left(\{U_i\}_i\right)(V) & \longrightarrow & \mathbf{Y}(V) \\ (V \overset{\kappa_i}{\to} U_i) &\mapsto& \kappa_i^\ast \phi_i = \mathbf{Y}(\kappa_i)(\phi_i) }

constitutes a functor of groupoids.

By definition of the Cech groupoid, and since the codomain is a just set regarded as a groupoid, this is the case precisely if

Y(Îº i)(Ï• i)=Y(Îº j)(Ï• j)AAAAfor alli,j, \mathbf{Y}(\kappa_i)(\phi_i) \;=\; \mathbf{Y}(\kappa_j)(\phi_j) \phantom{AAAA} \text{for all}\, i,j \,,

which is exactly the condition (37) that makes (Ï• i) i(\phi_i)_i a matching family.

\,

Cohesive toposes

Here we discuss basic concepts of cohesive topos theory.

Remark

(cohesive generalized spaces as foundations of geometry)

We have seen that presheaves model generalized spaces (Remark 2) and that the sheaves among them adhere to a local-to-global principle (Remark 9). However, the classical example of sheaves on a topological space? shows that the generalized spaces which are the objects of some categories of sheaves may depend on, or be parameterized over, an ordinary topological space. If we aim to lay foundations for geometry, then we are interested in isolating those kinds of generalized spaces which have foundational a priori meaning independent of an otherwise pre-configured notion of space.

In particular, categories of such foundational generalized spaces ought to have an internal logic that knows about modalities of geometry such as discreteness or concreteness. Via the mathematical formalization of modalities (Def. 16) this leads to the definiton of cohesive toposes (Def. 41 below, Lawvere 91, Lawvere 07).

(â€¦)

\,

Definition

(cohesive topos)

A sheaf topos H\mathbf{H} (Def. 36) is called a cohesive topos if there is a quadruple of adjoint functors (Def. 10) to the category of sets (Example 1)

(47)Î  0âŠ£DiscâŠ£Î“âŠ£coDisc:HâŸ¶AAAÎ  0AAA â†©AADiscAA âŸ¶AAAÎ“AAA â†©AAcoDiscAASet \Pi_0 \dashv Disc \dashv \Gamma \dashv coDisc \;\;\colon\;\; \mathbf{H} \array{ \overset{\phantom{AAA} \Pi_0 \phantom{AAA}}{\longrightarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AA} Disc \phantom{AA} }{\hookleftarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AAA} \Gamma \phantom{AAA} }{\longrightarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AA} coDisc \phantom{AA} }{\hookleftarrow} } Set

such that:

  1. DiscDisc and coDisccoDisc are full and faithful functors (Def. 8)

  2. Î  0\Pi_0 preserves finite products.

Example

(adjoint quadruple of presheaves over site with terminal objects)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a small category (Def. 3) with finite products (hence with a terminal object *âˆˆð’ž\ast \in \mathcal{C} and for any two objects X,Yâˆˆð’žX,Y \in \mathcal{C} their Cartesian product XÃ—Yâˆˆð’žX \times Y \in \mathcal{C}).

Then there is an adjoint quadruple of functors between the category of presheaves over ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Example 14), and the category of sets (Example 1)

(48)[ð’ž,Set]âŸ¶AAAÎ  0AAA â†©AADiscAA âŸ¶AAAÎ“AAA â†©AAcoDiscAASet [\mathcal{C}, Set] \array{ \overset{\phantom{AAA} \Pi_0 \phantom{AAA}}{\longrightarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AA} Disc \phantom{AA} }{\hookleftarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AAA} \Gamma \phantom{AAA} }{\longrightarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AA} coDisc \phantom{AA} }{\hookleftarrow} } Set

such that:

  1. the functor Î“\Gamma sends a presheaf Y\mathbf{Y} to its set of global sections, which here is its value on the terminal object:

    (49)Î“Y =limâŸµð’žY â‰ƒY(*) \begin{aligned} \Gamma \mathbf{Y} & = \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} \mathbf{Y} \\ & \simeq \mathbf{Y}(\ast) \end{aligned}

  2. DiscDisc and coDisccoDisc are full and faithful functors (Def. 8).

  3. Î  0\Pi_0 preserves finite products:

    for X,Yâˆˆ[ð’ž op,Set]\mathbf{X}, \mathbf{Y} \in [\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set], we have a natural bijection

    Î  0(XÃ—Y)â‰ƒÎ  0(X)Ã—Î  0(Y). \Pi_0(\mathbf{X} \times \mathbf{Y}) \;\simeq\; \Pi_0(\mathbf{X}) \times \Pi_0(\mathbf{Y}) \,.

Hence the category of presheaves over a small category with finite products, hence the category of sheaves for the trivial coverage (Example 39) is a cohesive topos (Def. 41).

Proof

The existence of the terminal object in ð’ž\mathcal{C} means equivalently (by Example 3) that there is an adjoint pair of functors between ð’ž\mathcal{C} and the terminal category (Example 3):

*âŠ¥â†ªâŸµpð’ž \ast \underoverset {\underset{}{\hookrightarrow}} {\overset{p}{\longleftarrow}} {\bot} \mathcal{C}

whose right adjoint takes the unique object of the terminal category to that terminal object.

From this it follows, by Example 36, that Kan extension produces an adjoint quadruple of functors between the category of presheaves [ð’ž op,Set][\mathcal{C}^{op}, Set] and [*,Set]â‰ƒSet[\ast, Set] \simeq Set, as shown, where

  1. Î“\Gamma is the operation of pre-composition with the terminal object inclusion *â†ªð’ž\ast \hookrightarrow \mathcal{C}

  2. DiscDisc is the left Kan extension along the inclusion *â†ªð’ž\ast \hookrightarrow \mathcal{C} of the terminal object.

The former is manifestly the operation of evaluating on the terminal object. Moreover, since the terminal object inclusion is manifestly a fully faithful functor (Def. 8), it follows that also its left Kan extension DiscDisc is fully faithful (Prop. 26). This implies that also coDisccoDisc is fully faithful, by (Prop. 24).

Equivalently, Discâ‰ƒp *Disc \simeq p^\ast is the constant diagram-assigning functor. By uniqueness of adjoints (Prop. 7) implies that Î  0\Pi_0 is the functor that sends a presheaf, regarded as a functor Y:ð’ž opâ†’Set\mathbf{Y} \;\colon\; \mathcal{C}^{op} \to Set, to its colimit

(50)Î  0(Y)=limâŸ¶ð’ž opY. \Pi_0(\mathbf{Y}) \;=\; \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \mathbf{Y} \,.

The fact that this indeed preserves products follows from the assumption that ð’ž\mathcal{C} has finite products, since categories with finite products are cosifted (Prop. 27)

Example 44 suggests to ask for coverages on categories with finite products which are such that the adjoint quadruple (48) on the category of presheaves (co-)restricts to the corresponding category of sheaves. The following Definition 42 states a sufficient condition for this to be the case:

Definition

(cohesive site)

We call a site ð’ž\mathcal{C} (Def. 34) cohesive if the following conditions are satisfied:

  1. The category ð’ž\mathcal{C} has finite products (as in Example 44).

  2. For every covering family {U iâ†’X} i\{U_i \to X\}_i in the given coverage on ð’ž\mathcal{C} the induced Cech groupoid C({U i} i)âˆˆ[C op,Grpd]C(\{U_i\}_i) \in [C^{op}, Grpd] (Def. 43) satisfies the following two conditions:

    1. the set of connected components of the groupoid obtained as the colimit over the Cech groupoid is the singleton:

      Ï€ 0limâŸ¶ð’ž opC({U i})â‰ƒ* \pi_0 \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} C(\{U_i\}) \;\simeq\; \ast

    2. the set of connected components of the groupoid obtained as the limit of the Cech groupoid is equivalent to the set of points of XX, regarded as a groupoid:

      Ï€ 0limâŸµð’ž opC({U i})â‰ƒHom ð’ž(*,X). \pi_0 \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}^{op}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} C(\{U_i\}) \simeq Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(\ast,X) \,.

This definition is designed to make the following true:

Proposition

(category of sheaves on a cohesive site is a cohesive topos)

Let ð’ž\mathcal{C} be a cohesive site (Def. 42). Then the adjoint quadruple on the category of presheaves over ð’ž\mathcal{C}, from Example 44 (given that a cohesive site by definition has finite products) (co-)restricts from the category of presheaves over ð’ž\mathcal{C}, to the category of sheaves (Def. 36) and hence exhibits Sh(ð’ž)Sh(\mathcal{C}) as a cohesive topos (Def. 41):

(51)Sh(ð’ž)âŸ¶AAAÎ  0AAA â†©AADiscAA âŸ¶AAAÎ“AAA â†©AAcoDiscAASet Sh(\mathcal{C}) \array{ \overset{\phantom{AAA} \Pi_0 \phantom{AAA}}{\longrightarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AA} Disc \phantom{AA} }{\hookleftarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AAA} \Gamma \phantom{AAA} }{\longrightarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AA} coDisc \phantom{AA} }{\hookleftarrow} } Set
Proof

With Example \ref{SmoothFunctionOnSmoothSpace} it only remains to be shown that for each set SS the presheaves Disc(S)Disc(S) and coDisc(S)coDisc(S) are indeed sheaves.

By the formulaton of the sheaf condition via the Cech groupoid (Prop. 31), and using the adjunction hom-isomorphisms (here) this is readily seen to be equivalent to the two further conditions on a cohesive site (Def. 42):

Let {U iâ†’X}\{U_i \to X\} be a covering family.

The sheaf condition (46) for Disc(S)Disc(S) says that

[C({U i})â†’p {U i} iy(X),Disc(S)] \left[ C(\{U_i\}) \overset{p_{\{U_i\}_i}}{\to} y(X) \,,\, Disc(S) \right]

is an isomorphism of groupoids, which by adjunction and using (50) means equivalently that

[limâŸ¶ð’ž op(C({U i}))â†’*,S] \left[ \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \left( C(\{U_i\}) \right) \to \ast \,,\, S \right]

is an isomorphism of groupoids, where we used that colimits of representables are singletons (Lemma 2) to replace limâŸ¶ð’ž opy(X)â‰ƒ*\underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} y(X) \simeq \ast.

But now in this internal hom of groupoids, the set SS is really a groupoid in the image of the reflective embedding of sets into groupoids, whose left adjoint is the connected components-functor Ï€ 0\pi_0 (Example 16). Hence by another adjunction isomoprhism this is equivalent to

[Ï€ 0limâŸ¶ð’ž op(C({U i}))â†’*,S] \left[ \pi_0 \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \left( C(\{U_i\}) \right) \to \ast \,,\, S \right]

being an isomorphism (a bijection of sets, now). This is true for all SâˆˆSetS \in Set precisely if (by the Yoneda lemma, if you wish) the morphism

Ï€ 0limâŸ¶ð’ž op(C({U i}))â†’* \pi_0 \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}^{op}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} \left( C(\{U_i\}) \right) \to \ast

is already an isomorphism (here: bijection) itself.

Similarly, the sheaf condition (46) for coDisc(S)coDisc(S) says that

[C({U i})â†’p {U i} iy(X),coDisc(S)] \left[ C(\{U_i\}) \overset{p_{\{U_i\}_i}}{\to} y(X) \,,\, coDisc(S) \right]

is an isomorphism, and hence by adjunction and using (49), this is equivalent to

[Ï€ 0limâŸµð’ž opC({U i})â†’p {U i} iHom ð’ž(*,X),S] \left[ \pi_0 \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}^{op}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} C(\{U_i\}) \overset{p_{\{U_i\}_i}}{\to} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(\ast, X) \,,\, S \right]

being an isomorphism. This holds for all SâˆˆSetS \in Set if (by the Yoneda lemma, if you wish)

Ï€ 0limâŸµð’ž opC({U i})â†’p {U i} iHom ð’ž(*,X) \pi_0 \underset{\underset{\mathcal{C}^{op}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} C(\{U_i\}) \overset{p_{\{U_i\}_i}}{\to} Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(\ast, X)

is an isomorphism.

Definition

(adjoint triple of modal operators on cohesive topos)

Given a cohesive topos (Def. 41), its adjoint quadruple of functors to and from Set

(52)Î  0âŠ£DiscâŠ£Î“âŠ£coDisc:HâŸ¶AAAÎ  0AAA â†©AADiscAA âŸ¶AAAÎ“AAA â†©AAcoDiscAASet \Pi_0 \dashv Disc \dashv \Gamma \dashv coDisc \;\;\colon\;\; \mathbf{H} \array{ \overset{\phantom{AAA} \Pi_0 \phantom{AAA}}{\longrightarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AA} Disc \phantom{AA} }{\hookleftarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AAA} \Gamma \phantom{AAA} }{\longrightarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AA} coDisc \phantom{AA} }{\hookleftarrow} } Set

induce, by composition of functors, an adjoint triple of endofunctors

ÊƒâŠ£â™­âŠ£â™¯:Hâ†©Êƒâ‰”Discâˆ˜Î  0 âŸ¶â™­â‰”Discâˆ˜Î“ â†©â™¯â‰”coDiscâˆ˜Î“H. &#643; \dashv \flat \dashv \sharp \;\;\colon\;\; \mathbf{H} \array{ \overset{ &#643; \;\coloneqq\; Disc \circ \Pi_0 }{\hookleftarrow} \\ \overset{\flat \;\coloneqq\; Disc \circ \Gamma }{\longrightarrow} \\ \overset{ \sharp \;\coloneqq\; coDisc\circ \Gamma }{\hookleftarrow} } \mathbf{H} \,.

Since DiscDisc and coDisccoDisc are fully faithful functors by assumption, these are (co-)modal operators (Def. 16) on the cohesive topos, by (Prop. 10).

We pronounce these as follows:

A\phantom{A} shape modality A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} flat modality A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} sharp modality A\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A} Êƒâ‰”Discâˆ˜Pi 0&#643; \;\coloneqq\; Disc \circ Pi_0 A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} â™­â‰”Discâˆ˜Î“\flat \;\coloneqq\; Disc \circ \Gamma A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} â™¯â‰”coDiscâˆ˜Î“\sharp \;\coloneqq\; coDisc \circ \Gamma A\phantom{A}

and we refer to the corresponding modal objects (Def. 17) as follows:

  • a flat-comodal object

    â™­XâŸ¶â‰ƒAÏµ X â™­AX \flat X \underoverset{\simeq}{\phantom{A}\epsilon^\flat_X \phantom{A}}{\longrightarrow} X

    is called a discrete object;

  • a sharp-modal object

    XâŸ¶â‰ƒAÎ· X â™¯Aâ™¯X X \underoverset{\simeq}{\phantom{A}\eta^\sharp_X\phantom{A}}{\longrightarrow} \sharp X

    is called a codiscrete object;

  • a sharp-submodal object

    XâŸ¶monoAÎ· X â™¯Aâ™¯X X \underoverset{mono}{\phantom{A}\eta^\sharp_X\phantom{A}}{\longrightarrow} \sharp X

    is a concrete object.

Proposition

(quasitopos of concrete objects in a cohesive topos)

For H\mathbf{H} a cohesive topos (Def. 41), write

H concâ†ªAAAAH \mathbf{H}_{conc} \overset{ \phantom{AAAA} }{\hookrightarrow} \mathbf{H}

for its full subcategory (Example 9) of concrete objects (Def. 45).

Then there is a sequence of reflective subcategory-inclusions (Def. 15) that factor the (Î“âŠ£coDisc)(\Gamma \dashv coDisc)-adjunction as

Î“âŠ£coDisc:HâŸ¶AAconcAA â†©AAÎ¹ concAAH concâŸ¶AAA â†©AAASet \Gamma \;\dashv\; coDisc \;\;\colon\;\; \mathbf{H} \array{ \overset{\phantom{AA} conc \phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AA} \iota_{conc} \phantom{AA}}{\hookleftarrow} } \mathbf{H}_{conc} \array{ \overset{\phantom{AAA}}{\longrightarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AAA}}{\hookleftarrow} } Set
Proof

For the adjunction on the right, we just need to observe that for every set SâˆˆSetS \in Set, the codiscrete object coDisc(S)coDisc(S) is concrete, which is immediate by idempotency of â™¯\sharp (Prop. 11) and the fact that every isomorphism is also a monomorphism.

For the adjunction on the left we claim that the left adjoint concconc, (to be called concretification), is given by sending each object to the image (Def. 30) of its (Î“âŠ£coDisc)(\Gamma \dashv coDisc) adjunction unit Î· â™¯\eta^\sharp:

conc:Xâ†¦im(Î· X â™¯). conc \;\colon\; X \mapsto im(\eta^\sharp_X) \,.

The the adjunction unit of (concâŠ£Î¹ conc)(conc \dashv \iota_{conc}) is provided by the epimorphism in the epi/mono-factorization, via Prop. 30:

(52)X 1 âŸ¶epiÎ· X 1 conc im(Î· X 1 â™¯) âŸ¶mono â™¯X 1 â†“ â†“ â†“ X 2 âŸ¶epiÎ· X 2 conc im(Î· X 2 â™¯) âŸ¶mono â™¯X 2 \array{ X_1 &\underoverset{epi}{\eta^{conc}_{X_1}}{\longrightarrow}& im(\eta^\sharp_{X_1}) &\underset{mono}{\longrightarrow}& \sharp X_1 \\ \big\downarrow && \big\downarrow && \big\downarrow \\ X_2 &\underoverset{epi}{\eta^{conc}_{X_2}}{\longrightarrow}& im(\eta^\sharp_{X_2}) &\underset{mono}{\longrightarrow}& \sharp X_2 }

To see this, it is sufficient, by Prop. 6, to show that Î· conc\eta^{conc} is a universal morphism in the sense of Def. 12. Hence consider any morphism f:X 1â†’X 2f \;\colon\; X_1 \to X_2 with X 2âˆˆH concâ†ªHX_2 \in \mathbf{H}_{conc} \hookrightarrow \mathbf{H}. Then we need to show that there is a unique diagonal morphism as below, that makes the following top left triangle commute:

X 1 âŸ¶AAfAA X 2 epiâ†“ Î· X 1 conc âˆƒ!â†— â†“ mono im(Î· X 1 â™¯) âŸ¶ â™¯X 2 \array{ X_1 &\overset{\phantom{AA} f \phantom{AA}}{\longrightarrow}& X_2 \\ {}^{\mathllap{epi}}\big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{\eta^{conc}_{X_1}}} &{}^{\mathllap{\exists !}}\nearrow& \big\downarrow^{\mathrlap{mono}} \\ im(\eta^\sharp_{X_1}) &\underset{}{\longrightarrow}& \sharp X_2 }

Now, from (52), we have a commuting square as shown. Here the left morphism is an epimorphism by construction, while the right morphism is a monomorphism by assumption on X 2X_2. With this, the epi/mono-factorization in Prop. 30 says that there is a diagonal lift which makes both triangles commute.

It remains to see that the lift is unique with just the property of making the top left triangle commute. But this is equivalently the statement that the left morphism is an epimorphism, by Def. 7.

Definition

(differentially cohesive topos)

Let H red\mathbf{H}_{red} be a cohesive topos (Def. 41). Then a differentially cohesive topos over H red\mathbf{H}_{red} is another cohesive topos H\mathbf{H}, equipped with an quadrupe of adjoint functors (Def. 10) of the form

Hâ†ªAAi !AA âŸµAAi *AA â†ªAAi *AA âŸµAAi !AAH red \mathbf{H} \array{ \overset{\phantom{AA} i_! \phantom{AA} }{\hookrightarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AA} i^\ast \phantom{AA} }{\longleftarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AA} i_\ast \phantom{AA} }{\hookrightarrow} \\ \overset{\phantom{AA} i^! \phantom{AA} }{\longleftarrow} } \mathbf{H}_{red}
Definition

(adjoint triple of modal operators on differentially cohesive topos)

Given a differentially cohesive topos H\mathbf{H} over H red\mathbf{H}_{red} (Def. 44), its adjoint quadruple of functors to and from the cohesive topos H red\mathbf{H}_{red} (Def. \ref{}CohesiveTopos)

induce, by composition of functors, an adjoint triple of endofunctors

â„œâŠ£â„‘âŠ£&:Hâ†©â„œâ‰”i !âˆ˜i * âŸ¶â™­â‰”i *âˆ˜i * â†©â™¯â‰”i *âˆ˜i !H. \Re \dashv \Im \dashv \& \;\;\colon\;\; \mathbf{H} \array{ \overset{ \Re \;\coloneqq\; i_! \circ i^\ast }{\hookleftarrow} \\ \overset{\flat \;\coloneqq\; i_\ast \circ i^\ast }{\longrightarrow} \\ \overset{ \sharp \;\coloneqq\; i_\ast \circ i^! }{\hookleftarrow} } \mathbf{H} \,.

Since i !i_! and i*i\ast are fully faithful functors by assumption, these are (co-)modal operators (Def. 16) on the cohesive topos, by (Prop. 10).

We pronounce these as follows:

A\phantom{A} reduction modality A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} infinitesimal shape modality A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} infinitesimal flat modality A\phantom{A}
A\phantom{A} â„œâ‰”i !âˆ˜i *\Re \;\coloneqq\; i_! \circ i^\ast A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} â„‘â‰”i *âˆ˜i *\Im \;\coloneqq\; i_\ast \circ i^\ast A\phantom{A}A\phantom{A} &â‰”i *âˆ˜i ! \& \;\coloneqq\; i_\ast \circ i^! A\phantom{A}

and we refer to the corressponding modal objects (Def. 17) as follows:

  • a reduction-comodal object

    â„œXâŸ¶â‰ƒÏµ X â„œX \Re X \underoverset{\simeq}{\epsilon^\Re_X}{\longrightarrow} X

    is called a reduced object;

  • an infinitesimal shape-modal object

    XâŸ¶â‰ƒAÎ· X â„‘Aâ„‘X X \underoverset{\simeq}{\phantom{A}\eta^\Im_X\phantom{A}}{\longrightarrow} \Im X

    is called a coreduced object.

(â€¦)

  1. â€œthe universality of the concept of adjointness, which was first isolated and named in the conceptual sphere of category theoryâ€ (Lawvere 69) â€œIn all those areas where category theory is actively used the categorical concept of adjoint functor has come to play a key role.â€ (first line from An interview with William Lawvere, paraphrasing the first paragraph of Taking categories seriously) â†©
